story: The latest weather forecast says Britain will be battered by brutal downpours as hurricane-force winds and ft waves crash along the coast.The Met Office issued severe yellow weather warnings for wind for nearly all of the UK — and snow is forecast in England, Scotland and Wales.Motorists have been warned of the dangers of Black Wednesday after Gareth doubled in size in  hours, from , to , miles wide, bringing gales from Iceland to Spain.Six crew had to be airlted from a stricken fishing boat in ft waves last night and this morning rail services have been cancelled and roads closed to high-sided vehicles.Brian Gaze, forecaster and director of The Weather Outlook told, The Sun Online: Heavy showers will affect Wales and north western parts of Britain.Over the hills they will turn to snow - cm to cm is possible over higher parts of the Scottish mountains.The Welsh mountains and hills in northern England could also have a few centimetres on the ground.In addition to the most powerful mph gales hitting the north west coast, gusts of up to mph are possible throughout much of the UK.He added: The combination of strong winds and heavy snow showers could lead to blizzard conditions over high ground in the north.A fiver will be paid into your bank account within four months of completing the switch. prepayment meter customer customers will receive a £ Amazon voucher. Open to those  and over. UK residents only. Click here for full TCs.RAC spokesman Simon Williams said: “Its Black Wednesday for travel with rush-hour dangers to motorists from fallen trees, debris and floods, plus traffic jams from increased accidents and road and bridge closures.”, roadside call-outs were projected today across all UK breakdown providers, the RAC said.Commuters using trains in Wales, Scotland, the north of England and East Anglia were warned that services could be disrupted by high winds during the morning rush hour, with speed restrictions in place across a wide area.Trains between Durham and Newcastle were halted until at least am after overhead electric wires were damaged, impacting LNER, CrossCountry, Northern and Transpennine Express services.Meanwhile, some Virgin Trains services between Manchester Piccadilly and London Euston and some trains between Glasgow Central and Preston were cancelled.There were also reports of trees blocking roads and some exposed routes in the north-east of England being closed to high-sided vehicles.Sandbags are on standby as cities, including flood-prone York, brace for floods.The Environment Agency said: “Flooding impacts are probable in York on Wednesday and in the Pennines on Thursday, with possible flooding impacts in other parts of the North, Midlands and West.”The Met office warned Storm Gareths gales will register Force  on the Beaufort Scale in many regions. There is only one level higher - and that is a hurricane.As trees were brought crashing down across power lines, nearly  homes, shops and offices near Bakewell in Derbyshires Peak District have been blacked out this morning.The A in Leicestershire is closed in both directions between the M and the A near Hinckley after a pile-up in which an HGV overturned and shed its load. Its likely to stay shut till at least lunchtime.The A over the Humber Bridge has been closed to high sided and vulnerable vehicles such as caravans and motorcyclists due to strong winds in the area.Gareth is the largest named storm to affect Britain since Storm Doris on February , , Met Office maps of past short storms showed.Mr Gaze said: “Gareth is a mega-storm, spanning much of western Europe.”The Met Office warned of gusts up to mph early this morning in Scotland, and mph in England, with up to two inches of rain.ft waves – the height of a five-story building – were due overnight off the west coast of Scotland, after ft waves hit the K Atlantic buoy yesterday, data from surfing website magicseaweed showed.“Phenomenal” sea conditions were reported as red shipping warnings were issued from Greenland to Spain.Gareth underwent ‘explosive cyclogenesis’ - becoming what is known as a ‘weather bomb’ - as its air pressure plunged by over  milibars in  hours.Gales ease this afternoon but pick up later tomorrow with a windy end to the week ahead.Three climbers died yesterday after being caught in an avalanche on Ben Nevis, Britains highest mountain, following heavy snowfall hit Scotland.At the Cheltenham Festival, punters were advised that organisers would be holding a precautionary inspection in the morning, although officials later gave the go-ahead after winds eased.It is feared that howling winds could put temporary structures in danger of being blown over.It is expected that a fortnights worth of rain will fall in less than a day in some parts of the north west.Met Office forecaster Bonnie Diamond said an explosive cyclone is seeing the Atlantic storm deepen rapidly.She added: “We expect structural damage to buildings, trees blown down, large waves on coasts and possible power cuts. People should be aware of warnings.“Gusts of -mph and possibly mph over higher ground are forecast — highest in western Scotland.John Hammond, chief meteorologist for Weathertrending told The Sun Online: “Cold air is sweeping in from the northwest and will be with us through Wednesday.Over in Wales the River Conwy burst its banks at Llanrwst causing nearby roads to flood.Yesterday, the eastbound carriageway of the M Severn Crossing was closed for a while due to the weather.There was also congestion on the M northbound in Gloucestershire at JA when two lanes were closed due to flooding.A slip road on the M in Cumbria was also closed due to flash flooding caused by the heavy rain.Train services were disrupted in the south-west with CrossCountry Trains forced to reduce its service due to the high winds.Southwestern and Virgin Trains had to operate at reduced speeds on their lines.In the West Country the storm caused power cuts and fallen trees blocking roads.The main train line through Dawlish, Devon, was closed.After the rain clears, the storm is expected to bring strong winds, with a chance of damage to buildings, power cuts and travel problems.A yellow weather warning for rain is also in place in parts of northern England on Thursday.The storm, caused by a deep area of low pressure, was named by Met Eireann, the Irish weather service.It is the third named storm this year after Storm Erik in February and Freya earlier this month.

title: bullied pupil cries classmates surprise gift tennessee
story: Azrael Robinson, , from Tennessee, US, was given a new pair of trainers by his friends in recognition of his selfless behaviour towards others.The teenager, who attends LaVergne High School, had previously been bullied at another school.In the viral clip, Azrael starts to sob when he unwraps and opens the box to reveal an expensive pair of Nike shoes.Two of his pals had presented him with the generous gt along with some cash and new clothes to say thank you for his kindness towards his fellow classmates.One of the pupil’s sister posted the video of the moment online.She wrote: “Today, my little sister sent me a video of what they did for one of their classmates, that’s having a hard time.“They all got together and bought him some shoes, and also donated clothes to this kid. ‘This video is so emotional  filled with love.“You just never know what kids go through, but it’s kids like them, that gives us hope.”The boy’s teacher Sonji Newman spoke to TODAY about Azrael’s kindness towards others.She said: “If they don’t understand something, he’s the first one to help.“If anything is dropped in the classroom, he’s the first one to pick it up.“If a student is down, he’s the first one to say everything is going to be okay.“They just wanted to give to him to make him feel better about himself. He was so grateful and so full of love. He just appreciated it so much.”Azrael’s mum Traci also said her son was so overwhelmed by the touching gt that he cried the whole way home.

title: tim berners lee how to save the world wide web
story: It is a moment to celebrate how far we have come, but also an opportunity to reflect on how far we have yet to go.The web has become a public square, a library, a doctor’s office, a shop, a school, a design studio, an office, a cinema, a bank, and so much more.Of course, with every new feature, every new website, the ide between those who are online and those who are not increases, making it all the more imperative to make the web available for everyone.And while the web has created opportunity, given marginalised groups a voice and made our daily lives easier, it has also created opportunity for scammers, given a voice to those who spread hatred and made all kinds of crime easier to commit.Against the backdrop of news stories about how the web is misused, it is  understandable that many people feel afraid and unsurethe web is really a force for good. But given how much the web has changed in the past  years, it would be defeatist and unimaginative to assume that the web as we know it can’t be changed for the better in the next .If we give up on building a better web now, then the web will not have failed us. We will have failed the web.To tackle any problem, we must clearly outline and understand it. I broadly see three sources of dys affecting today’s web:The second category requires us to redesign systems in a way that changes incentives.And the final category calls for research to understand existing systems and model possible new ones or tweak those we already have.You can’t just blame one government, one social network or the human spirit. Simplistic narratives risk exhausting our energy as we chase the symptoms of these problems instead of focusing on their root causes. To get this right we will need to come together as a global web community.At pivotal moments, generations before us have stepped up to work together for a better future. With the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, erse groups of people have been able to agree on essential principles.With the Law of the Sea and the Outer Space Treaty, we have preserved new frontiers for the common good.Now too, as the web reshapes our world, we have a responsibility to make sure it is recognised as a human right and built for the public good. This is why the Web Foundation is working with governments, companies and citizens to build a new Contract for the Web.This contract was launched in Lisbon, Portugal, at Web Summit, bringing together a group of people who agree we need to establish clear norms, laws and standards that underpin the web.Those who support it endorse its starting principles and together are working out the specic commit-ments in each area.No one group should do this alone, and all input will be appreciated. Governments, companies and citizens are all contributing, and we aim to have a result later this year.Governments must translate laws and regulations for the digital age. They must ensure markets remain competitive, innovative and open. And they have a responsibility to protect people’s rights and freedoms online.We need open web champions within government — civil servants and elected officials who will take action when private sector interests threaten the public good and who will stand up to protect the open web.Companies must do more to ensure their pursuit of short-term profit is not at the expense of human rights, democracy, scientic fact or public safety.Platforms and products must be designed with privacy, ersity and security in mind. This year we’ve seen a number of tech employees stand up and demand better business practices. We need to encourage that spirit.And most important of all, citizens must hold companies and governments accountable for the commitments they make, and demand that both respect the web as a global community with citizens at its heart.If we don’t elect politicians who defend a free and open web,we don’t do our part to foster constructive, healthy conversations online,we continue to click consent without demanding our data rights be respected, we walk away from our responsibility to put these issues on the priority agenda of our governments.The fight for the web is one of the most important causes of our time. Today, half of the world is online. It is more urgent than ever to ensure the other half are not left behind offline, and that everyone contributes to a web that drives equality, opportunity and creativity.The Contract for the Web must not be a list of quick fixes but a process that signals a sht in how we understand our relationship with our online community.It must be clear enough to act as a guiding star for the way forward but flexible enough to adapt to the rapid pace of change in technology.It’s our journey from digital adolescence to a more mature, responsible and inclusive future.The web is for everyone and collectively we hold the power to change it. It won’t be easy. Butwe dream a little and work a lot, we can get the web we want. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kate middleton joins beckhams kate moss national portrait gallery gala
story: Kate, , was one of a number of distinguished guests to step out of Storm Gareths path at the celeb-packed fundraiser.As Brexit disappointments were felt one mile away in Westminster, guests of the lavish gala were able to forget politics for a second as fans lined up to snap their glamorous outfits.Kate has been a patron of the gallery since  and features among the portraits in Paul Emsleys infamous rendering of her.The Duchess, who studied art at St Andrews, was due to meet members of the gallerys Youth Forum and view artwork produced by some of the gallerys outreach programmes at the black tie event.David and Victoria Beckham looked effortlessly suave in matching black and white outfits, while a host of musicians, models and entrepreneurs also donned their glad rags for the occasion.The evening was being hosted by Dr Nicholas Cullinan and Edward Enninful to raise funds for the National Portrait Gallerys Inspiring People project.Supermodels Kate Moss and Jourdan Dunnwere also dazzled, while the royal count was upped by Princess Beatrice with her property developer boyfriend Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi - seen together in public for the first time today.British Vogue editor Edward Enninful was also in attendance, along with other big hitters from the world of fashion.This was Kates second engagement for the day after visiting the Henry Fawcett Childrens Centre in Kennington earlier on.

title: barbers free condoms wheeze major flaw
story: Hairdresser Jake Gamez, , rendered the rubber contraceptives useless by punching holes in them with a stapler.The Texas businessman handed out the condoms because he claimed that his haircuts would make his male customers irresistible.Tweeting out pictures of the free sex aid, he wrote: “Gotta include one of these with every card! title: facebook google broken allow alternatives tech giants getting power
story: In his Spring Statement, Chancellor Philip Hammond will pledge fresh regulation to stop tech giants “accumulating too much power”.He will commit to examine measures that would make it easier for users to move their data and pictures from the likes of Facebook, Instagram, Youtube and Twitter to smaller s.It comes after a government-ordered review published last night found competition rules of the digital market are inadequate and called for ministers to create a new competition watchdog to rule on mergers.The review - led by former Barack Obama adviser Jason Furman - ruled that the lack of regulation had allowed firms like Facebook to acquire the WhatsApp messaging  without any competition or scrutiny and had created an “unlevel playing field”.Treasury sources said Mr Hammond is keen to implement radical changes because it will force the likes of Facebook and Instagram to act swter on issues such as self-harm pictures because greater competition would allow their users to switch providers.The review also calls for the creation of a code of conduct and the strengthening of regulatory powers to tackle anti-competitive behaviour.Hard professor Jason Furman, who led the review, said: “The digital sector has created substantial benefits but these have come at the cost of increasing dominance of a few companies which is limiting competition and consumer choice and innovation.“Some say this is inevitable or even desirable.“I think the UK can do better.“The Chancellor, Philip Hammond, was right to recognise there is a better way than just continuing with the status quo.“My  is outlining a balanced proposal to give people more control over their data, give small businesses more of a chance to enter and thrive, and create more predictability for the large digital companies.“These recommendations will deliver an economic boost driven by UK tech start-ups and innovation that will give consumers greater choice and protection.”The review also recommends changes to merger rules so that the Competition and Markets Authorityis better equipped to stop mergers that are considered likely to damage future competition or consumer choice.In addition, it calls for the introduction of powers that would force large companies to open up to smaller firms by providing access to certain data, where doing so would not affect user privacy.It saidthe proposals were adopted it could help boost the economy by encouraging the development of new s alongside established names.In response, Mr Hammond said: “The UK leads the world in embracing technology and the opportunities it delivers for people.“Competition is fundamental to ensuring the market works in the interest of consumers, but we know some tech giants are still accumulating too much power, preventing smaller businesses from entering the market.“The work of Jason Furman and the expert  is invaluable in ensuring we’re at the forefront of delivering a competitive digital marketplace.“I will carefully examine the proposals put forward by the  before responding later this year, setting out how the Government will implement the changes needed to ensure our digital markets are competitive and consumers get the level of choice they deserve.”Damian Collins MP, chairman of the House of Commons Digital, Culture, Media and Sportselect committee also backed calls for tighter regulation.“I welcome the publication of Professor Furman and his expert ’s report on unlocking digital competition.“Its central conclusions that digital markets only work wellthey are supported with strong pro-competition policies, corroborates a number of the findings of my committee’s report into disinformation and ‘fake news’ published in February,” he said.“It is clear that a strong code of ethics is needed to regulate online s, and I agree with the report’s conclusion that the proposed code of competitive conduct is complementary with the code of ethics suggested by my committee.“We welcome the measures put forward to tackle anti-competitive practices and bullying tactics by market leaders.“This comes at a critical moment ahead of the beginnings of regulation from Government to rein in the powers of the tech companies.“I agree with the report that common data standards, including around the treatment of inferred data, should be set.“My committee was concerned by the treatment of inferred data by large tech companies such as Facebook, and it is essential that the Government acts to protect consumers.“The report is right to highlight that United Kingdom has the opportunity to lead by example in the area of digital regulation.“With a history of fair and robust regulation, and with the largest tech sector in Europe, the UK is uniquely placed to set world-leading standards in the digital arena.“Through the formation of the International Grand Committee it has already been demonstrated that other nations are ready to work with us to tackle the plethora of challenges presented by social media s.”Later this month, a government white paper on online harms is expected to be published, which is likely to include some proposals for new regulation on social media s and internet companies.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kenya super tusker elephant queen photos land of giants
story: She is known as a super tusker due to her enormous kg tusks being so big that they graze the ground - and following her death there are now fewer than  of them left in the world.The awe-inspiring photos of the giant animal - known as F_Mu - were taken by British wildle photographer Will Burrard-Lucas who became transfixed by both her size and timid, almost regal nature.Will, , said: If ever there were a Queen of Elephants, it surely would have been her.He managed to take the series of black-and-white snaps during an -month project working in partnership with the Tsavo Trust and Kenya Wildle Service.Captured just before she died of natural causes, the portraits not only show off her colossal size but also her dignied and noble temperament.Recalling his le-changing experience meeting the Elephant Queen, Will said he was left speechless.He wrote in his blog: F_MU was skinny and old but she strode forward with stately grace.Her tusks were so long that they scraped the ground in front of her. She was like a relic from a bygone era.She had survived through periods of terrible poaching and it was a victory that her le was not ended prematurely by a snare, bullet or poisoned arrow.Tragically, ruthless poachers prize elephants like F_MU precisely because of their impressive tusks.Ivory can fetch up to £, per pound on the black market due to demand in Asia - where it is used in an array of ancient medicines.The rarity of the super-tuskers made Wills task tracking her down all the more dficult - an effort he described as like looking for a needle in a haystack.He and wildle experts from the Tsavo Trust used a spotter plane to comb the area from the skies and relayed information to Will via radio as he crossed the dusty terrain in a car.But he remembers being awestruck when he first laid eyes on his subject.He wrote: If I hadnt looked upon her with my own eyes, I might not have believed that such an elephant could exist in our world.Will needed to use one of his BeetleCams - a remote-controlled buggy with a camera mounted on it - to capture the dramatic close-up shots.He added: She always proved to be the most exceptional subject.Her temperament was gentle and calm. Sometimes she would come so close to me that I could have touched her.The snaps - taken in August  and now being published for the first time in a new book - are the last documenting the stunning animal, who died shortly after amid a crippling drought in the area.Tsavo is home to the largest elephant population in Kenya and covers about , square miles.This makes it dficult to patrol - forcing conservationists to not make F_MU more widely known in case she attracted poachers.The photos feature in a larger book of incredible photographs taken by Will called Land Of Giants - documenting the wildle in Tsava and the work of the Tsavo Trust.It contains  previously unseen black-and-white photographs taken over three expeditions of two female big tuskers - one being F_Mu - and four males, including LU, the largest of all.Will added: Photographing F_Mu was a feeling of privilege and euphoria that will stay with me forever.

title: russia secret nuclear submarine revealed 2020
story: The so-called Poseidon strategic missiles, carrying up to  megaton warheads, will be deployed by  and could wipe out the likes of Los Angeles, according to reports.Putins military plans to deploy the weapons on the new Project  sub Belgorod - a converted nuclear-powered submarine.Russias state-owned news agency Tass, citing a Moscow defence source, claims the underwater warships could carry six of the Poseidon torpedoes.In January, Fox News reported that a former senior adviser to President Trump admitting there are “genuine concerns” about the plan.Former State Department senior adviser Christian Whiton said a blast would create a “wave - and a highly irradiated one” but because the water would absorb a lot of the energy the wave would be less damaging than getting hit by the bomb itself.A prototype doomsday craft took to the waves for the first time on Christmas Day to begin under-sea trials, Tass news agency reported.A defence source is quoted as saying: In the sea area protected from a potential enemy’s reconnaissance means, the underwater trials of the nuclear propulsion unit of the Poseidon drone are under way.The drone is said to be powered by a miniaturised nuclear reactor, which has been fitted to the rear for ocean tests.Before Christmas it was expected that development of the weapon was at an early stage and the craft was being carried by one of the Russian navys nuclear submarines as part of experimental design work rather than full-fledged sea trials at this stage, the source told Tass.Vladimir Putin revealed the existence of the state-of-the-art new weapon earlier in , and claimed it would be able to whizz through the ocean almost silently at up to  knots.Putin said: It is really fantastic. They are quiet, highly manoeuvrable and have hardly any vulnerabilities for the enemy to exploit.There is simply nothing in the world capable of withstanding them.Poseidon - originally called the Status- Oceanic Multipurpose System - got its name after a Boaty McBoatface-style public poll by Russias defence ministry.The drones will be armed with conventional weapons and a two megaton nuclear warhead with the primary purpose of destroying naval bases, according to reports in Russia.However analysts at the Pentagon - which uses the name Kanyon for the drones - are said to believe they will carry tens of megatons of explosive power.Experts have said that kind of blast under water could be enough to trigger a tsunami as powerful as the one that killed , people in Japan and knocked out the Fukushima power plant in .Rex Richardson, a physicist, told Business Insider: “A well-placed nuclear weapon of yield in the range MT to MT near a sea coast could certainly couple enough energy to equal the  tsunami, perhaps much more.”Some reports claim the resulting wave could reach ft, swamping entire cities.And there are fears it could blow ocean sediment into the air, generating a deadly radioactive dust cloud.Russias navy had previously said they hoped Poseidon would be in service by .The claimed miniature nuke reactor - said to be  times smaller that previously achieved - is the same one that allegedly powers the Burevestnik M cruise missile.That was also unveiled earlier in , part of an arsenal of advanced weapons Russia claims is capable of thwarting the most modern defences to help it win World War Three.

title: molly russell family receive legal aid
story: The Government Agency had stunned her dad after declaring the hearing on the teenager’s suicide was not “a matter of wider public interest”.But  it reversed the decision after an appeal and said the family WOULD get aid to cover their costs for Molly’s inquest.Dad Ian Russell said: “I am delighted that the Legal Aid Agency has reconsidered their decision and I would like to thank everyone for the many offers of support we have received.“This decision is a weight lted from our family and we now look ahead to a full and fearless inquest into Molly’s death.”Molly took her own le in  in the week before her th birthday after she watched suicide material online on social media.Her family think it was key to what happened to her and want it fully investigated.It is unusual for the LAA to fund aid for legal representation and only does so in very few cases.Its original letter to the family said: “We do not see how and why the investigation in this matter will inevitably lead to signicant and material benefits to a large cohort of specic persons”.The Russell family’s lawyer Merry Varney said: “We welcome the decision by the LAA to reconsider legal aid for the Russell family.“However, it is disappointing that our clients had to go through the appeal process to get to a positive outcome and many other families are not successful in their appeals and cannot afford to bring a judicial review against the LAA.“This leaves them either reliant on lawyers working for free, fundraising or having to represent themselves at their loved one’s inquest, completely unqualied and unprepared against experienced legal teams on the other side.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: signs dementia held back eat 150g portions mushrooms week
story: Scientists found people who ate more than two g portions a week were half as likely to suffer mild cognitive impairment .The condition is a transition phase between normal ageing and dementia and hits memory, attention and spatial awareness.Researchers from the National University of Singapore believe a compound in mushrooms called ergothioneine could help protect the brain from ageing.A previous study found levels were lower among patients with MCI. Dr Lei Feng, who led the Singapore team, said: “This correlation is surprising and encouraging.“It seems that a commonly available single ingredient could have a dramatic effect on cognitive decline.“Based on current evidence, we propose that mushroom consumption could be a potential preventative measure to slow cognitive decline and neurodegeneration in ageing.”The study’s findings are published in the Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease.Up to .million Brits are thought to be living with MCI and , with dementia.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: paedo fantasised snatching child asda
story: John McDonald reported his own violent thoughts towards young children, and this week admitted flouting a sexual harm prevention order.The -year-old said he imagined taking a child from the South Bank supermarket in Middlesborough.He was previously jailed in  after admitting sexually assaulting a child under , inciting a child to engage in sexual activity and possessing more than  indecent and prohibited images of children and extreme pornographic images.After his release he was recalled after confessing his sick fantasies.Gazette Live reports Prosecutor Harry Hadfield said: He disclosed that he fantasised about snatching a five-year-old child from the street, taking them to a derelict house and raping them.He was kept in custody until his sentence expired in June last year but an officer found child abuse images on his laptop just a few months later.They also found searches suggesting an attraction to children among , pages in his history.The court heard McDonald said: I cant help myself. I cant stop. I need help.He askedthey could delete it all and forget about it, make it go away.The pervert had also deleted his cookies, breaching a sexual harm prevention order which banned him from doing so.This week he admitted breaching the indefinite sexual harm prevention order.Mr Constantine, defending, said: He doesnt want to spend the rest of his le in custody. He wants to get some help in removing those desires.He clearly has some awareness of the risk that he poses.He said McDonald had a learning disability and had been deemed unsuitable for a sex offender treatment programme.Judge Simon Bourne-Arton QC, the Recorder of Middlesbrough, said: Clearly this is a very serious breach. title: venezuela maduro urges gangs blackout
story: During a rambling address to the nation he called yesterday for the gangs to begin “the resistance” as he blamed a “demonic” plot by the United States for the power failure.As he blamed Washing for an “electromagnetic attack” on the nation’s power grid, he summoned neighbourhood “colectivos” to the streets.The Times reported that the same groups have been accused of murdering protesters, including during the recent attempt to bring humanitarian aid over the country’s borders.In a speech splashed across all TV and radio stations in the country, Maduro, , claimed the attack began with all computer screens in the control room of the Guri dam abruptly going black.The dam supplies most of the country with hydroelectric power, and China  today offered to help with the power grid repairs.While hospital patients and new-born babies die without power to essential medical equipment and residents loot supermarkets to find food, the rich of the country are still able to enjoy some of the luxuries.Thereported that in the dining room of the El Alazan in the affluent Altamira neighbourhood the lights are still on, and expensive cuts of meat and bottles of whisky were still covering the tables.A meal at El Alazan costs several times the minimum monthly wage of £, and while the diners enjoy themselves, an unofficial curfew grips the rest of the dark city.Elsewhere in Caracas, electricity has been restored to large swatches of the city, but there is still not enough to pump water to resident’s homes.The US has denied any involvement in the power outages, but have ordered all their embassy staff to leave the country by the end of the week as a precaution.The US has led an international effort to oust socialist Maduro and replace him with opposition leader Juan Guaido, who vows to hold a new presidential election.Guaido, who heads the opposition-controlled congress, said Maduros claims the US sabotaged the power grid with a cyberattack are an attempt to ert attention from the governments own failings.Winston Cabas, the head of Venezuelas electrical engineers union, which opposes the government, disputed government allegations that the countrys main hydroelectric dam was sabotaged last week.He blamed a lack of maintenance as well as the departure of skilled workers from the troubled country over the years.The system is vulnerable, fragile and unstable, he said.In their desperation, ordinary Venezuelans have been forced to queue to charge electronic devices from any renewable source available and pay for bread with  bills.Mobile phone reception has been patchy and homes have suffered from a lack of water as pumping stations shut down.The government on Sunday suspended school and business activities for the following day without providing any information on a likely time frame for resolving the situation, leaving many fretting that it could extend indefinitely.The blackouts also have hit the oil industry.Russ Dallen, a Miami-based partner at the brokerage firm Caracas Capital Markets, said the whole system is grinding to a halt.Two large tankers are sitting empty at the Jose offshore oil-loading dock, and at least  other ships are waiting their turns there, Dallen said.Guaido is backed by some  countries, while Maduro maintains support from countries such as China, Russia and Cuba.

title: woman tries sell leftover chinese food facebook
story: The fast-food bundle had four mystery dishes, two sauces and what looks like a bag of prawn crackers.The half-eaten food was posted about midnight on Saturday to the Plymouth Crazy Sell and Buy page at the bargain price of £.She wrote in the post she “paid well over  pounds” and it “only been sat here for a few hours”.The woman, from Devonport, claimed she needed it “gone ASAP”.It is unclearthis was posted as a prank orthis woman was genuinely trying to sell her leftover takeaway.She claimed the contents of her takeaway as four chicken balls with sauce that had been “undipped”, rice, prawn crackers, “untouched” chicken curry, “half a bag of cold chips”, chicken satay, chow mein and crispy chilly beef.The post had more than  comments in the closed Facebook group, but it was shared to a public page that amassed more than  shares and  comments.Some commented askingthe takeaway deal was still for sale yesterday and others wondered how much of the food was eaten.One said: “I thinkI’m honest I’m interested, is there any gloopy sweet and sour sauce ”Another added: “Bet all the chicken has been picked out. Itll all be sauce and veggies.”The woman appeared to offer to deliver the food.She wrote: “Serious buyers only. Can deliver for small free need to walk my dog anyway. Let me know.

title: brexit blue passports delay home office
story: The Home Office confirmed that the new blue passport design would be phased in “from late ”.But for months, Brits may be issued with either a blue or burgundy one – and will have no say on which design they get.“You will not be able to choose whether you get a burgundy or a blue passport during this time,” the Passport Office said.It insisted that all British passports should be blue from “early ”.But the decision is likely to cause uproar among Brexit and Remain-backing Brits. The iconic blue passport is inextricably linked with leaving the EU after Brexit-backers launched a campaign for its .Announcing the decision to bring them back two years ago, ex-Immigration Minister Brandon Lewis insisted every Brit would be able to request one from October .At the time he said: “I recognise that for many people who voted in that referendum, they want to see that things are dferent.”The Passport Office on Tuesday confirmed that British passports issued from March  would no longer include the words ‘European Union’ on the front cover. Both blue and burgundy designs would be equally valued for travel, it said.The Sun’s ‘True Blue’ campaign for theof the iconic blue book was launched after Brexit referendum result. It was ditched in  after a long-running battle with Brussels.The blue design was originally introduced in , and was described as “perfection itself” by the League of Nations, forerunner of the United Nations.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no deal brexit vote house of commons theresa may
story: The PM will enrage Brexiteers by backing a delay to our EU exit - rather than quitting without a deal on March .Even Mrs Mays allies admitted the move will massively split the party - complaining: Were totally f***ed.And Boris Johnson blasted the Prime Ministers absurd policy of offering Tory MPs a free vote in todays Commons showdown.After last nights crushing defeat for the Brexit deal, Parliament will today vote on whether or not to approve a No Deal exit in  days time.Mrs May announced she would leave it up to inidual MPs to decide how they should vote.And she today confirmed she will oppose No Deal along with other Cabinet ministers such as Amber Rudd.During the  election campaign, Mrs May repeatedly insisted: No Deal is better than a bad deal.But she has also pointed out that evenMPs vote against No Deal tonight, it remains the legal default and could still happen in May or June.And she insists her deal is a good one which is better than a World Trade Organisation exit.If No Deal is defeated, the Commons will get a further vote tomorrow on whether to delay Brexit by around two months.One of the PMs closest allies told The Sun tonights vote will be hugely damaging for the Tory party by pitting Remainers and Brexiteers against each other.The insider said: The party is going to be fundamentally ided over this, whichever way the PM goes. Were totally f***ed.Boris hit out at Mrs Mays decision to offer a free vote - telling LBC: I do think that is absurd, this is a fundamental matter of Government policy.But David Cameron backed the PM, saying: Obviously, what needs to happen next is to rule out No Deal - that would be a disaster for our country - and to seek an extension, and Im sure that is what is going to happen next.Even the Cabinet is likely to be split on the No Deal vote - with Brexiteers such as Andrea Leadsom voting in favour, while the likes of David Gauke oppose it.Speaking at Prime Ministers Questions today, Mrs May hit out at Jeremy Corbyn for opposing her deal without saying what he wants to happen instead.She pointed out that the Labour boss has this week held back from supporting a second Brexit referendum - even though that is his partys official policy.The PM, who is battling a bad sore throat, blasted: I may not have my own voice, but I do understand the voice of the country.He doesnt agree with Government policy, he doesnt even agree with Labour party policy - he has nothing to offer this country.No has not yet decided whether to back any of the amendments tabled to tonights motion.The two key amendments are one from Tory ex-minister Caroline Spelman which aims to remove No Deal as a default, and another tabled by a mixed group of Remainers and Brexiteers pushing the so-called Malthouse compromise.Mrs May would face a huge rebellionshe ordered Conservative MPs to vote against the Malthouse motion, which calls for a managed No Deal scenario with a long transition period.Senior MPs including Jacob Rees-Mogg and Damian Green believe the plan could avoid a chaotic Brexit clf edge while preventing Britain from being tied too closely to the EU.But Brussels is unlikely to sign up to the compromise evenits approved by the Commons.The PM is under increasing pressure from her own MPs to resign or even trigger a snap General Election.Nicky Morgan warned the Cabinet may have to confront Mrs May later this week and demand that she resign.Aides admit the PM is closer than ever to throwing in the towel - but remains adamant she will press on with her current deal.Its still not clear whether the EU will actually grant Britain an extension to the Brexit process eventhe Commons votes to request one tomorrow.

title: brexit no deal vote commons eu
story: The debate is due to kick off in the early afternoon but Theresa May has to face a potentially stormy PMQs beforehand.The Commons will vote on the motion: This House declines to approve leaving the European Union without a withdrawal agreement and a framework on the future relationship on  March.Theresa May has taken the unusual step of giving MPs a free vote on the issue, meaning they can vote with their conscience rather than having to follow the orders of the party Whips.It is expected MPs will vote in the early evening, around pm but this could easily be delayed.The day’s events kick off at noon with PMQ which will then be followed by Chancellor Philip Hammond delivering the Spring Statement.The Brexit motion is to be put before the House at .pm,things run smoothly and in theory a vote could take place any time after that.The issue though will almost certainly be debated and Speaker John Bercow could select amendments for MPs to also vote on.This depends on the outcome of the vote.If MPs back a no deal scenario then the UK will leave the EU as planned on March  and revert to trading under World Trade Organisation rules.Howeverthey vote against a no deal Brexit and back extending Article  on Thursday, May will be forced to formally ask EU leaders for the whole process to be extended.But even that is not clear cut as all EU members must vote unanimously to agree to her request.EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker though has stood firm, saying there would be no further negotiations on May’s Brexit deal, saying there would be no “third chance”.He added: In politics, sometimes you get a second chance. story: NewsBrexit: What happens next after Theresa Mays deal suffers crushing defeatThere are now just days for Mrs May or Parliament to take control of the Brexit negotiationsShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video theresa-responds-wake-parliament-rejecting-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMPs have delivered a brutal verdict on Theresa Mays deal - heaping yet another defeat on the Prime Ministers plan. There are now just days for Mrs May or Parliament to take control of the Brexit negotiation. In the coming days MPs will face a number of crunch votes. They will debate delaying Brexit andwe should rule out leaving with No Deal. The now very fluid situation could also see MPs rule out leaving the EU at all or agree to hold a second referendum. This is the guide for what could happen in the next few days as British politics enters its most unpredictable period in living memory.  MPs today will debate scrapping the chance of a no-deal Brexit. Under plans outlined by the Prime Minister on February , the Commons will have the option to vote on removing the possibility of the UK quitting the EU without an agreement. Theresa May controversially confirmed it will be a free vote to avoid a slew of Tory resignations. Businesses, experts and campaigners have repeatedly warned of a chaotic, economic doomsdayBritain was to plunge from the bloc minus a orce deal and transition period. Lorries could be stacked on roads leading to Channel ports, supermarket shelves may be emptied and vital medicine supplies might be disrupted, according to worst-case scenarios. But Theresa May has so far kept the option on the table, believing it is a key negotiating tactic. However, despite her desperation to preserve the possibility, there is no majority in Parliament for a no-deal departure.   If it comes to a vote tonight MPs are likely to deliver a resounding “No” to no-deal. Only a hardcore rump of Tories and some DUP MPs believe a no-deal - where the UK reverts to World Trade Organisation rules, raising the prospect of tarfs on a host of products - could be good for the country. Will Brexit be delayed  A vote on delaying Brexit is due to take place Thursday - and could finally dash the hopes of Leave supporters who were promised the UK would cease to be a member of the EU at pm on March . MPs are set to be given the chance to delay Article  - the formal mechanism for leaving the bloc - under plans unveiled in the Commons. The PM has always been adamant the UK will leave on March  - two years after formally triggering Article  - so any delay would be a severe humiliation. It would also fuel suspicions the UK will never leave - overturning the “will of the people”.   A short delay could happen regardless because evenMrs May manages to force through a deal at a third attempt, there maybe too little time left to pass the Withdrawal Agreement Bill through the Commons and Lords before scheduled departure day. The Government must table an amendable motion within seven sitting days of last night’s defeat - so by next Thursday. Experts say this means the PM will have lost control of the process, with Parliament in pole position to decide what happens next. However, the law of the land states the UK leaves the EU on March . That can only be stopped by changing the law - and time is running out. If the UK wants a delay, it has to ask for one from Brussels. The PM is due at a crunch summit in the city next Thursday where leaders could thrash out plans for a delay - or offer her another revision. The EU is likely to grant an extension of no more than two months - any longer, and the UK would be required to take part in EU Parliament elections. Will there be a general election  Mrs May is said to favour a general election over a second referendum, but neither option appeals to the premier. She is scarred by her disastrous  campaign where she was unable to resist a -point poll lead over Labour and triggered an unnecessary snap election, surrendering the Conservatives’ majority just two years after it was won by David Cameron. The PM’s “strong and stable” slogan backfired as Labour surged in the election day run-in, with Jeremy Corbyn resurrecting his leadership and performing much better than expected.   However, some polls in recent weeks have given the Tories a -point lead and Mrs May might fancy her chances of ballot box redemption. But the uncomfortable truth for the PM - and all MPs - is a new election could leave the parliamentary arithmetic largely unchanged: the Tories could still be the biggest party but wield no overall majority, and many Conservative MPs could still oppose Mrs May’s Withdrawal Agreement, The PM could find herself back at square one. Will there be a second referendum  Campaigners for another EU vote are biding their time before tabling an amendment demanding a re-run of the hugely isive  referendum. They want to exploit their “moment of maximum opportunity”, which may now be very near. Supporters of another vote claim voters should have the chance to back the PM’s deal or opt to Remain after all. But critics say the public has already decided to Leave, with ,, people backing Brexit and ,, wanting to stay in the EU - a majority of ,, to quit. Mrs May is dead against another EU referendum - and being forced to accept one may prove fatal to her premiership. Mr Corbyn has pledged to throw Labour’s weight behind a “People’s Vote”. But suspicions linger that he favours withdrawal - and the party leader continues to face anger over his apparent lack of enthusiasm for the EU during the  referendum campaign. Can May survive  Under normal circumstances, a PM who suffered a -vote defeat - the biggest ever in parliamentary history - on such an important motion as January’s meaningful vote would be expected to resign. But these are very far from normal times and Mrs May shrugged off the reverse and vowed to try again. Members of her own party tried and failed to oust her in December by tabling a vote of no confidence. She survived the vote by  votes to  - meaning more than third of her MPs wanted to topple her.   The victory - however hollow - meant Mrs May cannot face a fresh attempt to remove her as leader for another  months. In January, her Government survived a no-confidence vote by  votes to  after rebel Tory MPs and the DUP backed the Government just  hours after they combined to crush her original Brexit plan. Labour can table as many no-confidence votes as it likes, but Tories and the DUP are likely to continue to support Mrs Mays administration because they fear handing power to Mr Corbyn - and losing a confidence to vote would trigger a general election.

story: NewsWhat is a No Deal Brexit   ways youll be affectedUK leaves EU with no dealThe UK is due to leave the EU on  March  - and No Deal Brexit is becoming a bigger threat. Weve looked at  ways it would affect your everyday leShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video here-how-no-deal-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK is due to leave the European Union on  March  - andtheres no agreement, itll be a No Deal Brexit. A Brexit deal was agreed between the UK and the EU in November , but it was voted down twice in the House of Commons - first in January by  votes, then on March th by  votes. MPs are voting on Wednesday  March on whether to avoid a No Deal Brexit - and theyre widely expected to block it. But even so, no deal remains the default option and plans have long since been put into action, costing more than poundbillion, in case it happens. The government published  technical notices outlining the practical effects of No Deal - from driving licences to cats. And it unveiled new tarfs that would slap pound, on the cost of a family car from the EU - but leave % of goods imports, including steel, tarf free. This could threaten struggling UK industries with a flood of cheap imports.   Meanwhile ministers have , troops held at readiness, could call up Army reserves and declare martial law. Supermarkets and pharma giants are stockpiling food and medicine. If theres no arrangement in time, well lose  international trade deals in a blink, shed access to EU criminal databases and troops couldto the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic. A lot of the effects are on business. UK farmers face a nine-month wait for approval to export organic goods to the EU. Fishermen could be blocked from EU waters. And manufacturers fear their supply chains drying up. But businesses are not what whove written this guide for. Instead we have tried to establish  ways No Deal Brexit will affect you, the reader and your everyday le.   What is a No Deal Brexit  No Deal is the default optionMPs, the EU and the UK government cant agree a Brexit Withdrawal Agreement by  March . The -page deal on the table would have ensured businesses arent cut off by continuing rules in a transition period until December . But it came at a cost - a backstop that could trap the UK in an EU customs union from . That means MPs have opposed it. Leaving with no deal will mean falling back on World Trade Organisation trade tarfs - increasing the price of imports and exports - and could leave legal black holes where EU law stood before. The UK government has been ramping up preparations for no deal since the beginning of summer . MPs believe they will block No Deal through Parliament - in a vote on Wednesday  March - butthey dont its still the default option at pm on March .   ways No Deal Brexit will hit you NOTE,  March : These scenarios are accurate as of early , when this piece was last updated. Some have since been partially resolved - for example, there is an agreement to ensure flights will continue. . Martial law could be imposed with thousands of troops on standby  More than , troops are being held at readiness in case there is a disastrous no-deal Brexit. Army reserves are also legally able to be called upthere is civil unrest, while councils are braced for possible runs on banks, fuel and food. Local Resilience Forums are reporting back to Whitehall and expect several months of disruptionthere is no deal. The government has plans in case it needs to impose martial law - military law - and curfews to restore order. Cabinet minister Matt Hancock admitted the plans existed but insisted the government was not specically looking at martial law and it was not the focus of our attention.  At the moment, British citizens can enter Schengen area countries with a valid passport eventhey only have a day left before they expire. But in a no deal Brexit, after  March  you may not be able to travel to these countriesyou have less than six months left on your passport. The government is advising travellers to renew any passports older than nine years and six months. . Usually this means renewing six months before your passport expires. Butyour passport had more than  years validity, youll have to renew earlier, because the extra months on top of  years dont count. The following are members of the Schengen Agreement: Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland.  There is a huge surge in red tape for pet owners who want to take their beloved animals abroad. Currently dogs , cats and ferrets can travel anywhere in the EU as long as they have a pet passport. The main requirement is that three weeks before the first visit, owners must go to the vet to have their pet vaccinated against rabies and microchipped. But in the worst case no-deal Brexit, pet owners must visit a vet at least four months before taking their pet the EU. And because talks are ongoing, that means youd better book in now. ,],totalVotes:,votesToShow:,mentometerId:,publicationId:,callbackUrl:https:www.mirror poll-ws poll  status,voteActionUrl:https:www.mirror poll-ws poll  vote,closed:,closedMessage:This poll has been closed!,hideResults:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true" The animal must have a rabies vaccination followed by a blood test at least  days later, to prove the vaccination worked. Pet owners must then wait at least three months before visiting the vet to obtain a health certicate. But this cannot be done more than  days before the date the holiday starts.  Food is being stockpiled forwe crash out of the EU without a deal, and ministers have promised an adequate supply. But thats not the same as having the range of food we do now. Leaked plans in December warned Brits could have to y their diet. And in January, big names KFC, Pret, Lidl, Co-Op, MS, Waitrose, Sainsburys, Asda and McDonalds signed a damning letter warning food supplies could run short because of disruptions to the supply chain. They wrote in a joint letter to MPs: Our ability to mitigate these risks is limited. As prudent businesses we are stockpiling where possible, but all frozen and chilled storage is already being used and there is very little general warehousing space available in the UK. They added: Retailers typically store no more than two weeks inventory and it becomes dficult to restock storesthe supply chain is disrupted.  A string of firms have either moved jobs out of the UK or are threatening to do so in a no-deal situation. Airbus, which employs , people in the UK with around , more jobs in supply chains, warned it may move where. Car plants are moving forward standard shutdowns to be around Brexit in case there are supply chain issues. And critics fear new investment will not come the UKs way, hitting jobs in generations to come.  Major motorways in the South of England are set for serious disruption in case of a no-deal Brexit. From early  the Mwill be closed as needed from junctions -, with a contraflow of both directions on the opposite side, so it can be used as a lorry parkthere is gridlock at Dover. A backup lorry park will be in place at Manston Airport. The M in Kent is also expected to be used as a holding area for lorries. And a similar fate could befall a -mile stretch of the M towards Southampton.  The International Air Transport Associationwarn up to million plane tickets could be cancelledthere is no deal. Currently it is not known exactly which tickets could be hit, or how passengers would find outthey are at risk. The situation arose because in a no deal, there will be no automatic legal basis for flights between the EU and UK after pm on  March . Under a pact struck between the UK and EU in December, basic connectivity will be maintained for a -month periodtheres No Deal. But according to the IATA - which represents  airlines including British Airways - that only means maintaining the number of flights in . It does not allow an increase in services - yet tickets have already been sold based on a predicted increase. Talks are ongoing, but Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office, previously warned flights could be groundedgoodwill fails.  Currently a UK driving licence is the only thing visitors need to get behind the wheel on the continent. But under a no-deal Brexit, you should get an International Driving Permit. The pound. documents were due to be sold at , post offices from February. Before they were sold at fewer than . The number of permits issued would have to soar from , a year to million. Meanwhile you will also be forced to apply for a green card to prove you have the right car insurance. The certicates are free of charge and available from insurance companies. But the government warns firms may increase administration fees in order to cope with the extra bureaucracy. Those who forget their green cards would be forced to buy expensive frontier insurance in the country they are visiting. . Up to a million Brits may be forced to take a new driving test  British people driving in Europe could be forced to take a new driving testtheres a no deal Brexit. Up to a million Brits living in Europe were told to replace their driving licence with a local permit immediately. Guidance issued by the Department for Transport said: If you are aUKlicence holder living in theEUorEEAyou should exchange your UK driving licence for a local EU driving licence before  March . From that date, in the event that there is noEUExit deal, you may have to pass a driving test in theEU country you live in to be able to carry on driving there.  More than million EU citizens living in the UK will have less concrete rights to stay. Whether theres a Brexit deal or not, EU citizens can stay in Britainthey register for settled status with the government. But the rules are stricter in a No Deal Brexit. In No Deal, only EU citizens arriving before  March can apply, not those arriving by December . The deadline to apply will be  December , instead of  June there is a Brexit deal. And family members will only be able to join settled EU citizens in the UK before  March . As for the other way round - major EU nations have inidually said theyll allow UK ex-pats to stay, but this could y by country.  Pharmacists have requested special powers to ration medicinesthere is no Brexit deal. Under plans by the Healthcare Distribution Association, they would have special powers to y doctors prescriptions and offer something a drug is unavailable.  million packs of medicines are imported to the UK from the EU every month, and the NHS is preparing for a doomsday scenario to prevent supplies running dry. Government and NHS chiefs have set up a war room called the Operational Response Centre and industry firms are creating six-week stockpiles of medicine. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has chartered a plane to fly in short-shelf-le products, like isotopes for cancer treatment, from Maastricht. Insulin could also be stockpiled. Mr Hancock claimed hes become the biggest buyer of fridges in the world, after fitting out facilities for storage of the crucial drugs. NHS staff are being directed to urge patients not to stockpile medicines personally to avoid shortages throughout the system.  Mobile roaming charges face an immediate hikethere is a No Deal Brexit, the government has confirmed. Tory ministers are revoking the EU law which guarantees UK citizens pay the same for using their phone on the Continent as they do at home. That will leave mobile phone firms free to hike costs whenever they like after the UK leaves. Guaranteed free roaming launched across the EU just  months ago - and meant big savings. But that guarantee will be scrappedthere is no deal, thanks to an obscure law laid before Parliament.  Eurostar services could be suspended in a worst-case no deal Brexit. The government has told international train passengers - including the Eurostar - to make sure they have insurance and ticket terms and conditions that are sufficient to cover possible disruption. That implies passengers should buy FLEXIBLE tickets - not the fixed cheap ones that are popular for their low cost. The UK will need bilateral deals with France, Belgium and the Netherlands to ensure international trains keep running. Without such a deal, Britain has proposed recognising EU operator licences until March  to ensure services can continue. But this isnt guaranteed, and UK operators would have to reapply with the EU. The EU has agreed to keep permissions for services like the Channel Tunnel open for three monthsthere is No Deal, while a new agreement is negotiated. But there arent guarantees. Former Transport Secretary Andrew Adonis claimed the vital train link between Britain and Europe could be severed. . You might have to go through airport security twice  Air passengers changing flights in the EU may have to undergo two security screenings under a no-deal exit. Travellers boarding a plane in the UK to fly to a European airport, before changing flights for an onward destination, would be screened in Britain as they are now. But they might have to have a second check in the EU before getting their connecting flight. “Currently passengers flying from the UK and transferring at an EU airport for an onward flight do not have to be re-screened at that EU airport, because the UK applies, and exceeds, the EU baseline aviation security measures,” says a Department for Transport briefing note. “If there is no deal, and the EU decides not to recognise the UK aviation security system, then passengers and their luggage will have to be re-screened when changing flights in EU hub airports.” . You could be barred from using Netflix and Spoty on holiday  Britons could be barred from accessing their accounts for Netflix, Spoty and other online entertainment while travelling to EU statestheres a no-deal Brexit. Under the EU-wide portability regulation, which took force in April, citizens can access accounts set up and based in one country while visiting other member states. But a government technical notice said: The portability regulation will cease to apply to UK nationals when they travel to the EU. This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation. UK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU. . If you live in Northern Ireland, you face electricity blackouts  Northern Ireland will be forced to take drastic measures to stop the lights going out. A worst-case No Deal Brexit would scupper the all-island electricity market shared by Northern Ireland and the Republic - leaving it without any legal basis. This would make both markets less efficient, with potential effects for producers and consumers on both sides of the border, the government warns. And it may be necessary to seek additional [legal] powers to preserve security of supply. To stop the lights going out, Northern Ireland would have to take more electricity from British power stations through an interconnector running under the Irish Sea. But Northern Irelands Transmission System Operator may need to rely on fall-back arrangements to ensure power keeps flowing, the government warns. That is why, eventheres a no deal, the government will take all possible measures to keep the all-island market running. There has been talk of barges in the Irish Sea. Dustin Benton of Green Alliance warned:Any emergency action to keep the lights on, both in Northern Ireland and across the rest of the UK, would likely be highly polluting and expensive. . You could be stranded on your package holiday  Package holidaymakers could be left with no legal protectionthe firm they booked with goes bust. Currently Brits have insolvency protectionthey book with a package holiday provider thats based anywhere in the EU. But in a No Deal Brexit, that protection would only applythe firms are targeting the UK market. That means those booking with, say, a cheaper Spanish firm online that has no UK presence could be unprotected. Eventhe UK government could act, in practice it will be much harder to take enforcement action against foreign firms because other countries will no longer recognise UK courts. . Youll lose rights to take action over dangerous products  Government documents reveal the same problem - UK courts not being recognised - will strip Brits of their consumer rights for EU goods bought online. Alex Neill of consumer group Which  warned: A no-deal Brexit would massively weaken peoples rights to take action when they purchase faulty or dangerous products from outside the UK. The Governments advice that we all become experts in international consumer law is hopelessly unrealistic. Securing a good deal with the EU is vital to ensure that Brexit doesnt result in a bonfire of consumer rights and protections.” . Your cigarette packets will change  Graphic warnings on cigarette packets will be replaced by Australian versions in a no-deal Brexit. And in some ways they are even more gruesome than the ones we have now. The grim pictures show a foot ridden with peripheral vascular disease, a clogged artery, a bleeding brain and high-resolution teeth stained black. The photos will be changed in a No Deal Brexit because the European Commission owns theon ones we currently use. That means the UK would be unable to use them after  March . . If youre going through a family breakdown, you could be trapped in limbo  Families who are midway through orce or child custody cases involving another EU country could find themselves trapped in limbo. If there’s a no deal Brexit, the UK will cease to be part of co-operation between EU family courts on  March . Instead the UK will fall back on legal conventions drawn up in The Hague. But these are complicated and do not cover every area of the law. The government has advised families with ongoing cases to seek legal advicethey will not finish by Brexit Day. A government technical note says: Broadly speaking, cases ongoing on exit day will continue to proceed under the current rules. However, we cannot guarantee that EU courts will follow the same principle, nor that EU courts will accept or recognise any judgments stemming from these cases.” . Your everyday medicines and perfumes could become more expensive  Currently, popular ingredients in cold medicines can usually be traded within the EU without a licence. In a no deal, a licence will be required to trade these so-called precursors. Sowe leave without a deal, firms who want to trade such chemicals with the EU will have to register with the Home Office, which can cost between pound and pound,. They will also need an import export license, which costs pound. Critics say this could push up prices for consumers in the shops. Similarly, cosmetics firms will be slapped with more red tape to prove their products are safe for human health. Currently they can use one legal “nominated person” to certy a product for the whole EU market. Butthere’s a no deal Brexit, UK checks won’t be recognised in the EU - and EU checks wont be recognised in the UK. That means two sets of checks. Labour MP Owen Smith claimed drug giants will look to pass on the costs. And finally... your regular caviar parties are doomed!  Caviar imports will be snarled up or stop completely in a No Deal Brexit. Sturgeon eggs join snowdrops, orchids and reptiles in endangered species that would need import and export permits to cross an EU border. Youd only be allowed to bring in g of caviar for personal use. A tragedy.

title: my little girls superhero shes
story: NewsMy little girls a superhero - and shes got her super eye patch to prove itLyndsey Charnock, , feared the worst when doctors told her newborn Jess might have a tumour. Now, five years on Lyndsey tells of her relief and the journey her brave daughter has been onShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI heard the word tumour and felt instantly terried. Whats wrong  What will her le be like  What happens next  - the questions kept coming. Jess had entered the world just hours before and we were overjoyed. It had been a tough few days, but our second daughter was finally here - a sister for our one-year-old Millie. But joy turned to such terrible worry and upset after those first newborn checks were carried out. Now, as we watch our bubbly little girl enjoying le in her colourful, cartoon eye-patch, were so proud of how shes taken everything in her stride. The operations - one for every year of her le - the endless hospital visits and perseverance with her superhero eye patch - shes breezed through it all.  My pregnancy with Jess had gone really smoothly. Scans at each stage showed there was nothing wrong and she was growing normally - we couldnt wait to meet her. But her tiny eyes were closed and we had no idea there was a problem. My waters broke five days before she was born and despite it being hard work, the birth was absolutely fine. Then, after just a few hours with our girl, alarm bells started to ring. The paediatrician came to the ward to carry out basic newborn checks on Jess. Everything was going well, until they looked at her eye. Theres no reflex in her right one doctors told us. They explained how after shining a torch into her eye, there wasnt the red glow a healthy eye gives when having a picture taken.  They said it could be a number of things, so we were sent for more check-ups on the neonatal ward. Then they mentioned a tumour. It was absolutely terrying - we thought about her future, the le we had planned her being a part of and desperately hoped for good news. We then went to the Manchester Eye Hospital, where a few days later they told us it was cataracts - a clouding over the lens of the eye. I felt pure relief at first - thinking of how easy it was to fix my dads cataracts - but I didnt know how dferent it was in a baby who had no developed eyesight. Jess then had her first operation at just six weeks old - and I was terried. Doctors explained how they would remove the lens of her right eye, but might not be able to fit an articial one as her eye was still too small. She was so tiny and saying goodbye to her as she went into surgery was gut-wrenching.  I was a bundle of nerves and couldnt go with her to theatre - I had to leave that to her dad. I knew she was in good hands with the doctors, but all I could do was wait for good news. And in a way, it came. They were able to remove the lens, but couldnt fit a new one. She was just too small and delicate. We were left with only one option- contact lenses, taken in and out of our tiny daughters eye every day. Along with the contact lens in her affected eye, we had to patch up her good eye to make the other work harder. The little sight Jess had, I was taking away from her - but I knew it was for her own good. Six weeks later, Jess had another operation to remove some remnants of the lens which had been left in and had started to mesh together. My girl wasnt even six-months-old and she had already seen the inside of an operating theatre twice. There was more to come.  After her cataracts operations, we were hit with another blow when she developed glaucoma - a potentially blinding condition. Jesss eyes soon began weeping a lot because her drainage channel wasnt letting enough water in and she needed two separate operations to widen it. We were still going with eye drops and patches, but it started to become really hard work when she got to the age of one. Jess was becoming more aware and started realising there were times without the eye patch, and times with it. And she made it perfectly clear what she preferred. She would constantly peel it off and wed go through about  a day - maybe more. It was a really dficult time and so draining on us - we were trying our best for Jess, but she was too young to understand.  As we desperately battled to keep her patch on and get her poorly eye stronger, we were faced with another stumbling block. Jess would constantly fall asleep when we covered her good eye. Being left with just the reduced sight in her left, she got bored and tired quickly and struggled to stay engaged. But we needed her to stay awake and strengthen the brain-to-eye connection. If we got a full  minutes with the patch on - wed see this as a win. We then started doing patch time, which basically involved doing anything to take her mind off wearing it. Wed play games or go out somewhere, and for a few amazing hours, shed forget about it. When Jess started pre-school, her daily routine also helped her understand when she had to keep it on. Jess has been absolutely amazing throughout the whole thing, and I think we found it harder than her at times. But when she started reception, it was the first time she started asking questions about why other children dont wear eye patches.  Thats when the Super Eye story started, helping my daughter make sense of what was happening to her, We told her she was so special, she was born with a Super Eye and she came to enjoy the colourful, sparkly patches she got to wear. Jesss latest surgery came in November last year, to fix a turn in her eye - known as a squint. We first noticed it at about  months old, but doctors told us to wait until her sight had sufficiently developed. It was a  degree turn in the eye, so quite noticeable. Why does my eye turn in and nobody s does  - It was the question that got me thinking it was time to get it looked at. Wed tell her it was her special Super Eye - but she was definitely becoming more aware of her condition compared to others around her. Her squint is much better, but weve been told she may need one more operation in the future to correct it even further. She also knows the patch will be a part of her le until shes eight.
