title: mans-driving-ban-after-refusing-to-give-breath-test
story: Adrian Magee was staying at Seton Sands Holiday Village when he was pulled over by officers on suspicion of drink-driving at about midnight on September  last year.He was taken to Dalkeith Police Station, where he twice refused to take part in a breath test and stated: ldquoI do not give my consent.Magee, currently of Sutton-on-Trent, Nottinghamshire, pleaded guilty to the offence during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court on Monday.Sherf Thomas Welsh was told that twice previously Magee had been caught over the drink-driving limit, including an offence in England which took place just four days before the latest case.Defending solicitor Kenneth Woodburn said that Magee did not comply with the request to take the test due to ldquohistorical matters between him and the police.Mr Woodburn said that -year-old Magee ldquono longer drinks and no longer drives and had sold his car following his latest arrest.The solicitor asked the sherf to deal with the matter that day instead of deferring for reports as his client had a -hour round trip to get to court in Edinburgh.Following a short adjournment, Sherf Welsh agreed to the request and banned Magee from driving for three years and fined him pound.Magee pleaded guilty to failing to provide two specimens of breath at Dalkeith Police Station on September  last year.

title: couples-quick-wedding-after-brides-dad-given-weeks-to-live
story: Bex Wood, neacutee Cunningham, was not even engaged when she found out that her dad, George Cunningham, had just weeks to live.Bex, along with boyfriend Ali Wood, quickly got engaged and got married just six days after the doctors broke the bad news to her dad.She told the Courier: ldquoThe wedding was brilliant.ldquoIt was quite bittersweet but from looking back at photographs, everybody commented on how happy everybody was.ldquoWe could have made it a sad day but we did not want that.ldquoIt was a still a celebration it was perfect, the weather was great ndash everything.ldquoThat was how it would have gonewe took a couple of years to plan it.George, , of Longniddry, had been suffering from stomach pains last year.Bex told the Courier: ldquoHe was diagnosed with lymphoma last June.ldquoThey said they were putting him on a curative plan and said to him he could be home and cured by Christmas.ldquoHe was getting treatment but then in October he started to get more treatment.ldquoThey did tests and just found out it was not working and he only had weeks to live.Ali and Bex had been together for five years and had spoken of getting married but had never really put any plans into motion.However, after the diagnosis, Ali went shopping for an engagement ring and proposed on the Sunday.The couple, who live in Prestonpans, tied the knot on the Thursday at Longniddry Parish Church before a reception at Archerfield House.Despite the short timeframe, Bex said the couple were not overly stressed by the occasion, with Alirsquos sister-in-law Lyndsay putting things together.Bex, , said: ldquoYou need a team of people to help. We hardly did any of it ourselves ndash Alirsquos sister-in-law pretty much did all of it.ldquoShe was the events planner at Archerfield and she did pretty much all of it.ldquoFamily did bits and pieces but Lyndsay did most of it so we cannot take any of the credit.The happy couple were married on November , with George walking his daughter down the aisle in front of  guests.Medical sales rep Bex said: ldquoHe was absolutely fine on the day.ldquoHe was a bit tired and went for a lie down but he walked me down the aisle no bother.ldquoHe did his speech and the first dance together and then he just sat and everybody chatted to him.George sadly passed away on November , with the funeral taking place in the same church.Bex and Ali, who works as a field sales manager, decided to hold off on a honeymoon, with the couple jetting off to Dubai and the Males next month.Bex added: ldquoWe wanted to spend as much time with him as possible.ldquoWe had no idea in terms of timeframes so we spent everyday with him.An online fundraising page has also been set up to raise money for Bloodwisego to justgiving fundraising alastair-wood

title: substation-plan-at-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-approved
story: The site, which is owned by East Lothian Council and had been earmarked as having the potential to bring more than , jobs to the community, has been at the centre of a battle between the community, the council and windfarm company Inch Cape.Ministers called in the planning application from Inch Cape,which wants to bring energy from a planned offshore windfarm onshore at the site, before East Lothian Council had made any ruling on it.The call-in was controversially made while First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was visitingChina, where she met representatives of the Chinese state-owned Red Rock company, which owns Inch Cape.Issuing their decision, Scottish Ministers said they agreed with the Scottish Government reporterrsquos findings that the substation was of ldquonational importance.East Lothian Council and local communities had argued it would ldquosterilise the site for future economic development.However, the reporter noted that the substation would take up less than  per cent of the former power station site.

title: parking-time-limit-restrictions-at-musselburghs-old-town-hall-tightened-up
story: A new Traffic Regulation Orderwas introduced on Monday. Although the location had been subject to a -minute limit in the past, the council created additional spaces to which the time restriction needed to be enforced.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe previous TRO made reference to the size and shape of the old road layout and therefore couldnrsquot be enforced following the construction of the new road layout.She said that a -minute waiting restriction would remain from St Peterrsquos Church, past Loretto School.The spokeswoman added that parking issues with motorists leaving their vehicles all day were compounded following the removal of Police Scotlandrsquos traffic warden service in  as there was little chance that vehicles would be ticketed.The council was then granted powers on January , , to carry out parking enforcement and undertook a series of reviews on town centre parking.A new parking layout, including additional spaces and new parking for bicycles has since been introduced by the Town Hall.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe restrictions were  minutes before but had been ignored as no enforcement could be carried out.ldquoThe council then got enforcement powers and a Traffic Regulation Order has brought in -minute limited waiting within the new road layout near Musselburgh Town Hall and on the section of High Street opposite.ldquoThe disabled parking spaces will also be enforced, ensuring blue badge holders can park close to a busy town centre.ldquoThe -minute restrictions will create a turnover of vehicles and stop all-day parking, which should assist the needs of businesses, visitors and residents during peak times. These timed restrictions will operate between the times of .am to .pm, Monday to Saturday.ldquoThe issue of increased car ownership is a major contribution to the parking problems found in Musselburgh and in other towns throughout East Lothian and, whilst this is a dficult problem to address, the council is committed to tackling such issues by improving the quality of transport infrastructure across East Lothian, promotion of sustainable transport options and identying opportunities to create more car parking spaces such as the new parking provision in Musselburgh High Street.ldquoIn addition the councilrsquos parking strategy includes extending and introducing residents parking schemes throughout East Lothian.

title: politicians-disappointed-with-apology-letter-from-scotrail
story: Martin Whitfield MP and Iain Gray MSP had written a letter to ScotRail in January outlining the problems that East Lothian constituents were facing after complaints of late trains and too few carriages.ScotRail responded by saying: ldquoWe know that train performance hasnrsquot been good enough in recent months and I am sorry for how that has impacted our customers.ldquoWhen the railway doesnrsquot work as it should, it causes immense inconvenience and disruption for those who rely on us to get to work, or to see family and friends.ldquoThe level of cancellation has reduced steadily over the past month and we will continue to cut cancellations to improve the service.ldquoAs more staff are trained, our performance is improving, and our most recent performance results continue to show an improvement.Both Parliamentarians have branded this letter ldquodisappointing, with Mr Gray saying: ldquoEast Lothian rail users are rightly fed up with ScotRailrsquos litany of excuses and hollow apologies for their ongoing service failures.ldquoActions always speak louder than words. I will not let up in highlighting the problems experienced by constituents and demanding change until we see sustained improvements in the way ScotRail delivers local services.Mr Whitfield added: ldquoOnce again, ScotRailrsquos reply to our service challenge says all the right things about delivering more staff and investing in new and upgraded trains to improve performance.ldquoThe problem is that we have heard it all before, but things never seem to get better.

title: fresh-bid-for-houses-new-clubhouse-and-course-at-dunbar-golf-club
story: Between  and  new houses could be built on two sites next to the -hole golf course, as well as a new clubhouse, a new nine-hole course and practice facilities.The proposals come  years after the club applied to East Lothian Council to develop a new clubhouse, nine-hole golf course, golf academy and driving range, short practice facilities, greenkeepersrsquo shed, housing and hotel to complement the existing course.In October , the scheme was given the green light.Now, a fresh application has been made by Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd.The majority of the homes would be built around the existing Deer Park Cemetery, to the south-east of much of the existing golf course.A smaller number of houses is earmarked for land at the current clubhouse, off Golf House Road.Plans suggest that the nine-hole course would be created opposite the housing development being built off Bowmont Terrace.New documents lodged with the councilrsquos planning department, referencing the previously approved plans, state: ldquoThis permission also included a Section  legal agreement which seeks to control the timing of the delivery of new homes alongside the delivery of the new clubhouse and associated facilities, commits the golf club to contributions towards education provision, as well as a commitment to a collaborative approach in promoting the site for a future hotel development [and as per the masterplan].ldquoAs Dunbar Golf Club undertook further work, including marketing the site under the terms of the planning permission, it became clear that the layout proposed in the masterplan accompanying the planning permission in outline did not reflect the best option for future development, mostly with regards to the proposed mix of housing and the balance of the quantum of development between the clubhouse site and Deer Park. Clear feedback highlighted that more units should be proposed at Deer Park, with a limited development of larger homes on the existing clubhouse site.ldquoIn detailed discussions with East Lothian Council, it was agreed that fresh planning permission would be required. Given the size of the site and scale of development, it is considered a major development and therefore triggered the requirement for this formal pre-application consultation process.A public exhibition is to take place on April  at the Dunmuir Hotel, -pm, to reveal the new plans to the public for the first time.The number of houses planned are estimated to be between  and , compared to  in the previous application. The golf club will also maintain a site for potential future hotel development. Councillors Norman Hampshire, Paul McLennan and Sue Kempson, who represent the town, will also be made aware of the plans, as will the townrsquos community council.Dunbar Golf Clubrsquos East Links has played host to many national and several international championships, as well as being a final qualying course for the Open when it is played at Muirfield. The club was founded in .

title: musselburgh-woman-taking-her-dog-to-debut-at-crufts
story: Lorraine Murtagh, , of the townrsquos Delta Drive, and dog Inca are part of the Scottish team competing in the rally competition at Crufts.Rally, the latest dog sport to be recognised by the Kennel Club, involves the dog and handler working as a team to navigate a course featuring  to  exercises.Each course is dferent and there are more than  exercises in rally, including stationary tasks, recalls, jumps, retrieves and cone weaves.Lorraine is entered at level two in the Inter-regional Rally Competition, one of six competitors in the Scottish team at the NEC in Birmingham event next Thursday .The Inter-regional Rally Competition at Crufts features seven teams: Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regions. Last year, the Scottish team finished third.Lorraine got involved in rally just six months ago, having enjoyed other dog sports, and focused Inca is also proving a natural with her love for learning new things.Lorraine, who has five dogs ndash three springer spaniels and two Border collies ndash runs her own dog-walking business, Waggy Walks Edinburgh.She said: ldquoInca is a five-year-old English springer spaniel whom I rescued at just over a year old. I got her from the Dog Aid Society.ldquoShe is the sweetest, most affectionate dog and, at home, loves nothing more than cuddling on the sofa.ldquoOn walks she loves to run and explore, and is always up for an adventure. Inca also loves to work and will turn her paw to anything I ask of her.ldquoShe is always happy to learn and, although we are both new to rally, we are really enjoying learning new skills together. Inca and I also train and compete regularly in flyball and in agility, where she currently competes at Grade . We also do a little Canicrossto keep us busy.ldquoInca is a joy to work with and a wonderful friend.ldquoI am really excited about my first time competing at Crufts ndash I canrsquot wait.Tom Mather, Crufts chairman, said: ldquoCrufts offers something for everyone and this year looks like being no exception.ldquoVisitors to the show will be able to see dogs and their handlers taking part in a iety of activities and displays and we would urge anyone looking to buy a puppy to visit the ever-popular Discover Dogs area where they will be able to meet the breeds up close.ldquoWe feel honoured to welcome dogs from a wider iety of breeds than ever before, representing all corners of the globe.ldquoThe fact that people travel far and wide to enter this prestigious event proves that it really is the worldrsquos greatest dog show.Crufts runs from March  to . Nearly , dogs will compete for best in show, including , dogs from overseas. Italy has the most entries from overseas with  dogs followed closely by France .For more information, visit crufts.org.uk

title: more-than-30-jobs-to-be-created-as-dunbar-asda-extension-approved
story: The extension, which will be to the north of the existing building, is expected to see the store stock more homeware products and also see the launch of a home shopping service.The supermarket giant submitted plans to East Lothian Council before Christmas. Now planners have given the scheme the green light, with no objections from the public.A spokesman for Asda told the Courier: ldquoWersquore delighted with the outcome.ldquoThese plans represent a signicant investment into our Dunbar store and will improve the range of goods on offer and help bring Asdarsquos famously low prices to more people, as well as providing new job opportunities.It is not yet known when work will start on extending the Spott Road store or how long the construction work will take. Currently, the store, which opened about  years ago, has a floorspace of about ,m, with the extension adding a further m to the building.A total of  parking spaces will be lost but it is felt that the remaining  spaces will be adequate because the increase in home deliveries will likely offset the reduction in customer trips to the store.The home delivery service will see four vans operating from the store.One van is expected to make four deliveries per day, with the remaining three doing half that number.Dunbar Community Council backed the plans, while Dunbar Tradesrsquo Associationhad reservations but vowed to keep working to ensure the success of the townrsquos High Street.The planning officerrsquos report noted: ldquoThe proposed extension would sit comfortably on the side of the existing building and would not harmfully disrupt its architectural form and appearance.ldquoIt would be physically and visually well contained to the side of the existing building and would not be an overdevelopment of it.ldquoThe proposed extension would be a subservient and complimentary addition to the existing building and would not appear intrusive or incongruous in its setting.

title: breathing-space-for-the-hollies-day-centre-after-120000-boost
story: The grant, for a three-year period, has been announced, much to the delight of manager Liz Shannon.She told the Courier: ldquoThe dference the award from The National Lottery Community Fund will make to the members and customers of the Hollies is immeasurable.ldquoIt will give a breathing space for the near future.ldquoIt will allow us to not only maintain existing services but expand what we already offer the elderly population of Musselburgh and surrounding areas.ldquoThis includes providing entertaining and structured activities for the over-s in a warm, safe and comfortable environment.ldquoWe also want to help prevent social isolation and encourage social interaction by continuing to provide a place for people to meet friends and make new ones.Maureen McGinn, chairperson of The National Lottery Community Fund Scotland, said: ldquoI am delighted that Hollies Day Centre SCIO has been successful in securing a grant from The National Lottery Community Fund.ldquoThe award will make a big dference where it is needed most and I wish the Hollies Day Centre every success as it goes on to develop and expand its project for the benefit of their local community.Ms Shannon said that the lottery funding would help with services such as staffing costs and the centre would also continue to fundraise.The good news follows a dficult time for the cash-strapped Hollies, which was the victim of a break-in before Christmas when a safe was stolen from the High Street premises.But supporters and members of the public rallied round, with donations from ious sources, including Scott Glynn of the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation, who presented a cheque to the centre for pound, to replace the cash stolen in the safe.Staff and volunteers also celebrated the success of their pound, bid for funding from the Robertson Trust, which aids organisations working in Scotland and a pound, leline from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund to keep its services going in the lead-up to Christmas.The Hollies, which received an pound, grant from East Lothian Council last year, has received its final instalment of more than pound, which takes it to the end of the financial year in March.Ms Shannon said that the centre was still in talks with the local authority over provision of its services in the future.Martin Whitfield, East Lothian MP, visited the Hollies recently to meet staff, volunteers and members, and congratulate them on their lottery funding boost.He said: ldquoThe Hollies Day Centre is a much-loved community facility which does an amazing job for older people in Musselburgh.ldquoI was pleased to visit the centre to meet staff, volunteers and some of the local people who use its services and congratulate them on their latest success in securing this lottery funding.ldquoItrsquos great news for the centre and will help it to keep making a positive dference for older people in Musselburgh.ldquoI want to congratulate Liz and her team, and thank them for everything they do.Ms Shannon added: ldquoThe Hollies staff and volunteers were delighted to welcome Mr Whitfield.ldquoHe enjoyed a tour of our fabulous community resource in the centre of Musselburgh.ldquoWe hope that he will visit again soon so we can keep him abreast of all the new and exciting activities taking place at the Hollies.

title: top-jockey-peter-scudamore-helps-launch-new-replay-cards-at-musselburgh-racecourse
story: On-hand to support the initiative last week was eight-time champion jockey Peter Scudamore MBE and local MP Martin Whitfield.Mr Scudamore joined local Sporting Memories groups, volunteers and other local racing representatives to talk about his time as a jockey and trainer and share his memories and stories. He also took part in a question-and-answer session involving group members.The launch at Musselburgh, Scotlandrsquos second biggest racecourse, was held by Sporting Memories in partnership with Racing Welfare Scotland and Racing Together. It ran simultaneously with another launch event at Palace House, The National Heritage Centre for Horseracing  Sporting Art, at Newmarket.The sporting aid memory cards feature the great and the good of horseracing throughout history and were compiled with the assistance of Racing Welfarersquos Malton-based welfare team to support older people living with dementia, depression and loneliness. The cards have an image of a sporting legend on the front and some information about their achievements on the back.Sporting Memories produces a number of resources and materials to inspire and promote reminiscence, which are then available for third-party organisations to buy to utilise at their own events.Chris Wilkins, co-founder and director of Sporting Memories Network, said: ldquoThe Sporting Memories Foundation in England and Scotland uses sports reminiscence to engage isolated older people living with conditions such as dementia, loneliness and depression.ldquoOur club members, who meet on a weekly basis in locations across the UK, are brought together through a shared love of sport, and enjoy using our replay reminiscence cards that help trigger memories and conversation.ldquoWe have already produced a range of replay cards which reflect a wide selection of sports, and we are now delighted to launch our latest set on racing, which will help to trigger memories of watching or participating in horseracing.ldquoThemes for the cards were suggested by members of our Racing Welfare Sporting Memories Club at Malton and reflect some of the great jockeys, horses and courses that together represent some of the best and most enduring memories of racing.ldquoImages can be very powerful in helping prompt memories and stories which, particularly for people living with dementia, can otherwise remain locked away and untold. Our aim is to unlock those stories and together celebrate some wonderful racing memories.ldquoWe couldnrsquot deliver our work without the support of volunteers and we are always looking for other sports fans who might be interested in supporting the fun and fulfilling activities that take place in our weekly clubs. Information about our clubs and volunteering opportunities can be found at our website thesmfMP Mr Whitfield said: ldquoI was delighted to attend the launch of the Sporting Memories Foundationrsquos new racing replay cards in Musselburgh.ldquoThese cards are another great resource from Sporting Memories, which has an extensive range of sporting memory aids. Listening to Peterrsquos stories and the memories they evoked in others made it clear what a valuable tool they can be for those living with dementia.ldquoI commend Sporting Memories and Racing Welfare on this welcome initiative and their other activity supporting older and vulnerable people.

title: in-pictures-our-lady-of-loretto-youth-players-back-to-the-80s-show
story: The cast of young performers, aged  to , were delighted with the support from audiences over the three days of the recent production.Hit songs by a range of stars from the s ran through the show, which told the story of Corey Palmer, played by Peter Lally, remembering his last year in high school.The music included Footloose, Irsquom Gonna Be , Girls Just Want To Have Fun, Hey Mickey, Shot Through The Heart, Video Killed The Radio Star, Kids In America, The Final Countdown, Total Eclipse Of The Heart and Walking On Sunshine.The -strong cast included: Tfany Houston, played by Kirsteen Brownlee Mr Stevie Cocker ndash Georgio Michalakis Ms Sheena Brannigan ndash Anna Scott Cyndi Gibson ndash Jorgey Scott-Learmonth Fergal McFerrin ndash Jamie Fleming Michael Feldman ndash Luke Davidson and Eileen Brannigan ndash Eva Hills.Jill Alexander, an audience member, took to Facebook to praise the show, saying: ldquoWent to this show on a girlsrsquo night out with no expectations. Was totally blown away by this young grouprsquos talent, enthusiasm and professionalism. What a fabulous group with a shed-load of stars. Absolutely loved it.On the last night, the cast thanked Lorna Stewart, who stood down as chairperson after ldquomany years of incredible support to the group. She has been involved with OLOLYP for  years, which began as parent helper when her children were members of the group. She has given assistance through the committee and at shows, serving as chairperson for the past seven years.A former Musselburgh resident, she has now moved to Fe but continued to travel back to the Honest Toun to support OLOLYP.The young performers also paid tribute to the crew, sponsors and Brunton staff for their help in staging the show.The Musselburgh-based group now take a break until August, when they look forward to welcoming new members, aged  to , to join for their new show. They meet at Our Lady of Loretto Church Hall at pm every Sunday from late August.Anyone interested should email lorettoyouthplayers@hotmail or search for lsquoOur Lady of Loretto Youth Playersrsquo on Facebook.

title: 5000-donation-saves-dunbars-stone-stacking-championships
story: The European Stone Stacking Championships brought , people to the townrsquos coastline last April but it was feared that the competition might be cancelled this year due to a lack of funding.But James Craig Page, who co-organises the event, which is now celebrating its third year, was pleased to say the event would now be going ahead.He said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted, it is amazing.ldquoOf course, it was a worrying time just down to a lack of finance and whether it would go forward, but now it is going ahead.ldquoSomeone has come in and sponsored the event.Mr Page had previously told the Courier that cancelling the event, which offers a place at the World Stone Stacking Championships in America to the champion, was the ldquoworst-case scenario.However, thanks to a pound, donation from ldquoa private inidual, who wishes to remain anonymous, the event will once again take place on Dunbarrsquos shoreline.Further donations have also been received, with the event expected to cost about pound, to put on.Competitors from throughout Europe are expected to travel to East Lothian ahead of the two-day competition, which takes place on April  and .Stone stacking is an increasingly popular pastime which sees practitioners spending hours meticulously balancing rocks and stones, in sometimes unbelievable and unlikely ways, on top of one another.The competition brings together a community of stackers from across Europe.Mr Page added: ldquoIt is the most ancient art form that there is.There will be four inidual competitions at the event: the most stones balanced, the most artistic stone stack, the junior championship and the overall stone stacking champion.The first competition on April , from am to pm, is at rocky Eye Cave Beach, below Dunbar Sea Cadet hall.Competitors face the challenge of balancing as many stones as possible vertically, with last yearrsquos winner managing to balance  stones.This is followed by the balance against the clock adult competition at pm, where competitors have to balance the most stones in a three-minute challenge.The following day, adults are given three hours to create anything from stone or found objects in the artistic competition, which starts at noon.There are further competitions for youngsters, with more information at stonestacking

title: msp-writes-to-minister-opposing-housing-plans-by-dirleton-castle
story: Michelle Ballantyne, South Scotland MSP, has written to Scottish housing minister Kevin Stewart MSP urging him to throw out the proposals for the village of Dirleton.She said the plans, which would see  homes built at Castlemains Farm, to the east of Dirleton Castle, could lead to a reduction in the ldquomany tourists who visit the medieval fortress.The castle is one of East Lothianrsquos top five visitor attractions and dates back to the th century.In a letter to Mr Stewart, Conservative Ms Ballantyne said: ldquoDirleton attracts many tourists, particularly during the summer. The inclusion of a development which is out of step with the rest of the villagersquos architectural character could cause a reduction in visitor numbers.Developer Queensberry Properties Ltd was refused planning permission to build the houses by East Lothian councillors in September. It lodged an appeal with the Scottish Government after councillors voted against the advice of their own planning officers.In her letter to Mr Stewart, Ms Ballantynesays there is ldquooverwhelming local opposition to the plans and urges him to fully engage with local residents to ensure their voices are heard.She said: ldquo written objections were lodged with the council and only one representation of support. This matches with what I have seen on the ground. At a street surgery this was the number one issue raised.ldquoDirleton is an exceptionally beautul village with a th-century castle of national historic importance. There are few villages such as Dirleton in south Scotland and it would be a shame to rush into a development which could be much more considerate of the surrounding history and community.

title: five-out-of-six-electric-vehicle-charging-points-at-east-lothian-stations-not-working
story: Only the charging point at Drem Railway Station is back in action.The delays in bringing the charging points back into public use have been described as ldquodisappointingby East Lothian MSP Iain Gray.And Councillor Norman Hampshire, deputy leader of East Lothian Council, said moves to encourage people to buy electric cars could be hampered by the lack of working charging points.Mr Hampshire said the council had received numerous complaints about the out-of-order points at train stations.The council is currently working on an ambitious project to provide its own charging points not only in town centres but in villages and more rural locations as it strives to meet national targets.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoWe have received many complaints about the failure of this provision at all our train stations.ldquoIt has been taken up with Scot Rail on several occasions but no progress has been made.ldquoEast Lothian Council is working with the Scottish Government to deliver the new charging points and are stressing to them the importance of funding to deliver a high maintenance standard.ldquoWe will not give people the confidence to purchase an electric vehiclethey see many charging points with Out of Order signs on them.ScotRail said it lsquodecommissionedrsquo all its charging points across Scotland in May last year after a wiring fault was discovered at Pitlochry Station.At the time, the train operator said it hoped to have the points back in use in six weeks but a spokesperson, confirmed only  of ScotRailrsquos  chargers were in service, but they hoped to have the others back working in the spring.MSP Mr Gray said: ldquoWith the number of electric vehicles on our roads growing year on year, it is vital that owners have access to charging points in places that are convenient for them.ldquoTrain stations are an obvious place to help facilitate a joined-up approach to travel, so itrsquos certainly disappointing that so many charging points at East Lothian stations are out of order.ldquoI have already raised this with ScotRail and believe they should make it a priority to have them back up and running again as quickly as possible.A ScotRail spokesperson said: ldquoWe apologise to customers currently unable to charge their electric cars. We are working with our contractor to have our charge points back in service as quickly as possible.

title: cockburnspath-woman-meets-her-stem-cell-donor-on-itv-show
story: Laura Regan received a bone marrow transplant in  from an anonymous stem cell donor after being diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.Laura said that she thought about her donor often, adding: ldquoI knew it wouldnrsquot have been easy for him, having to re-arrange their le around the transplant.The -year-old was discovered by the ITV show This Time Next Year through her blog, in which she records the stages of her recovery.They filmed her saying that she would find her donor and they would appear on the show together a year later ndash which she did.The donor was a -year-old doctor named Simon Bird, and to her surprise they ended up living close to each other in London.ldquoThe first thing I did when I got Simonrsquos details was to look up his address on Google Maps," Laura said."It turned out that he lived just three miles away!ldquoEvery one of my friends told me I would be in tears but on the night, I couldnrsquot stop smiling."Simon was everything Irsquod hoped and imagined in real le and I was just so grateful to him for what hersquod done.ldquoWe were both keen to do the show to raise awareness for the Anthony Nolan Charity, who had helped me find a donor in the first place."Following filming, the pair have kept in touch. Laura said: ldquoWersquove been out for drinks. Wersquore both in long-term relationships, and Simon and his partner have invited me and my partner over for dinner. Wersquove become close.The episode, hosted by Davina McCall, will be aired tomorrowat .pm.

title: east-lothian-council-services-for-hire
story: The council is looking at ways to bring in extra revenue in the next three years by capitalising on its services and the influx of new housing in the county.Burial plots in two new cemeteries will be made available for advance sales as the council re-opens the pre-sale of lairs in Dunbar and Prestonpans, where capacity issues have seen the practice suspended in recent years. New housing developments in the towns have seen plans put forward for new graveyards to cope with the increasing populations.In Prestonpans, a proposed cemetery is included with plans to build  houses at Dolphingstone Farm while in Dunbar plans for a new graveyard at Newtonlees have been approved by the council.A council spokesperson said advance sales were withdrawn in the towns to ensure lairs were available for immediate need as they ran out of space.However, he confirmed: ldquoIt is expected that, as the new provision opens in Prestonpans and Dunbar, we will be in a position to process requests.As further new sites are developed, it is anticipated this option will become more widely available.It is anticipated the move will bring an additional pound, in revenue for the local authority in the next financial year as people queue up to book plots in their home towns.The move is one of a number of ventures which have been given the go-ahead in the councilrsquos budget plans for the next three years to maximise income.It also includes plans to bid to take over factoring contracts for landscaping in new housing developments and offer to install play equipment and areas in the same estates.The local authority is looking to capitalise on the influx of housing into the county, which is seeing up to , new homes being built across its communities.It hopes that it can compete with private factoring firms to take on responsibility for public areas within new housing estates, which developers traditionally hand on to independent factors.And it has budgeted a potential income of up to pound, by providing the commercial service over the next three years, as well as a further pound, by offering to install play areas in the new developments.The council said it was seeking to develop ldquocommercial opportunities across all services.The spokesman said: ldquoGiven the countyrsquos growth agenda, these are areas that we intend to explore.

title: man-who-slept-in-van-after-drinking-avoids-driving-ban
story: Mario Delacruz, , was caught sleeping in his van in an Edinburgh car park after he had been out drinking with friends in the city last year.Delacruz was spotted by police officers sleeping in the passenger seat of his van but they also saw his keys were lying nearby on the driverrsquos seat.The officers woke the Spanish national up and, after noticing he had been drinking alcohol, decided to breathalyse him.The tests showed that Delacruz, of The Promenade, was more than four times the drink-drive limit.Delacruz appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he pleaded guilty to being in charge of the vehicle at the time on October  last year.Solicitor Peter OrsquoNeill said that his client had been out with friends in the Leith area of the city and had decided to ldquosleep it off before going home the following day.Mr OrsquoNeill said that Delacruz had been in the UK for about five years and had moved to Scotland last July.He currently works as a cleaner and has sold the van he was found sleeping in.The lawyer added: ldquoHe is sorry and knows it should not have happened.Sherf John Cook fined Delacruz pound and told him that he would have  penalty points placed on his licence.Delacruz pleaded guilty to being in charge of a motor vehicle with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at Nichollfield, Edinburgh, on October  last year. The legal limit is  mcg.

title: conservatives-announce-haddington-by-election-candidate
story: Haddington resident Craig Hoy will represent the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party at the vote on May .The by-election was triggered by theresignation last week of Councillor Brian Small, who represented the Conservatives.Mr Hoy previously worked in journalism, first with the BBC before setting up several publications, including Holyrood Magazine.More recently, he has joined the development board of a major Scottish charity, which focuses on issues such as fuel poverty among older people.My Hoy was ldquodelighted to have been selected and looking forward to the election.He said: ldquoWith Nicola Sturgeon threatening a second independence referendum, itrsquos more important than ever that we elect a strong voice for Haddington and the Lammermuirs who will stand up to the SNP.ldquoAs a local resident and campaigner, Irsquom confident that I am well placed to do just that, and I look forward to taking our message to voters right across the ward over the coming weeks."And he added: "Our area has a fantastic sense of community and history.ldquoMy aim in this campaign is to meet as many people as possible to find out what their views are and what issues they want me to focus on.Tim Jackson, East Lothian Scottish Conservative Association chairman, was delighted to have secured ldquoa candidate of Craigrsquos calibre for the by-election.He said: ldquoNot only is he passionate about the area, but with his experience in media and business he can bring a lot to the council.ldquoI know he will give his all in the campaign, andelected he will do everything he can to provide a strong voice for everyone living in Haddington and the Lammermuirs.No other party has announced their candidate for the by-election.

title: port-seton-man-offers-to-clean-gardens-of-dog-waste
story: Super Pet Scooper was founded in January by Port Seton man Greg Mahony, of Laburnum Avenue, who will be servicing the East Lothian area for its doggy clear-up needs.ldquoI was looking for a business opportunity in the area, Greg said.ldquoCleaning gardens of dog waste is big in the USA and Canada, and even England, but not around here, so I saw a gap in the marketOriginally from Manchester, Greg and his family fell in love with all East Lothian had to offer, especially when walking his own rescue dog, Rocco. It was then he noticed that dog fouling in the area was becoming an issue.ldquoOur community wants to live in a nice environment, he said.ldquoWe promote responsible ownership, enforce fines and put up signs, but sometimes itrsquos just not enough.ldquoMany dog owners, like myself, always take doggie bags to clean up the waste, but sadly, many owners do not.This was when Greg came up with the idea for Super Pet Scooper.ldquoI never thought Irsquod start a business, but I wanted to do something that would help people and I love animals, especially dogs, so it made sense, he said.ldquoI donrsquot mind cleaning up after dogs, it doesnrsquot bother me! It also gets me out and about on a weekend, as well as a little more income.Greg works during the week for the NHS but has high hopes that he can build his company to a full-time role.ldquoAt the moment, Irsquom only part-time but Irsquom hoping to expand, he said.ldquoI got in touch with East Lothian Council for advice and they were fantastic, helped me get my waste carrier licence and advice on business insurance and things.Despite only being in his first month of business, the -year-old has a few clients and has been getting good reviews across Facebook.ldquoIrsquove had a positive reaction to the company, he said. ldquoI know a lot of people think thatyou have a dog you should be able to clean up after them yourself, but a lot of people canrsquot. They can fall ill or just become unable to move around like they used to, so thatrsquos where I can help.

title: ghost-hunters-heading-to-historic-east-lothian-buildings
story: The two events will be taking place in the coming months.Lisa Tedstill, company owner of UK Ghost Nights said: ldquoItrsquos all about the personal experience, the emotions, and sometimes the giggling and laughing. Itrsquos about the camaraderie. Itrsquos a great way to view history, and there have been many spooky things happening in these places.The night involves a tour of the building by a medium, then the chance to use high-tech ghost hunting equipment for experiments, as well as more standard methods such as seances and spirit boards.ldquoWe like to give people a chance to see and use lots of new things and provide a good mix of the technical and the traditional, added Lisa.ldquoItrsquos great here in East Lothian as there is so much history in these buildings.The ghost hunts are at Dunbar Town House on March  and Cockenzie House on April , both pm-am.

title: pupils-to-enjoy-unique-study-visit-to-oxford-university
story: Exeter College has teamed up with East Lothian Council to bring  third-year pupils to the university for a stay which will allow them to experience first-hand the unique learning techniques and opportunities available there.The project was established by former Councillor East Lothian Brian Small and his son Andrew, who is a doctoral student at the college and came up with the idea.Brian, of Pencaitland, said the pair now hoped to establish an endowment fund to ensure the trip can become an annual event for East Lothian students by providing travel costs and other support.This yearrsquos trip will see the local authority fund travel with the college covering all costs of the stay itself.Mr Small, who resigned from the council last week after branding his fellow Conservative councillors ldquoheartless over the way they dealt with his battle with health issues, said he wanted to make sure money was available to repeat the project every summer.He said: ldquoI am delighted we have been able to start this innovative project as pathways for all our children in East Lothian was always something I was fully committed to as a councillor.ldquoI am now looking to set up an endowment fund to ensure travel costs along with perhaps some other support needs are able to be covered in future years.ldquoIf anyone would like to discuss this further then I would be delighted to talk with them.Two pupils from each of East Lothianrsquos six secondary schools will travel to Oxford in June for the week-long stay.The selected students will live on Exeter Collegersquos historic main site, in the very heart of Oxford, where they will be given a taster experience of what makes an Oxford education.The council said interested pupils were now given a chance to apply for a place in the trip with places awarded by teachers following a selection procedure involving written work.Andrew said: ldquoThis is a fantastic opportunity for pupils from East Lothian to come and learn at one of the worldrsquos greatest educational institutions.ldquoThe weekrsquos activities have been selected to improve pupilsrsquo independent and creative thinking, which we hope will improve their attainment at school and perhaps even plant the seed of aspiration that will motivate pupils to attend the university.ldquoMy hope is that this is just the beginning of a long-standing partnership between the college and East Lothian.ldquoI would like to thank Sir Rick Trainor, Rector of Exeter College and Professor Mac Niocaill, the collegersquos Tutor for Admissions, for their full support. Without them, this partnership would have remained just an idea.Fiona Robertson, head of education, East Lothian Council, said the trip offered a rare opportunity for young people in the county to study at one of the worldrsquos top universities.She said: ldquoI hope the  pupils involved will find it to be an inspirational trip and one which allows them to develop their independent, creative thinking and commitment to learning. I would like to thank Andrew Small and his father, Brian Small, for making this a reality.

title: 1000-sign-petition-over-loss-of-creche-services-at-leisure-centres
story: The organisation manages leisure facilities across the county on behalf of East Lothian Council.However, it has taken the decision to close the creches following a drop in funding.The move has not gone down well with a number of parents, who fear they may have to cancel their gym membershipsthe creche service does not continue.A group of parents met with Iain Gray, East Lothianrsquos MSP, on Monday to discuss the issue.Among them was Sarah Brunton, who regularly uses enjoyleisurersquos facilities in North Berwick, Haddington and Dunbar.The mum-of-four said she had improved her fitness at the facilities since having her children. She said: ldquoItrsquos down to those facilities and being able to have a healthier lestyle.ldquoIt is about not just weight loss but also a mental health aspect. It gives you confidence and a lt after you have done exercise and it is proven that exercise does improve mental health.Mrs Brunton stressed the issue affected ldquoa lot of people and many were considering whether to cancel their membership.Another of those who has signed the online petition is -year-old Erin Malone, who uses the Aubigny Sports Centre, in Haddington, and Tranentrsquos Loch Centre.She said: ldquoThe creche is really important ndash not just for me but my son as well.ldquoMy daughter used it as well and we have been using it for over six years.ldquoIt is a social thing and a mental health thing as well.Lydia Eunson, from Dunbar, uses the sports centre in Dunbar twice a week.She added: ldquoMy husband works away four weeks at a time and I donrsquot have any family near here.ldquoBasically, I could not use the gym unless I paid a babysitter or went to a gym in Edinburgh with a creche.Bill Axon, general manager of enjoyleisure, stressed it was not a decision that was taken lightly, with discussions taking place with trade unions and no date set for any creche closure.He said: ldquoWe truly appreciate that the cregraveche service, which is supervised by highly-regarded staff, is an incredibly valued service by those who make use of it.ldquoIt is because of this fact, that the decision to withdraw this service has been so incredibly dficult.ldquoOver the past  years, since enjoyrsquos creation, we have retained this service for the benefit of our customers, despite operating at a shortfall.ldquoHowever, as user numbers continue to decline year upon year, the subsequent financial deficit has increased strain on the rest of the organisation.ldquoGiven the funding reductions and additional financial challenges faced by enjoy this year, we have reached the point where we simply cannot continue to subsidise a deficit of this magnitude.ldquoAdditionally, strict adult to child ratios and current charging requirements reduce our capacity of increasing income for this service, and at existing user levels, it is not possible to retain this provision at an affordable cost to customers.Mr Gray has got in touch with enjoyleisure to highlight the ious concerns.Mr Gray said: ldquoI met with a group of women campaigning against the cregraveche closures and listened very carefully to their concerns.ldquoItrsquos clear that whatever the reasons for the withdrawal of the cregraveche service, it will have a signicant impact on those who currently use it.ldquoI have now written to enjoyleisure to highlight the concerns raised with me and ask for a response.Councillor Stuart Currie, leader of the SNP Group on East Lothian Council, was similarly unimpressed with the decision to scrape the creches.He said the SNP Group was supporting the petition calling for enjoyleisure to think again.The Musselburgh councillor said: ldquoIn Haddington, Musselburgh and every other town this damaging decision will hit many people, particularly women, the hardest.Council leader Willie Inneshas written to Gordon Wales, chairman of the enjoyleisure board, to express his concern about the proposed changes.He said: "Following concerns expressed to me by regular users of enjoyleisure facilities about the closure of cregraveches I have written to Gordon Wales outlining the councils position about the importance of access to leisure facilities.ldquoCregraveches provide an important resource for families to be able to fully access a range of leisure activities and I hope alternative measures can be considered."To sign the petition, go to you.degrees.org.uk petitions keep-our-creche

title: pictures-a-look-around-the-new-wallyford-primary-school
story: The move to the new pound.million Wallyford Primary School took place on February .Mhairi Stratton, headteacher, said: ldquoIrsquove been really impressed at how quickly the children have settled into their new school. Theyrsquore enjoying the outdoor space and the freedom it gives them.ldquoThe more open classroom layouts are also great and very flexible for learning and play.As pupils settle into the new school, which boasts  classrooms and a further four nursery playrooms, East Lothian Council is in the process of securing land for a second high school for the Musselburgh area.The approval of the new high school, which will be built on land near Dolphingstone and take in students from the Pinkie area of Musselburgh, as well as Wallyford, was given at a meeting of East Lothian Council in December .The new high school was expected to begin taking in pupils from August , or as soon as possible after that date.But the council then wrote to all concerned to tell them that the expected opening of the school had now been put back to August .The decision to build a new secondary school near Wallyford followed a public consultation after it became clear that Musselburgh Grammar School would not be able to cope with the expected influx of new residents as a result of extensive housebuilding in Musselburgh and Wallyford.Three options were put forward: extend the current Grammar building create an upper and lower school on two campuses or build a new secondary school to complement Musselburgh Grammar.The council said a clear majority was in favour of building a new school but some labelled the consultation ldquoflawed.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe are in the process of securing the land for a new secondary provision for the Musselburgh area. Our capital budget for the five-year period  -  has allocated pound.m towards the project and developer contributions will be secured towards this investment.No decision has been taken on the future of the former Wallyford Primary School building at Salters Road, which was too small to accommodate the rising population.Land was secured on the east side of the town on the St Clementrsquos Wells development to create a new primary school campus to offer room for modern educational facilities for a growing school population, surrounded by plenty of outdoor space.The council spokesperson said: ldquoNow that the new Wallyford Primary School is open and ing, we are in the final stages of moving equipment from the old school.ldquoNo decision has been taken on the future of the former school site but the council will be considering options.

title: search-for-headteacher-for-new-merged-prestonpans-primary-school
story: That comes after it was confirmed that the current headteachers of both schools would not be putting their names forward for the role.East Lothian Council approved a merger of the two schools last December.The local authority has now confirmed that neither the current headteacher of Prestonpans Primary, Jonathan Revell, nor of Prestonpans Infant School, Sheila Laing, will be applying for the role.Sheila Laing became headteacher at Prestonpans Infant School in September , moving from Campie Primary School in Musselburgh, while Mr Revell was appointed headteacher at Prestonpans Primary in September .A video has been posted on Prestonpans Primary Schoolrsquos Twitter feed and its parent council Facebook page in which pupils and teachers appeal for candidates to apply.In the video, Fiona Robertson, head of education at the council, states the need for someone who can ldquobelieve, achieve, strive for excellence and care for all.The video also sees the children demonstrate their cooking and sign language skills, with one child adding: ldquoThe best teachers you could ever wish for are in this school.ldquoThere are lots of fun and dferent events happening throughout the year.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for education, told the Courier: ldquoThis is a great opportunity for someone who is passionate about supporting an amazing school and its local community.ldquoThere is already lots of great work happening in Prestonpans, especially in supporting and engaging with parents and carers, which has received national recognition. We need someone who will continue to build upon this work and support our children and young people to achieve their fullest potential.The appeal for the new headteacher coincides with a consultation that has been opened by the council to give a name to the new school.The name of the school, as suggested by the council, should be based on either a notable person from the area, the location of the school or include the vision of the school.The consultation closes on March , and any suggestions can be either emailed to educationconsultations@eastlothian.gov.uk or posted to John Muir House, Haddington.The new school will follow a single curriculum. There are no plans to move buildings, with the new school running across the two former education establishments.

title: plans-lodged-to-turn-former-dunbar-rbs-into-a-sweet-shop
story: Gavin and Susan Love, of Love Sweets and Ices, plan to open a second sweet shop on Dunbar High Street, with a shop within the former Royal Bank of Scotlandpremises.The national bank moved out of  High Street last May, with the premises lying empty ever since.Now plans have been submitted to East Lothian Council looking for alterations to be carried out and the building to be turned into a shop and cafe with outdoor seating.Drawings included in the planning application show little in the way of changes inside the building, with internal walls remaining in place.A seating area would be included at the rear of the building, with benches outside the front in a fenced-off seating area.A managerrsquos office would also be created to the front of the building.Gavin Love, who along with we Susan runs the business at its existing premises of  High Street, said: ldquoThings have been progressing really well.ldquoOur initial plan was to open in March but we have now decided to add some internal seating for sit-in ice cream and we now intend to open in late April early May.Mr and Mrs Love intend to run both shops and use the additional space to provide a wider range of traditional specialised confectionery products and ice cream.Drawings included within the planning application suggest a new lsquoThe Sweetie Bankrsquo sign could be created outside the business.The plans were first highlighted at the townrsquos community council meeting in November last year.Pippa Swan, the grouprsquos chairwoman, was hopeful the business would prove to be a great success.She said: ldquoI had no idea there was such a demand for sweeties and scrumptious things but what a wonderful, fun use of a great building. Irsquom looking forward to it and I am sure it will be a good addition to the street.The bank branch closure was one of  RBS and  NatWest branches to shut following a decision at the end of .The move was widely criticised by local politicians and members of the public, with North Berwickrsquos RBS also closing.

title: belhaven-bays-baywatch-to-patrol-the-beach-this-summer
story: A grant of pound, has been given to Dunbar Surf Le Saving Clubto run the project, which will see training given to volunteers, as well as raising awareness of the risks associated with the coast.The money, from the Big Lottery Fund, will ensure the Dunbar organisation is the first of its kind in Scotland to run a volunteer Beach Surf Lesaving Patrol.Sally Harris, head coach of DSLSC, told the Courier: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to receive this funding from the National Lottery.ldquoWe will now be able to put together Scotlandrsquos first community-led voluntary surf lesaving beach patrol team in Dunbar.ldquoThe funding will also allow us to continue our preventative education programme, helping to reduce the national coastal drowning statistics.The aims of the Belhaven Bay Community Le Saving Beach Patrol are to provide a lesaving service for the community and visitors, to prevent accidental drowning and injury among beach users.Training will also be given to young people and adults in the community to deliver the services while also raising awareness of the risks associated with using the beach and sea.In , more than  people drowned in the UK.Belhaven Bay, within John Muir Country Park, is a favourite spot for surfers, open-water swimmers and water sports enthusiasts from across the country and beyond.The Beach Patrol will initially operate during the busy summer weekends.Dunbar and East Linton ward member Councillor Norman Hampshire welcomed the scheme.He said: ldquoAs the local ward councillor, I am delighted that Belhaven lsquoBaywatchrsquo with Scotlandrsquos first volunteer Beach Patrol Service are going to start this year.ldquoI would like to congratulate them on their successful application to the Big Lottery.ldquoThis will provide some good training opportunities for young people and adults in the area.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, wished the club the best of luck.He said: ldquoIt is a worthwhile objective andit makes the beach safer one must applaud it.

title: world-champion-sprinter-maria-lyle-thanks-her-mum-for-rekindling-her-love-of-athletics
story: Maria Lyle ed from the Fazza International Championships in Dubai recently with two gold medals.However, it was just last year that she broke down in tears during her ldquodarkest moment before a major competition.The teenager has lived with diplegic cerebral palsy in her legs almost all her le.The -year-old told the Courier that her mum Susan had been with her throughout her journey, which has seen her represent Great Britain in the Paralympics and Scotland in the Commonwealth Games.Her mum is a PE teacher at Dunbar Primary School and taught Maria.Keen for Maria to be involved as much as her peers, but with little experience of teaching pupils with a disability, Susan looked for ways to deliver lessons which allowed Maria to flourish.Maria said: ldquoWhen I was younger, I struggled quite a lot. Things didnrsquot come quite as naturally for me as they did for my peers and often I ended up feeling a bit rubbish about myself.ldquoThings drastically changed, however, after one PE lesson. We had to complete the multi-stage fitness test .ldquoAs someone who fell over constantly and ended up with cut knees  per cent of the time, you could say I wasnrsquot that keen to join the lesson.ldquoTo everyonersquos surprise, I was the last one left in the test. That was the first time Irsquod ever felt such a sense of achievement. From that moment, running would become a big part of my le.Those short runs started to build Mariarsquos strength.She became European champion in  and within the next four years Paralympic, World and Commonwealth medals followed.But despite all her success, Maria couldnrsquot find the same love for her sport as she had during those early runs with her mum. The teenager became overwhelmed with worry about competing and her concerns impacted her le away from the track.After suffering in silence for years, Maria finally opened up to her mum, who convinced her to seek professional help. She was later diagnosed with having anxiety.Maria, who works at the Scottish Parliament as a committee assistant, said: ldquoMy mum would give up lots of her time, she would lead my sessions and drive me all over the country so I could compete. She would even take time off work to watch me in competitions. Because of this I would get worriedI didnrsquot run well.ldquoIrsquod feel guilty about wasting her time. Disappointing my mum wasnrsquot the only thing I was anxious about. I was worried about my competitors and factors I couldnrsquot control.ldquoBefore the  European Championships, I revealed something to my mum that I had never spoken about before. I broke down and cried for hours expressing how rubbish I felt about myself in both my running and personal le.ldquoRunning had completely taken over and there was nothing positive.ldquoIn my darkest moment, my mum was there for me.ldquoShe was the one who listened for hours. She was the one who hugged me. From that day, my mum and my immediate family have supported me. They have made me realise that there is more to le than running.Susan said that no medal ceremony could compare to seeing her daughter enjoying running again. She said: ldquoMy proudest moment is not Maria winning medals on the world stage, it is probably Maria competing in Glasgow last weekend at the  National Indoor Championships.ldquoFor the first time in years, I saw Maria stand on the start line feeling relaxed and running through the finish line with a smile on her face.ldquoAlong with the support from us as a family and her coach, Jamie Bowie, Maria has turned herself around and is back on track in all areas of her le.

title: little-support-for-idea-of-public-wi-fi-in-town-centres
story: A report to East Lothian Council revealed that moves to increase access to a fast, free public internet service did not win favour with residents.Despite the lack of support, council officers are pushing ahead with their strategy to introduce it across towns in the county.The report into the local authorityrsquos town centre strategy revealed the results of public consultations over a range of actions proposed within the communities.It said: ldquoFor each town centre there was overall support for all the proposed actions, with the exception of the introduction of public Wi-Fi in each town centre, except Haddington which already has public Wi-Fi.In Musselburgh, two-thirds of respondents disagreed with a proposal to introduce it in the town centre, with less than a third agreeing in Tranent. The reaction was similar in Prestonpans and North Berwick, while Dunbar saw the least support, with only one in five backing it.In the majority of towns, the most support was to use statutory action to force private owners of buildings in multiple ownership to have external repairs carried out.Among comments about public Wi-Fi relayed to councillors, one person said: ldquoI really find it surprising that town Wi-Fi has been identied as a possible benefit for the town centre. With excellent G coverage in the town, this would perhaps be more suited at the end of the list of improvements.Another added: ldquoI donrsquot think lack of public Wi-Fi is an issue with G cover widely available.But the council responded: ldquoThe council notes that even with  per centsuperfast broadband coverage [the same goes for G G], affordability will remain a signicant challenge. Consequently, there will still be a requirement for free Wi-Fi across our communities.

title: musselburgh-golf-club-hopes-to-attract-more-women-members
story: Head professional Norman Huguet will lead lessons for women interested in learning to play golf and they will also get the chance to practise their skills on the clubrsquos stand-alone par  beginnersrsquo course.Committee member Linda Smith has organised the initiative, which starts with an open event at the club next Sunday , -pm and -pm.Women can join others also considering taking up golf in a relaxed atmosphere. Everyone is entered into a draw for a free afternoon tea at the club.A block of six lessons for one hour a week then start in April, with clubs provided and trainers allowed. During this time, players have full access to the beginnersrsquo course and all other practice areas.The tuition for a maximum of  women is held on a Tuesday, starting on April , and also on a Wednesday, beginning April , -pm. More classes will be organisedthere is demand.Linda said: ldquoWe want to give people an easy and cheap way to try golf.ldquoPeople might think they need to get golf shoes and equipment. If you decide you want to play, yoursquod get those things over time but, to try golf, you donrsquot need them as we will provide the clubs. We want to take away those barriers.ldquoThere might be a lot of women who would like to try golf but donrsquot know how to go about it.ldquoGroup lessons are a nice way for women to learn and, once the lessons are finished, they have a nice, ready-made group of people that they know in the golf club. So,they go on to join the club, they have people they can play with.ldquoWe will make sure the ladies, during the lessons and after, are integrated into the club. That is something we want to focus on because there is playing on the golf course but there is the golf club which is a dferent thing.ldquoPeople can come into the clubhouse and enjoy the tray bakes and scones, have a coffee and a chat with people, and meet new friends.Linda said the ladiesrsquo section was small with just over  members who play.She added: ldquoDuring the six-week lessons, lady members will help with the lessons and then we can go for a tea or coffee after, so people will be comfortable coming into the clubhouse.ldquoExisting members will also play with the ladies involved in the lessons on the six-hole course.ldquoThe six-hole par- course is great. No one is going to go and watch you playing there. If you miss-hit the ball, which you will when you are learning, there is no one to see you other than other learners.ldquoIt is a non-scary place to learn to play golf.ldquoWe are a really friendly club and people will be made very welcome. If people like it, after the six-week period, they can join the six-hole course or join and be able to play on the championship course.ldquoWe are just hoping that there are enough people out there who want to come and learn.Linda stressed that there were dferent s mapped out on the championship course, including a shorter blue course.Linda said: ldquoThey can play thethey feel is suitable for them.ldquoWe want people to come in and make new friends and use the clubhouse facilities.ldquoIf people want to come and only focus on getting their handicaps down because they are competitive golfers, thatrsquos great as well and there are places for that. Those people donrsquot need these group lessons.Linda added that golf was social, provided exercise in the fresh air and the chance to see wildle and the seasons change.Anyone interested to going along to the open event or to find out more about the package, which costs pound, email sec retary@themusselburghgolf club or call   .

title: brexit-live-prime-minister-loses-commons-vote-on-brexit-proposals
story: Herersquos how events unfolded and the reaction that followed:.pmTory former Brexit minister Steve Baker said he had tabled a ldquoMalthouse Compromise amendment to Wednesdayrsquos motion with Tory colleagues which would seek extension of Article  until May .The motion states: ldquoThat this House notes the steps taken by the Government, the EU and its Member States to minimise any disruption that may occur should the UK leave the EU without an agreed Withdrawal Agreement and proposes that the Government should build on this work as follows:ldquo. conference in  was infamously overshadowed by her inability to speak.She could only get out the first two words of her speech, saying ldquoMr Speaker before coughing and clearing her throat.As Labour
