title: meeting-arranged-in-bid-to-save-cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala
story: Organisers previously announced following their emergency general meetingyesterday eveningthat the gala, which celebrated its th anniversary last year,had been cancelled due to a lack of support.A statement issued on Facebook by Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala committee said:"Following on from the poor attendance at our EGM, it is with deep regret that we must inform you that the  gala is cancelled and future galas are also in jeopardy."We appreciate this will be deeply upsetting for you all to hear."We will look to organise a disco event for the gala children as a small compensation."We tried our best but we can no longer carry on with the number of committee we have."However,after an outpouring of support on Facebook, the committee has decided to review the decision to cancel the gala, although its future is still uncertain.A meeting will be held on Thursdayand all volunteers and potential committee members are encouraged to attend.The meeting takesplace at pm at Port Seton Community Centre cafe, with any queries to be emailedto cpsgala@hotmail

title: developer-looks-to-have-plans-rubber-stamped-for-another-150-houses-in-gullane
story: CALA Homes already has planning permission in principle for the site at Saltcoats Field, on the villagersquos south-eastern edge.Now they will look for the local authority to approve the design, which includes eight three-bedroom apartments and  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached homes.A further  properties are split into  four-bedroom detached villas and  five-bedroom detached villas.Registered Social Landlord People for Places will also provide  affordable properties.That will be made up of eight one-bedroom apartments and a dozen two-bedroom apartments.Ten two-bedroom semi-detached properties will also be created, alongside eight three-bedroom semi-detached homes.Tom Drysdale, chairman of the villagersquos community council, which also covers Dirleton, Aberlady, West Fenton and Drem, said: ldquoPlanning permission in principle was given some time ago.ldquoWhat they have applied for is detailed planning permission.ldquoWe have been looking at that, the community council has been looking at that, and I think we accept there is not much point nit-picking about the development ndash it is going to happen.However, Mr Drysdale felt there were details of the plans that could be improved.The main point was the lack of connectivity between the existing properties in the village and the proposed development site.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThey are big houses, with two cars, and people are simply going to use their cars.ldquoThat was the area we have written in, making those comments, and hope the council will take on board.According to the developer, the proposals will help to meet the growing need for new family homes in the local area, with the properties appealing to a erse range of buyers.The development will also see CALA invest a further pound.m into local infrastructure, including schools, transport, sports pitches, play equipment and rail contributions.Other proposals by CALA include a footway from Gullane to West Fenton, forming part of the Drem-Gullane Core Path link.Derek Lawson, land director with CALA Homes , said: ldquoSaltcoats Field will be a logical follow-on from our current developments in Gullane.ldquoSubject to the planning process, we hope to be in position to commence development in , with homes for sale being available in .

title: labour-and-liberal-democrats-announce-haddington-by-election-candidates
story: The vice-chairman of Ormiston Community Council has been announced as Labourrsquos candidate for the seat vacated by the resignation of Conservative councillor Brian Small last month.Neal Black will represent Labour as they attempt to secure a third seat in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Provost John McMillan and Councillor Shamin Akhtar were elected as Labour councillors in  and will be hoping Mr Black, who works as a learner engagement officer at Edinburgh College, joins them in the ward.Tom Trotteris the other sitting councillor in the ward.Mr Black also represents Ormiston on Farsquoside Area Partnership andhas a long association with Ross High RFC, where he is currently the clubrsquos secretary.He said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that local members have put their faith in me to contest this important election.ldquoI can think of no greater honour than being able to serve the community where I was born and have lived my whole le.ldquoIrsquom looking forward to giving my all to the campaign and talking to as many people as possible over the coming weeks.ldquoMy priority will always be standing up for local interests and defending local services.The current Labour-led administration has made signicant investment in the communities that make up the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Meanwhile, Stuart Crawford will represent the Scottish Liberal Democrats at theby-election, which takes place on May .The count takes placethe following day at Meadowmill, near Tranent, with Haddingtonrsquos Corn Exchange undergoing a major refurbishment.Mr Crawford is a writer and journalist,as well as a trustee of Haddington Garden Trust.He said: ldquoI am really looking forward to being given the chance to represent residents of the Haddington and Lammermuir ward where I live.ldquoIt is important that the concerns of local people in vital local issues such as the pressures increased housing bring on the area are put above party interests.ldquoToo often local peoplesviews are ignored in the interests of party politics.I seek to reverse this.The Scottish Conservatives announced last week that Craig Hoy would be representing them at the by-election.The SNP have not yetannounced a candidate for the by-election.

title: brexit-live-debate-continues-as-mps-prepare-to-vote-on-blocking-no-deal
story: MPs voted by  to  against the PMrsquos Withdrawal Agreement.Members will later vote on whether they are willing for the UK to leave the EU without a deal on March .The EUrsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier this morning insisted there would be no further offer from Brussels, and it was now ldquothe responsibility of the UK to suggest a way forward.Herersquos the latest:The Prime Ministerrsquos deal has failed ndash CorbynIn his concluding remarks, Mr Corbyn said: ldquoThe Prime Ministerrsquos deal has failed, she no longer has the ability to lead, this is a rudderless government in the face of a huge national crisis.He added the Commons needs to listen to the country, including workers and EU nationals who are fearful for their futures, saying of Mrs May: ldquoShe needs now to show leadership.ldquoSo can the Prime Minister tell us exactly what her plan is now Mrs May reiterated votes were planned on a no-deal Brexit and extending Article , adding: ldquoThere will be hard choices for this House but this House will need to determine what its view is on the way forward.She said the Government will continue to work to leave the EU with a ldquogood deal, adding on Mr Corbyn: ldquoHe doesnrsquot agree with Government policy, he doesnrsquot even agree with Labour Party policy.ldquoHe has nothing to offer this country.lsquoI may not have my own voice but I do understand the voice of the countryrsquoMrs May, with her voice still croaky, later said Mr Corbyn repeatedly votes in a way that ldquobrings no-deal closer and said his proposals have been rejected by MPs.She added: ldquoI may not have my own voice but I do understand the voice of the country.ldquoThey want to leave the European Union, end free movement, have our own trade policy, ensure laws are made in this country and judged in our courts.ldquoThatrsquos what the deal delivers, thatrsquos what I continue to work to deliver.ldquoHe used to believe that too, why is he just trying to frustrate it Mr Corbyn, in his reply, said: ldquoI do have sympathy with the Prime Minister on her voice and I hope it soon recovers, I understand how painful this is.May answers Prime Ministerrsquos QuestionsPrime Minister Theresa May has said she will be voting for her motion on a no-deal Brexit.Speaking at PMQs, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn asked how she would vote tonight.She said: ldquoI will be voting for the motion in my name.The Prime Minister earlier defended her deal in the face of a hostile question form Tory backbencher John Baron.Mr Baron pushed Theresa May toback a no-deal Brexit, saying ldquono deal is better than a bad deal.Mrs May agreed no deal was better than a bad deal but insisted her deal was a good deal.She said: ldquoI want to leave the EU with a good deal ndash I believe we have a good deal.Donald Tuskrsquos message to Sophie, European Council President Donald Tusk posted an image on Instagram, said to be from a six-year-old girl named Sophie from London.In the post, Mr Tusk responded: ldquoWe will always be friends, Sophie.Commons must reject no deal ndash MandelsonFormer European trade commissioner, Lord Mandelson, a supporter of the Peoplersquos Vote campaign for a second referendum, said:ldquoRefusing to comply with our responsibilities under international trade law to operate a customs border at any frontier is not a serious or sustainable solution to the problem of a hard border that Brexit ndash of any iety ndash threatens.ldquoTodayrsquos ill thought-out proposals on tarfs and customs illustrate the political, economic and reputational risk that the Governmentrsquos make-it-up-as-we-go-along approach poses to the United Kingdom.ldquoToday the Commons must reject any prospect of a no-deal Brexit and on Thursday they should make sure any extension of the Article  deadline is used to deliver the clarity about Brexit that has been missing from the last two-and-a-half years of debate.SNP bids to take no deal off the tableSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford tweeted an image of an amendment tabled by the party, which adds the option to revoke Article .Delighted to say #@theSNP# will be seeking to take no deal off the table in all circumstances and for the house to recognise we have the option to revoke article . We have a duty to protect Scottish jobs first and foremost. pic CbYHsnIRZLmdash Ian BlackfordMarch , May under fireConservative MP Nick Boles said that Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal had run into dficulties because the Prime Minister is a ldquocontrol freak.Mr Boles told BBC Radio  Live: ldquoI think she is a control freak, bluntly.She doesnrsquot like to allow anybody  to have an input into the formation of the plan.ldquoShe has her very clear red lines.She set them out ages ago.Theyrsquore much too constraining.ldquoWe rushed into them without thinking about them.And she never actually took into account what were the views of the Parliament that she was going to have to get this deal through.ldquoShe hasnrsquot allowed Parliament to explore what alternative compromises we might support.People keep saying there is no majority for any compromise.We donrsquot know that.Wersquove never been allowed to debate and vote on anything other than her deal.Businesses lsquocannot adapt in two weeksrsquoFood and Drink Federation chief executive Ian Wright said:ldquoTodayrsquos announcement on tarfs underlines why the UK is not ready to exit the EU on March .Business cannot adapt to this new regime in just two weeks.ldquoIt is disgraceful that we are only now getting to see these.There must be proper consultation with business before a change of this magnitude is introducedhellipldquoIn a world where it is costly and complex to export finished goods to the EU, and costly and complex to import key ingredients, many food and drink manufacturers who trade with the EU will surely question whether the UK is the right place for them to be.Watch: David Cameron warns no deal would be a lsquodisasterrsquoCall to back lsquoMalthouse CompromisersquoTory former Brexit minister Steve Baker, who has tabled a ldquoMalthouse Compromise amendment to Wednesdayrsquos motion with Tory colleagues which would seek extension of Article  until May , told the Press Association: ldquoToday what I hope will happen is Members of Parliament rally behind this compromise wersquove tabled. Damian Green and Nicky Morgan have both put their names to it as well as myself and Jacob Rees-Mogg from the lsquoLeaversquo side. Today a Labour colleague has agreed to put her name to it as well.ldquoWe think there is a majority for our compromise wersquove tabled ndash it seeks to throw three safety nets around leaving without a withdrawal agreement.Nigel Farage addresses the European ParliamentThe solution to avoid hordes of new Brexit Party MEPs being elected is for the European Council to veto any extension of Article  and ensure we leave on March . pic jYLBAYjPkmdash Nigel FarageMarch , Ending tarfs lsquoa hammer blowrsquoResponding to the Governmentrsquos announcement of a no-deal tarf scheme, TUC general secretary Frances OrsquoGrady said:ldquoEnding tarfs in the event of a no-deal Brexit would be a hammer blow to our manufacturing industries and the communities they support.ldquoThe Government is flying blind, having introduced these plans without any consultation with the workers they will affect. We need a full and proper impact assessment.ldquoMinisters must not show such reckless disregard for peoplersquos jobs.ldquoMPs must vote to take no-deal off the table. And the Prime Minister needs to ditch her destructive red lines, which threaten working peoplersquos jobs and rights.Find a way out of this mess, UK urgedI have always said #Brexit is also a failure of the European Union. The place of the United Kingdom is in the European Union. I am sure a younger generation will one day take another decision and bring Britain back into the European family. #EPlenarymdash Guy VerhofstadtMarch , #Brexit is supposed to be about lsquotaking back controlrsquo. The big slogan of the Brexiteers. Instead, it seems to be spinning lsquoout of controlrsquo. #EPlenarymdash Guy VerhofstadtMarch , My plea to our British friends  Put all your energy into finding a cross-party majority to find a way out of this mess. There is no solutionboth big parties are using this existential issue as a bullet in a weapon against each other. Queen and country needs to come first.mdash Guy VerhofstadtMarch , I hope a no deal is massively rejected today  the UK Parliament position on an extension is known tomorrow. I am against any extension of Article , even for just  hours,it is not based on a clear majority from the House of Commons in favour of something.mdash Guy VerhofstadtMarch , lsquoHe will die not seeing BrexitrsquoSteven Woolfe, MEP for North West England, told the plenary session his uncle was diagnosed with a terminal illness two days ago and he will die this weekend.He said: ldquoHe voted to leavehellip and he will die not seeing Brexit.ldquoHe will die not seeing Brexit because of a political class that despise him and voters in Britain who believe that they are far superior in the way that they think they should control our lives and do not wish to listen to the voters who wanted to get rid of them.Farage: Wersquove had enoughNigel Farage told MEPS: ldquoWe have had enough, we have seen the snarling anger towards our country of Mr Verhofstadt, the bureaucratic intransigence of Mr Barnier, the constant stream of insults that come from Mr Tusk, and we are of one mind: we donrsquot want to be governed by you we want to govern ourselves.Responding to Mr Barnierrsquos estimation of how long negotiations about the EU-UK future relationship could take, he said: ldquoWe donrsquot want to waste four more years of our le, four more years of agony.He called for any extension request from Britain to be vetoed, adding: ldquoWe leave, and both you and we can get on with the rest of our lives. Thatrsquos the only neat solution ahead of us.lsquoPlease make up your mindsrsquoGuy Verhofstadt, the European Parliamentrsquos Brexit co-ordinator, called for the UK to put ldquoqueen and country before party politics, appealing for certainty from the House of Commons.He told MEPs in Strasbourg: ldquoThat is what we need and so I am against every extension, whether an extension of one day, one week, even  hours,itrsquos not based on a clear opinion of the House of Commons for something. That we know what they want.He added: ldquoPlease make up your minds in London, because this uncertainty cannot continue. Not for us, not for Britain and certainly not for our citizens.Watch: Countdown to BrexitlsquoNo hard borderrsquoIrelandrsquos Europe Minister Helen McEntee reiterated that Ireland was not planning for a hard border on the island.She said people in Northern Ireland did not want the Withdrawal Agreement to be cast aside and ministers in the Republic were still not planning to allow the introduction of a physical border on the island.ldquoIt is not something that we as a Government have been planning for, it is not something that we are thinking about and it is not something that we would allow.She said the UK and Ireland collectively had obligations as co-guarantors of the  Good Friday peace agreement to protect the peace process.Flying the flagFormer Ukip leader Nigel Farage attended this morningrsquos plenary session at the European Parliament in Strasbourg.lsquoAppallingrsquo timing for tarfs updateNational Farmersrsquo Union president Minette Batters said it was ldquoappalling the import tarfs which will be applied in the event of no-deal had only been published a fortnight before they could be coming into effect.She welcomed the Governmentrsquos move to treat many agricultural sectors ldquosensitively but raised concerns over sectors which would not have such protection, such as eggs, cereals, fruit and vegetables.ldquoEven those sectors that are treated sensitively will, in most instances, see worrying and large reductions in the tarf rates currently charged on non-EU imports, she said.ldquoWe recognise the importance of ensuring food prices for consumers do not rise in a no-deal Brexit but we are deeply concerned that the approach to tarfs published today will mean a greater reliance on food produced overseas.And she urged MPs and Government to take ldquono-deal off the table and find a workable solution as a matter of urgency.Deal remains lsquoonly available treatyrsquoThe EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, told the European Parliament that the Withdrawal Agreement reached last November ldquois and will remain the only available treaty.In agreeing to draw up documents clarying the terms of the Agreement in Strasbourg on Monday, ldquowe went as far as we possibly could in order to help the UK Government get the support of the House of Commons, said Mr Barnier.The EU has done everything it can to help get the Withdrawal Agreement over the line. The impasse can only be solved in the #UK. Our ldquono-deal preparations are now more important than ever before.mdash Michel BarnierMarch , Mr Barnier said it was now ldquothe responsibility of the UK to suggest a way forward.ldquoThey have to tell us what it is they want for their future relationship, he told the European Parliament.ldquoWhat will their choice be, what will be the line they will take  That is the question we need a clear answer to now. That is the question that has to be answered before a decision on a possible further extension.ldquoWhy would we extend these discussions  The discussion on Article  is done and dusted. We have the Withdrawal Agreement. It is there.ldquoThat is the question asked and we are waiting for an answer to that.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson claimed the EU would come up with a new deal by March .He told LBC Radio: ldquoI covered a lot of EU summits, I have been to a lot of them in my time, I have seen how the EU works.ldquoThe horses always change places in the final furlong, itrsquos always at five minutes to midnight that the real deal is done.ldquoIn Brussels the real fix is always in at the end.Cameron: No deal a disasterDavid Cameron has warned MPs that failing to rule out a no-deal Brexit would be a ldquodisaster for Britain.The former Conservative prime minister said he backed Theresa Mayrsquos attempts to secure a deal despite her second overwhelming defeat in Parliament on Tuesday night.He told Sky News: ldquoIrsquove always supported the Prime Minister in her attempts to have a close partnership deal with Europe and she continues to have my support.ldquoThatrsquos the right thing to do. Obviously what needs to happen next is to rule out no deal, that would be a disaster for our country, and to seek an extension and Irsquom sure thatrsquos whatrsquos going to happen next.Warning over no-deal tarf regimeA new tarf regime on EU products in the case of a no-deal Brexit will act as a ldquosledgehammer to the UK economy, business has warned.The new levies, to be imposed from the day after a March  BrexitMPs vote for a no-deal withdrawal, would force up prices on EU imports including cars and many food products.The unilateral and temporary regime includes levies of .% on European cars and trucks which had previously been free of tarfs, potentially increasing the cost of a typical family hatchback by around pound,. Car parts would face no extra tarfs to avoid disruption to supply chains.But tarfs will be slashed on imports from outside the EU, potentially lowering prices on goods from countries like the USA and China.CBI director-general Carolyn Fairbairn told BBC Radio rsquos Today: ldquoThis tells us everything that is wrong with a no-deal scenario.

title: minister-launches-new-support-plan-for-people-with-learning-disabilities
story: There are , people with learning disabilities in Scotland with only % employed and .% in further education.The Keys to Le framework, launched by the Scottish Government and council umbrella body Cosla, sets out plans to inform more employers about available help, such as a job coach or supported employment.Further plans include encouraging NHS Scotland to employ more people with learning disabilities, ensuring their needs are considered by public transport providers ndash particularly bus companies ndash and are reflected in housing provision decisions.Watch the official launch video: The keys to le  ndash  Unlocking Our Futures ndash https:t.co qKfbtDeLPY#Thekeystole #UnlockingFutures #LearningDisability @scotgov @COSLA @SCLDNewsmdash The keys to leMarch , Speaking at the launch in Edinburgh, Mental Health Minister Clare Haughey said: ldquoWe want Scotland to be an inclusive society in which everyone can play a full role.ldquoWe are absolutely committed to changing attitudes and to showing the positive contributions that people with learning disabilities make.ldquoThe new framework is about children and young people as well as adults, and it is also about the whole le journey, not just health and social care.The three-year implementation plan, an update on the former framework published in , also pledges to build ldquofurther capacity in additional support in schools.The framework, developed with the Scottish Commission on Learning Disabilities and the Scottish Learning Disabilities Observatory, also covers healthy relationships and the right to become a parent.

title: nicola-sturgeon-facing-strong-public-opposition-to-second-scottish-indpendence-referendum
story: The Survation survey for the Scottish Daily Mail found three-fths of Scots were opposed to a re-run of the  vote for at least five years.:Kirsty Blackman: Scotlands best future would be as an independent nation in the EUA fth were against holding one for at least  years and a third were opposed at any time.However, the poll also found relatively strong support for the SNP at Holyrood and predicted the Nationalist and Greens could hold on to their pro-independence majority at the  election.Voting intention for the SNP was  per cent in constituenciesand % on the list , giving a seat projection of , down four.The poll put the Greens on % on the list, giving a seat prediction of  .That would give the two parties  MSPs in total, one more than they won in , although previous predictions of a record surge in Green MSPs have failed to materialise.The prediction is more positive than one generated by a Panelbase poll for the Wings Over Scotland website last week, which pointed to a pro-Union majority after .: Poll blow for Yes movementAfter months of delays caused by uncertainty over Brexit, the First Minister is due to update Holyrood on her plans for a second referendum within weeks.She first called a second referendum in March  because of Brexit, but ldquoreset her plans after the SNP lost a third of its MPs and half a million votes in the  general election.Ms Sturgeon says she has a ldquotriple lock mandate to hold a referendum, but the UK government has said it would refuse to grant Holyrood the requisite powers.Only last week, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said in Glasgow that ldquoof course Theresa May would reject any request for a Section  order transferring such powers.With sections of the Yes movement agitating for a vote in the current Scottish parliament, before Ms Sturgeonrsquos mandate expires, the First Minister is under pressure to act.:Theresa May - The last thing we need is a second Scottish independence referendumShe could press for a second vote in the expectation Mrs May would refuse, then use that refusal as a campaign tool in the next election.However the Survation poll suggests the public would not welcome a fresh push for a vote, and even a tactical request for one could backfire.Opposition partiessaid the public were ldquosick and tired of talk of a second referendum.It found only .% of Scotland wanted a referendum within two years of Brexit taking place .% wanted another vote within two to five years .% in five to ten years .% after  years % never wanted another referendum and .% were undecided.Overall, % did not want an independence referendum before .On a more optimistic note for the SNP, around % were open to a second referendum in the longer-term, after  years.The pol also gave the SNP a healthy lead over its rivals at Holyrood, putting them  points ahead of the Tories in constituencies and  points ahead of them on the list.Constituency voting intention for the  Holyrood election was SNP %, Tory %, Labour %, LibDem % and other %.List voting intention was SNP %, Tory %, Labour %, LibDem %, Green %, Ukip % and other %.Seat predictions were SNP  , Tory  , Labour  , LibDem  , Green  .:Richard Leonard defies majority of Scots to back Brexit over second referendumScottish Tory MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoThis shows a clear majority do not want another referendum any time soon. Scots are sick and tired of Nicola Sturgeonrsquos obsession with a referendum. They deserve a Scottish Government focused on their priorities of health and education.LibDem MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton said: ldquoThe public are sick and tired of the SNP banging on about another independence referendum when they should be fixing the problems in our schools and hospitals.Pamela Nash, chief executive of the anti-independence Scotland in Union group, added: ldquoItrsquos clear that the Nationalistsrsquo attempt to weaponise Brexit in the hope of boosting support for separatism is failing.ldquoThe First minister should take the irresponsible threat of an unwanted second referendum off the table.SNP Depute Leader Keith Brown welcomed the SNPrsquos continued poll leadHe said: ldquoPeople in Scotland are better off with the SNP, which explains this strong poll showing. By contrast, the poll makes dismal reading for the Tories and other Westminster parties who are out of touch and in chaos over Brexit.ldquoSupport for independence is now higher than backing for any kind of Brexit ndash which is why the Tories are running scared of giving people a say on their future because they fear they would lose.ldquoThis poll shows a big majority of people support an independence referendum and no wonder, when the Westminster system is clearly broken.Survation polled  Scottish adults between March  and .

title: nicola-sturgeon-told-she-was-not-bright-enough-to-understand-brexit-deal
story: Scotlands Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell told Westminsters Scottish Affairs Committee the incident happened the last time he and Nicola Sturgeon met Ms May.Mr Russell said: "When I met the Prime Minister with the First Minister to discuss what we thought we might be discussing, and indeed this was what was being said publicly, we would discuss compromise positions."What we actually heard was an explanation of why we simply werent bright enough to understand how good her deal was. Obviously she wasnt either because her deal changed.":Nicola Sturgeon facing strong public opposition to second Scottish indpendence referendumHe added: "I must be honest about this, the Prime Minister is not a person who seems willing to listen to what the devolved administrations want to say, still less to compromise as a result of that."He was giving evidence to the committee in its inquiry into intergovernmental relations between Westminster and Scotland.He said relations were "poor", having been worsened by Brexit, and added that the joint ministerial committee system had "failed", particularly in its supposed oversight role on the Brexit process.:Brexit: Live updates ahead of second meaningful vote on EU withdrawal"Last night, there was of course a briefing for Arlene Forster - there was no briefing for Nicola Sturgeon," he said, referencing last-minute adjustments to the Brexit deal.Mr Russell also questioned the relevance of the position of Scottish Secretary, saying he does not "see what the purpose is"."I dont think the role has anyat all," he added.He said the Scotland Office is "not relevant to what were doing and is an appendage from a past settlement that is no longer necessary".A UK Government spokesman said: "The Secretary of State for Scotland and his office play a vital role in ensuring Scotlands voice is heard at the heart of Whitehall, and that the UK Governments responsibilities and activities in Scotland are fully understood."A UK Government source added: "The Prime Minister has always treated the First Minister with the utmost respect and to suggest otherwise is categorically untrue."

title: snp-msp-christina-mckelvie-elderly-can-be-shining-light-for-the-young
story: SNP MSP Christina McKelvie claimed that the elderly can serve as a "shining light" for younger generations as she launched a conference set up to discuss the challenges an ageing population will bring.People aged  and over are projected to be the fastest growing group in Scotland in the coming decades, with the number projected to increase by  per cent during the next ten years, and by % over the next  years.The Herald and GenAnalytics EngAGE Conference -The Festival of Ageing is being held in association with The Scottish Government to explore how this increasingly elderly population and workforce can be turned into an opportunity for the country as a whole.:Scotland failing to plan properly for ageing populationElderly people still have a valuable part to play, the Minister saidMs McKelvie said there needed to be more positive stereotypes associated with getting older, and that there was too much negativity surrounding the elderly.She said: "We have a big job of work to do to make sure we keep these people healthy, fit engaged and connected - all the things we want to see to happen."The working population is also ageing with more workers over the age of . title: herald-diary-was-theresa-may-angling-for-a-sick-day
story: SOME weather. As reader Alasdair MacKenzie gets in touch to tell us: "It has been quite wet recently, so imagine my surprise this morning to see a council worker watering the plants in Glasgows George Square!"And as a colleague told us: "Its so windy today Ive decided to venture out dressed as a mime artist so I dont look daft when I walk to the shops."ShoppedWE can just imagine the conversation as young Amna was telling her pals on social media about ing to Glasgow. Said Amna: "I was helping out at my dads shop when a customer asked, Oh, arye wan ay the weans  I replied, Aye, just helping out for a wee bit the day. Said the customer, Which wan are ye again  The teacher  Or the wan who never visits "Voice of the peopleSORRY, cant really ignore the Brexit bourach. As Richard Littler comments: "Were not having a second referendum. The will of the people is clear. You cant just keep having referendums until youre happy with the result, says Theresa May as she submits her deal for the third time."And the fact that the Prime Minister was struggling not to lose her voice during her Commonds delivery yesterday did not elicit sympathy from everyone. Said radio presenter Iain Lee: "Theresa May doing her sick voice so she doesnt have to turn up at her work tomorrow. Genius. Weve all done it."AlarmingOUR growing old observation today comes from veteran DJ Tony Blackburn who commented: "You know youre getting older when people call you at pm and askthey woke you up."Took offCHELTENHAM Festival has begun ndash weve already tipped Bellshill in Fridays Gold Cup ndash and we shouldnt forget Scotlands other big connection with the festival which was the late Cumnock-born bookie Freddie Williams who took mammoth bets at the festival without blinking an eye. He was once robbed by armed gunmen as he left the course in his Range Rover, and the next year he arrived by helicopter stating: "If they shoot that down, then good luck to them."Not all of Freddies bookmaking was at the races. In his early days he was at a Cumnock Juniors game where committee members from Cumnocks opponents bet Freddy that they would lose -, which they did. Freddie, though, had shrewdly taken a bundle from locals backing Cumnock to win by at least six.THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : ldquoIf I see a real tragedy in someonersquos hand I keep it from themFood for thoughtTHE things weans say, continued. Says Bob Jamieson: "We took our grandaughters, six and nine, out for the day. As we sat on a bench having a picnic, my we asked, Would Grandad like something to drink  The six-year-old took one look and said, Donrsquot think so Granny, hersquos too busy stuffing his face."JokingTODAYS piece of whimsy comes from a reader who emails: "Tell the punchline first."How do you ruin a joke "Fighting talkBIG birthday yesterday was the th anniversary of the world wide web. Its contribution to our lives was perhaps best summed up by TV station Dave which declared: *The internet is a place where you get to pick fights with strangers and not get thrown out of the pub.*There are millions of dferent websites on the internet but its best to stick to the two or three you know.*You can do anything on the internet, watch opera, find new music, share ideas but its best just to watch gs of dogs.*Always remember that there is a le outside of the internet, but there are people and bees and rain out there so stay safe on the internet.Any other good uses of the internet Camleys Cartoon: Calmac begin business networking cruises to the islands

title: iain-macwhirter-end-of-the-road-for-may-and-perhaps-the-end-of-brexit
story: At any rate, Brexit is now on a kne edge. Assuming Wednesdays vote happens as the Prime Minister promises, and parliament votes against a no deal, that should be the end of their dreams of a ldquoclean break WTO Brexit in two weeks. MPs surely have the power to prevent such an outcome. On Thursday,there hasnt been an election called, MPs should vote also for an extension of Article , and therefore put a brake on the UKs departure from the European Union.Since no one in their right mind believes there is any point in just having another three months of this neurotic indecision, the extension would have to be long enough for the UK to have a general election and come to some consensus on what leaving the EU means. Or whether to leave it at all. That would surely take a year at least. Probably two.Read more:Humiliated Theresa May suffers second Commons defeat as MPs reject Brexit dealThis would mean the UK paying many billions for the privilege of remaining, and having to elect MEPs to the European Parliament in May. That is a legal requirement for member states, and the UK would of course remain a full member of the EU pro tem. Such might be the sense of frustration and disillusion with Brexit, which is demonstrably a result of its advocates being unable to decide what it means, that this extension might turn into something rather more permanent.My own view is that it would probably lead to Britain parking itself in the European Economic Area ndash the so called Norway option. This means the UK would be out of the political institutions of the EU, and the Common Agricultural Policy, but remaining in the European Single Market. This is an unsatisfactory compromise, since the UK loses its voting rights in the Council of Ministers, but it is undoubtedly Brexit. It has been good enough for Norway since , and it may be the only compromise that works.But at this moment, in the backwash of todays astonishing events, rational thinking on Britains future relations with Europe is pretty well impossible. The government cannot govern, parliament cannot choose and Britains political parties are disintegrating. The Tory Party is irrevocably split in all but name, and Labour already has.It was left to the Attorney General, Sir Geoffrey Cox, to drive the last nail into the Prime Ministers coffin with his legal advice on her latest ldquobreakthrough. It was ldquobollocks he said ndash at least that was his Tweeted censure to the Channel  presenter Jon Snow, whod suggested that Sir Geoffrey had been bounced into changing his legal advice on the backstop. In fact, Cox hadnt changed his advice ndash at least not materially. His statement concluded that the UK, even under Mays new deal, could be trapped indefinitely in the customs union backstop, albeit that the risk of this had been reduced. If Brussels behaved in bad faith, Britain could legally cry foul.The Brexit Select Committee tried to make sense of this and ended up resorting to metaphysical speculation about the meaning of ldquobad faith. This is an existential question, essentially, and one that the philosopher Jean Paul Sartre wrestled with all his le. The Brexit Secretary, Stephen Barclay, who is no Sartre, said that Britain could claim bad faiththere was ldquounjustiable delay beyond the agreed timescale for negotiating the future trading relationship. This is supposed to be completed by December . But since no one ever took that date seriously, delaying beyond it could hardly be bad faith.Anyway, by definition the European Union always conducts its negotiations in good faith. If there is still no technical solution to avoiding a hard border in Northern Ireland, how would a delay in the expiry of the backstop be in ldquobad faith. The benchmark is surely the Good Friday Agreement and the British governments commitment to it. She thought she could rely on a legal solution to what is essentially a political problem. Lawyers confine themselves to the very strict meaning of words. The Withdrawal Agreement is legally binding, therefore there was never any way ndash in codicils, declarations or addendums ndash to undo what was already set in legal stone.Her other mistake was to believe that she could keep her party united by placating the hard Brexiteers in Jacob Rees-Moggs European Research Group. That was never going to work because they are essentially incorrigible. Like the followers of the Branch Davidian cult in Waco, Texas, they would happily go up in flames for their beliefs ndash and take the country with them.This is a cathartic moment. The government and parliament has had to face up to its collective inability to resolve the greatest crisis faced by Britain since the Second World War. There is no leadership, no constructive thinking. Just a vacuum where political leadership should be. This would be an ideal moment for a charismatic figure to seize the moment and lead the country out of its confusion and disarray.We dont do charismatic leaders anymore. We do Jeremy Corbyn, who never knowingly rises to an occasion. Or we do Boris Johnson ndash who remains the most likely to succeed Theresa Mayshe falls in the near future. There could be no better illustration of the state we are in, than that choice.

title: nicola-sturgeon-tells-theresa-may-to-use-brexit-delay-for-peoples-vote
story: The First Minister spokes to the Prime Minister this afternoon, shortly before MPs again defeated Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit deal, this time by a margin of  votesThe conversation between the two leaders was revealed by SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford in the Commons chamber immediately after the - result.He also held out the prospect of a second independence referendum.He said: ldquoWe in the Scottish National Party will be prepared to engage in discussion with the government on securing an extension to Article  that is long enough to enable the issue to be put back to the people.ldquoThis afternoon, the First Minister of Scotland told the Prime Minister that in the event of her deal was voted down again, we would engage constructively on sensible proposals.ldquoThese proposals must include another EU referendum.Read more:Humiliated Theresa May suffers second Commons defeat as MPs reject Brexit dealHe said later: "The Prime Minister must finally act in the interests of all four nations of the UK - and not just her own party - by whipping her MPs to vote against a No-Deal Brexit and extend Article ."Giving her MPs a free vote is a disgraceful dereliction of duty, the Prime Minister is clearly in office, but not in power. Extension of Article  is the only way to prevent lasting harm to jobs, living standards and the economy.ldquoScotlands wishes have been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process. We voted to remain in the EU and we must not be dragged out against our will."The case for independence is stronger than ever. If Westminster continues to prove incapable of respecting Scotlands wishes - Scotland will move to protect our own interests."Shadow Scotland Secretary Lesley Laird said: ldquoAfter weeks of running down the clock, Theresa Mayrsquos dreadful deal has been defeated again in the Commons.ldquoThis is a Prime Minister, in office but not in power, who drew needless red lines to appease hardline Brexiteers instead of reaching out in common sense to find common ground.ldquoParliament must now vote to take no deal off the table.Read more:Iain Macwhirter: End of the road for May and perhaps the end of BrexitEdinburgh South Labour MP Ian Murray, an advocate of a Peoplersquos Vote, said: ldquoThis latest humiliating defeat for the Prime Minister shows that she cannot command the support of MPs for her disastrous deal. Itrsquos is disgraceful that she has run down the clock, and with time running out she must now stop playing this reckless game with peoplersquos livelihoods.ldquoIt is vital we seek to extend Article , rule out a calamitous no deal Brexit, and go back to the people with the option to keep the best deal we currently have as a member of the EU.Kerry Buist, Director of Scotland for a Peoplersquos Vote, said:"Yet again, the UK government has been defeated by a huge majority on one of the most important votes ever brought to the House of Commons ndash with  per cent of Scottish MPs rejecting Theresa Mayrsquos bad deal.ldquoWith the days and hours draining away, a further spin of the wheel at Westminster for this dead deal would be utterly pointless.Instead, there is only one way forward ndash to hand the final decision back to the public through a Peoplersquos Vote.ldquoPolls show that people in the rest of the UK have joined with voters in Scotland in not wanting Brexit at all anymore ndash a Peoplersquos Vote is a democratic opportunity for Scotlandrsquos wish to stay in the EU to be respected.Dr Liz Cameron OBE, head of Scottish Chambers of Commerce, said the defeat would add to the ldquogrowing frustration and disappointment felt by businesses around the country.She said: ldquoFirms have shouldered the burden of uncertainty for too long, and tonights result will further impact on our capacity to trade, invest and hire."Business communities have warned time and time again that the UK is not ready to face the consequences of a disorderly exit from the European Union.ldquoYet, we are alarmingly close to departing without a clearly thought-out plan - this must not be allowed to happen on th March, whether by default or design."With only  days to go, politicians on all sides must deliver for business and the economy, and seek to avoid the debilitating consequences that a no-deal outcome would have on the Scottish and UK economy."Scottish LibDem MP Jamie Stone added: ldquoThe Prime Ministerrsquos government has lost its authority and cannot take this forward. Parliament itself now has the job to get No Deal off the table. MPs should extend Article  to allow time to exit from this mess through a Peoplersquos Vote with the option of remaining in the EU.

title: eu-brexit-deal-defeat-significantly-increases-likelihood-of-no-deal
story: Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, said his side had done ldquoall that ispossible to reach an agreement.He insisted the remaining  EU countries will only accept an extension to the Brexit deadlinethere is a ldquocredible justication for doing so.It came after Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit strategy was dealt another devastating blow, with MPs rejected her deal by an overwhelming majority for a second time.The Withdrawal Agreement was defeated by  votes, reduced from the record -vote defeat of the first "meaningful vote" in January.Mr Tusk said he regretted the result, adding: ldquoGiven the additional assurances provided by the EU in December, January and yesterday, it isdficult to see what more we can do.ldquoIf there isa solution to the current impasse it can only be found in London.ldquoThe EU for its part continues to stand by the Withdrawal Agreement, including the backstop, which serves to prevent a hard border in Ireland and preserve the integrity of the single market unless and until alternative arrangements can be found.ldquoWith only  days left to  March, todays vote has signicantly increased the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit.ldquoWe will continue our no-deal preparations and ensure that we will be readysuch a scenario arises.ldquoShould there be a UK reasoned request for an extension, the EU will consider it and decide by unanimity.ldquoThe EU will expect a credible justication for a possible extension and its duration.ldquoThe smooth ing of the EU institutions will need to be ensured.Michel Barnier, the EUrsquos chief negotiator, said it had done everything it could to help get the Withdrawal Agreement over the line.He added: ldquoThe impasse can only be solved in the UK. Our no-deal preparations are now more important than ever before.MPs will vote on whether to rule out a no-deal Brexit tomorrow, but it will still remain the default optionnothing  is put in its place.On Thursday, Westminster is set to vote on whether to ask the EU for an extension to the Article  process ndash pushing back the date of the UKrsquos exit.

title: nicola-sturgeon-the-case-for-scottish-independence-has-never-been-stronger

We now have a Government that has effectively ceased toand a country that remains poised on a clf edge.ldquoWhat is abundantly clear is the UK Government and Parliament have been unable to turn the result of the  referendum into a workable or deliverable plan to leave the EU.She said the Prime Minister should rule out a no-deal Brexit, rather than offer MPs a free vote on it today.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoRuling out no-deal and extending Article  would stop the clock on Brexit and enable another referendum on EU membership to be held. We will support any such referendum, provided it has the option to remain in the EU on the ballot paper.ldquoScotlandrsquos needs and voice have been ignored by the UK Government throughout the Brexit process. title: soap-barons-bid-to-change-islands-way-of-life-is-marked-100-years-on
story: Generations of families have toiled to survive, digging for peat to warm their home, growing what meagre crops could survive the westerly gales and venturing into the roaring seas to fish for herring.Today, islands such as Harris and Lewis are attracting a new generation keen to keep alive traditions, skills and heritage.Yet,  years ago, one incomerrsquos vision of a more modern way of le was fuelling croftersrsquo wrath, and would inadvertently go on to help spark one of the most dramatic upheavals in land ownership of the age.Soap baron Lord Leverhulme arrived on his newly-acquired island of Lewis in  with a vision to propel crofters into a modern world ndash a move that could have seen a precious and fragile way of island le lost forever.Instead, he encountered a strong-willed group of locals who not only wanted to retain their way of le, but to firmly reject his.Later this year Lord Leverhulmersquos botched attempt to sht reluctant islanders into factory jobs ndash sparking a series of bitter land grabs ndash will be remembered during a three-day event on the island.The gathering, in September, will be a chance for islanders to reflect on how close they came to losing their much-loved way of le.The  clash between Lancashire-born soap baron William Hesketh Lever, known for his ldquoforced labour style of management, and the spirited crofters and cotters , pitched th century progression against age-old clan heritage, and it would end in humiliation for the powerful businessman.one of the business worldrsquos most powerful men.ldquoLeverhulme didnrsquot understand what the people wanted and was baffled by the fact they didnrsquot welcome his proposals, says historian Dr Iain Robertson, who explores the episode in his book Landscapes Of Protest In The Scottish Highlands After .In the end, the author adds, rather than unpick what he saw as an outdated way of le by removing crofts in favour of large farms and a modern fish-processing industry, Lord Leverhulme strengthened crofting heritage and even laid the foundations for the pivotal  Land Act and the bedrock for todayrsquos flourishing community right-to-buy land schemes.Lord Leverhulme bought Lewis for pound, in . The semi-retired earl, whose Lever Bros business would go on to form part of giant Unilever, believed the croftersrsquo outmoded way of le needed a visionary like him to revolutionise their communities.He believed a mechanised fishing industry with ice factory, canning and processing plants to feed his UK-wide network of businesses could end the back-breaking task of toiling the land and allow crofts to merge to create single, sprawling farms, boosting his fortunes in the process.ldquoThere was a strong aspect of late Victorian paternalism, of people in poverty and seeing the crofting way of le as a very backward one, adds Mr Robertson.ldquoHe thought these were impoverished people in need of being improved. He didnrsquot see any benefit in crofting and thought what Lewis and Harris needed were more large farms ndash dairy farms in particular ndash and that the people should go to work on the farms or in his fish processing and canning factory.Resistance came, in particular, from young men home from the First World War. Angry at having been initially promised crofts on their , they drew inspiration from the rebellious actions of the Red Clydesiders and organised themselves in military-style groups.Together they marched on crofts that Leverhulmersquos farms had swamped, and carried out a series of land grabs to take them back. Sixteen of Lord Leverhulmersquos  Lewis farms were affected, while his threat to evict the crofters drew little public or political sympathy.ldquoLeverhulme didnrsquot understand the crofts and cotters. They didnrsquot want what he was offering, it was incompatible with their lives, says Mr Robertson, a lecturer at the University of Highlands and Islands.ldquoTherersquos a Gaelic word lsquoduthcashrsquo an amalgam of a sense of heritage and a fundamental belief in common rights. They believed they had a right to inherit land ndash even land they didnrsquot own.A showdown between Lord Leverhulme and croftersrsquo representatives symbolised the yawning gap between the two.The episode is marked today by the Gress Raiders Memorial. Eventually, Lord Leverhulme gave in and switched focus to Harris, where a small fortune was ploughed into creating his modern vision in the fishing port of Obbe ndash hastily renamed Leverburgh. He died in .But the episode prompted Parliament to pass rethink croftersrsquo rights and passed the Land Settlement Scotland Act , which gave government the right to remove land from private ownership and deliver it to the people.Today, it is accompanied by more recent ldquoright to buy legislation that gives communities, such as recently happened in Ulva, the chance to push for landowners to sell land to them.Mr Robertson said: ldquoLeverhulme wanted to completely reorganise how the land was worked on Lewis and Harris. The irony is in many ways, he helped keep it alive.

title: Rosemary Goring  Owners must be compelled to maintain A-listed buildings
story: Its current owner says that the A-listed building is in the process of being repaired after serious water damage in , and that he intends to be living in it by Christmas. Experts, however, take a less optimistic view. One, Susan Hallsworth, believes thatit is not immediately repaired, within a decade it will be beyond saving. Meanwhile, Scottish Borders Council is liaising with the proprietor over the ongoing renovation, and progress thereof.Since the studio has been designated ldquoAt Risk by Historic Environment Scotland , the agency that protects the countryrsquos most historically valuable buildings and properties, we should remain hopeful that, with so many concerned eyes upon it, the studio will be resuscitated in the nick of time. But it is not a certainty, and as many at HES must doubtless feel, it should not have been allowed to fall into such a state in the first place.Lately I have learned a great deal about some of our most priceless properties, be they country houses or castles, sheep pens or coal mines. Ask me the dimensions of the Titan Crane on Clydebank, and I could reel them off. Want to discuss the visionary genius of Charlotte Square in Edinburgh  Irsquoll give it a go. I could even hold forth,required, on the origins and s of corrugated iron, a subject I never realised was so gripping.Read more: MSP call for public inquiry into GSA fireAll this has been for a book called The A-List, about  of the most fascinating properties on this register. One of them, of course, is the Bernat Klein Studio. This elegant, light-filled construction is a delightful example of the modernist work of Wormersley, among whose other structures are the ndash in my opinion ugly ndash football stand for Fairydean FC in Galashiels, to which architects flock from all over the world.Yet while the Klein Studio is of the architectural first-rank, it is also a landmark in the story of the Borders textile industry. A vital part of our industrial legacy, itrsquos a reminder of the boost that Klein, whose tweeds and textiles were picked up by the likes of Chanel and Dior, gave to a region whose mills were almost as dilapidated when he arrived in the s as his studio looks today.The role of HES in preserving our built environment goes on largely unseen and, as the studio shows, being placed on the A-list does not guarantee a buildingrsquos safety. If only. How painful to think that, with the exception of Edinburgh Castle, probably our most famous single building was the Glasgow School of Art. It was A-listed, yet still appears not to have been taken care of properly. That magnicent, inspiring edice ought to have been one of the cornerstones of the A-list, yet now it is a blackened shell.The Governmentrsquos culture committee, tasked with examining the fires that destroyed Charles Rennie Mackintoshrsquos masterpiece, came to the conclusion that there should be a public inquiry. More interestingly, it also advocated that HES be given powers to compel owners or custodians to safeguard celebrated buildings.An inquiry, sadly, wonrsquot bring back the school, but enhancing the authority with which HES can act would be a step in the right direction. At the moment, as with any listed building, custodians of the A-list cannot make structural changes without permission. Itrsquos a protracted and restricting procedure, which probably makes some deeply regret their purchase. Yet while these are necessary and important safeguards, there are none, it seems, that allow HES to step in and prevent ruination. As the examples of the Glasgow School of Art and the Bernat Klein Studio make abundantly plain, this has to change, and fast.If the A-listare deemed a crucial part of the nationrsquos heritage, upkeep ought to be a legal obligation on all caretakers. If this proves unreasonably expensive, then financial assistance should be available. Otherwise who would ever buy somewhere with a roof bigger than a coal shed, or with acres of harling that might not last another winter To be honest, I can think of few things more thrilling than living in a slice of history ndash ideally a Border keep. It would be a heavy responsibility, but also a privilege. Who caresitrsquos impossible to install a power shower or stairlt  Our time on this earth is fleeting. As with the land under our feet, we are not lords and masters of our venerable houses or castles, merely ndash as goes the advert for a pricey range of watches ndash taking care of them for future generations.

title: letters-it-really-is-time-now-for-a-peoples-vote
story: However, one wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that commands the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, now that we know its contents, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: ldquoIf a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a Peoplersquos Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr,Flat ,  Marchmont Road, Edinburgh.THE intransigence of the EU is breathtaking. The way forward must therefore be either no deal now, or a second referendum that respects the result of the first and poses only two questions, Theresa Mays deal or no deal.This might just be a wake up call to the SNP, which needs to be far more aware of the straightjacket EU membership would lead toScotland were independent. Maybe even at this late stage, the SNP will realise we are better together and call off indyref and its awful consequences for Scotland.EU membership is no magic cure, it is simply another headache.Dr Gerald Edwards,Broom Road, Glasgow.Read more: UK Government behaving towards Holyrood asit is a dictatorship, claims RussellAS the Brexit fiasco gets more ridiculous every day, the present focus seems to be entirely on ldquothe backstop. However we seem to be forgetting why the UKvoted to leave Europe. You will recall that big red bus, much was made of the ldquovast sums of money we were handing over to the EU every week, with no mention of what was ed in the way of subsidies to farming and fishing. also capital contributions to a plethora of infrastructure and other projects throughout the UK.I have just received my tax code notication for the next financial year on the back page of this document there is a pie chart showing how my tax contributes to public spending. Under ldquoUK contribution to the EU budget" I am paying pound, or . per cent of the total.This segment of the chart is so small that it appears as virtually a single line.So, for the price of a pizza and a wee glass of wine I am being dragged out of the EU against my will, and my European citizenship gone.At least Irsquove still got my UK citizenship and a passport, unlike our European friends who have lived, worked and paid taxes here for many years and and are now facing distressing uncertainty over their future.The politicians who are allowing this to happen are a disgrace, and will not be forgiven for destroying our economy and the rights we have enjoyed for more than  years.Angus Ferguson, Hutton, Glasgow.THE Prime Ministers own political survival has surely now been dealt irreversible damage and a no- deal Brexit which critically endangers our economy, democracy and international standing, will, almost certainly, be rejected by our parliamentarians.Following a likely extension to Article  this week, the country will remain in a political and constitutional paralysis, with a moribund Prime Minister, and a ided Government and Opposition. The call for a second referendum may now result in even more instability and uncertainty in the country and even invoke civil unrest.David Cameron left Mrs May with the ultimate poisoned chalice. She has failed to negotiate the Brexit maze and deliver a deal that even superficially unites the British people.Her only recourse now is to call a General Election to let the people decide what path to follow democratically. Her resignation will, irrespective of the result, inevitably follow.Owen Kelly, Dunvegan Drive, Stirling.AS the Brexit clock ticks away, hardliners who will not accept any deal other than simply walking away, will likely find the SNP joining them in the voting lobby. Nicola Sturgeon and her colleagues are determined to see nothing good in any plan the UK proposes. Instead of course they seek to link Brexit and independence. Amongst other things, this includes the knowingly misleading assumption that those in the majority who voted to stay in the UK in , and who went on to vote Remain in , would somehow support the SNPrsquos demand to break-up the UK on the promise of a possible future in the EU .As leading figures in the independence movement are falling out amongst themselves over just how much austerity they are willing to accept to join the EU, we must hope that as Ms Sturgeon demands the power to call an independence referendum rerun, she has the good grace to be honest about the very real prospect of separating from the UK only to find we are also left stranded outside of the EU.Keith Howell,White Moss, West Linton, Peeblesshire.

title: disruption-as-storm-gareth-batters-scotland-with-gales-of-up-to-75mph
story: The Met Office has issued two yellow warnings for high winds covering Northern Ireland, Wales, most of England and the west coast of Scotland.Gusts of up to mph were recorded in parts of Scotlandon Tuesday night, while winds of over mph were seen widely across western parts of the UK in the early hours of Wednesday.:Police warning after three die in Ben Nevis avalanche: Nothing is worth risking your le forStorm-force winds created ldquoatrocious conditions for an operation to rescue six crew from a French fishing vessel off Landrsquos End.Two RNLI leboats launched after the alarm was raised at pm on Tuesday, but waves of up to ft meant it was ldquoimpossible for a tow line to be attached and the crew were air-lted off by the Newquay Coastguard Rescue Helicopter.Storm Gareth is expected to continue moving across the country throughout the day, with the worst of the winds occurring in the early hours before gradually easing later on in the afternoon as the storm moves out to the North Sea.#StormGareth will continue to bring severe gales and heavy showers for Wednesday mornings rush hour. Take heed of the warnings and stay #weatheraware pic Lxwboegyemdash Met OfficeMarch , Transport links were at risk of being impacted as the squally weather blows through.Commuters using trains in Wales, Scotland, the north of England and East Anglia were warned that services could be disrupted by high winds during the morning rush hour, with speed restrictions in place across a wide area.Trains between Durham and Newcastle were halted until at least am after overhead electric wires were damaged, impacting LNER, CrossCountry, Northern and Transpennine Express services.Meanwhile, some Virgin Trains service between Glasgow Central and Preston and some trains betweenManchester Piccadilly and London Euston were cancelled.A @MetOffice weather warning for High Winds remains in place until  today. #StormGareth has been active throughout the night. Please check your journey before you travel at https:t.co ZfmOgwp for the latest live info. pic tGLIiKmdash ScotRailMarch , At the Cheltenham Festival, punters were advised that organisers would be holding a precautionary inspection in the morning, although officials later gave the go-ahead after winds eased.Met Office forecaster Alex Burhill said: ldquoWersquove got some very strong winds. The strongest in the morning rush hour are probably going to be around Northern Ireland and also western coastal parts, particularly western Scotland and north-west England.ldquoEastern areas might start getting some very strong winds by that point, but generally across much of the UK itrsquos going to be very windy this morning.:Storm Gareth: mph gales to hit Scotland as Met Office issues warningldquoPeople need to be aware that there could be some travel disruption because there could be delays to things like ferries and aircraft and also bridges may need to be closed.Heavy showers with some thunder were also expected across the northern half of the UK as the storm moves across throughout the day.Dozens of flood alerts have been issued by the Environment Agency in England, including two warnings for the River Ouse at York.####UKweather ndash Storm Gareth is bringing strong winds and heavy rain to many parts of England, Scotland and Wales. Yellow weather warnings are in place and disruption to your train journey is possible. Please check your journey before you travel: https:t.co muRuIjxaOj###mdash National RailMarch , Storm Gareth swept in across Northern Ireland on Tuesday, causing problems on the roads with fallen trees and the cancellation of ferries.Met Eireann, the Irish Meteorological Service, also warned of ldquosevere and damaging gusts as the storm moved over the country.The storm is expected to have moved out into the North Sea by Wednesday evening, although another band of wet and windy weather is expected to arrive from the west on Wednesday night.

title: brexit-five-things-you-need-to-know-about-the-next-48-hours
story: Events over the next two days will have a major impact on how, when - and- the UK leaves the European Union. Here are five things you need to know about the next  hours in Brexit.:Nicola Sturgeon: Tories should hang their heads in shame over Brexit chaos- What is happening in Westminster MPs will vote on today on whether they want to leave the European Union without a Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration - a no-deal Brexit.The Prime Minister warned that a no-deal scenario would be "bleak", with a "signicant economic shock", the loss of security co-operation with Europe and the prospect of the break-up of the UK as support for Scottish independence and a united Ireland could increase.:MPs to vote on blocking no-deal Brexit after Theresa May suffers defeatShould MPs reject that, there will be another vote on whether Parliament wants to seek an extension to Article  - delaying the UKs departure beyond the current March  deadline.But Mrs May stressed that would not resolve the isions in the Commons and could instead hand Brussels the power to set conditions on the kind of Brexit on offer "or even moving to a second referendum".- How could Brexit be delayed and for how long To secure an extension to Article , Mrs May would need the support of the  other EU states. They are likely to agree to an extension as long as there was a prospect of a deal being reached - or a referendum or general election which could change the political landscape at Westminster.European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker said that Brexit should be completed before the European elections which take place between May  and ."If the UK has not left the EU by then, it will be legally required to hold these elections," he said.If a longer extension was sought, that would mean taking part in the elections, something likely to fuel Eurosceptic anger - and potentially see Nigel Farage standing for the new Brexit Party.- Who is supporting an extension Tory former Brexit minister Steve Baker has tabled a "Malthouse Compromise" amendment to Wednesdays motion with Tory colleagues which would seek extension of Article  until May .It was signed by Damian Green, Iain Duncan Smith, Nicky Morgan, Steve Baker, Jacob Rees-Mogg, Simon Hart and the DUPs Nigel Dodds.The amendment calls for the Government to "seek an extension of the Article  process to .pm on May nd , at which point the UK would leave the EU".Thereafter, it says, "in a spirit of co-operation and in order to begin discussions on the Future Relationship, the Government should offer a further set of mutual standstill agreements with the EU and Member States for an agreed period ending no later than th December ".- Will the Prime Minister seek further changes in Brussels Mr Juncker was clear during his meeting with the Prime Minister in Strasbourg that there was no more room for movement."In politics, sometimes you get a second chance. It is what we do with this second chance that counts. Because there will be no third chance," he said.:What amendments have been tabled to no-deal Brexit motion "There will be no further interpretations of the interpretations and no further assurances of the re-assurances."But a European Council summit on March  could give Mrs May one last chance to persuade her fellow leaders face-to-face that she needs extra help to get a deal over the line.- So what happens on March  Impossible to say at this stage. If a deal is somehow reached and legislated for then although the UK will formally leave the EU at pm, very little will change as a transition period will smooth progress to the UKs new future.If there is a delay, the UK will still be in the European Union until the extension period expires.Butthere is a no-deal Brexit, things are a lot more uncertain - the Government has been ramping up preparations to try to prevent shortages of food and medicine amid fears that increased bureaucracy will clog up key ports where goods arrive from the Continent.:Kirsty Blackman: Scotlands best future would be as an independent nation in the EU

title: tariffs-to-be-slashed-on-many-imports-from-outside-the-eu-in-no-deal-brexit
story: But some products coming from the remaining  EU member states which are currently imported free of tarfs will now face levies for the first time.Ministers said that, overall, the changes would represent a ldquomodest liberalisation of the UKrsquos tarf regime.Among the % of imports by value which will be subject to tarfs will be:ndash Beef, lamb, pork and poultry and some dairy products, in order to protect UK farmers and producers from cheap importsndash A number of tarfs on finished vehicles to support the automotive sector, which will not apply to car parts imported from the EU to prevent disruption to supply chainsndash Products including certain ceramics, fertiliser and fuel, where tarfs protect UK producers against unfair practices like dumping and state subsidiesndash Goods including bananas, raw cane sugar and certain kinds of fish, where tarfs are used to permit preferential access to the UK market for developing countries.Proposed tarf rates on a range of food products were announced as a proportion of the so-called ldquomost favoured nationcurrently imposed by the EU on imports from countries which do not have a free trade agreement.Rates include beef , poultry meat , sheep meat , pig meat , butter , Cheddar-like cheese , protected fish and seafood productsand milled and semi-milled products .Tarfs on finished cars and trucks will be set at .%, down from the EU MFN rate of .%, while for finished buses the rate will remain unchanged at .%.Other rates include .% on mineral products, .% on chemical products, . on fertilisers, .% on plastics and rubber, .% on leather and hides, .% on textiles and textile products, .% on stone and cement, .% on ceramics, .% on glass and .% on transport equipment.Trade Policy Minister George Hollingbery said: ldquoOur priority is securing a deal with the EU as this will avoid disruption to our global trading relationships. However we must prepare for all eventualities.ldquoIf we leave without a deal, we will set the majority of our import tarfs to zero, whilst maintaining tarfs for the most sensitive industries.ldquoThis balanced approach will help to support British jobs and avoid potential price spikes that would hit the poorest households the hardest.ldquoIt represents a modest liberalisation of tarfs and we will be monitoring the economy closely as well as consulting with businesses to decide what our tarfs should be after this transitional period.

title: edinburgh-fringe-urges-capital-residents-to-provide-a-room-for-artists-during-2019-festival
story: The Fringe, the worlds biggest cultural festival, will today announce a new partnership with an online booking , TheatreDigsBooker, which the festival hopes will increase the amount of affordable accommodation for artists in the city.The festival, which has noted accommodation as a key issue for artists at the annual event, is now encouraging Edinburgh residents "with a passion for the arts to share their homes with a Fringe participant."The Fringe would like residents to host a performerthey have a spare room and are prepared not to charge the performers the highest rates.A statement said that the Fringe Society are "looking for people who are primarily interested in the experience both they and the artists can share, as opposed to the financialthey can gain.:ARTS NEWS: New director for Scottish Dance Theatre, Kickstarter and the Fringe make deal, Auld Alliance inspires exhibitionTheatreDigsBooker is a website designed specically for artists seeking accommodation across the UK, and was established in .No money is changing hands in the deal, a Fringe spokeswoman said, but the two would be working together to increase the amount of "affordable" accommodation in accommodation and transport providers.The Fringe has also arranged an agreement with Queen Margaret University and Napier University.Both will be providing "affordable rooms specically for artists", the Fringe said.Shona McCarthy, chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society said: "The Fringe Society is committed to making accommodation more affordable for artists at the Fringe, and I Edinburgh to register their property and host an artist in their spare room."Over a third of Edinburgh residents visit the Fringe during August and this is another way they can engage and support the story: Councillors have capped an increase in leisure facility fees at .% after hearing a planned % rise could have a #major impact# on usage and membership numbers.It followed a robust debate at the first ever meeting of Aberdeenshire Council’s new Culture and Sports Sub-Committee which met earlier today .While the committee approved the - Live Le Aberdeenshire pricing policy, not everyone agreed the increase was appropriate.Inverurie councillor Lesley Berry questioned why officers believed it was now acceptable to cut the previously agreed % increase to just .% – claiming the council would be going “in the wrong direction” in terms of income generation by taking such a massive cut.At a time when the council had just gone through a major budget process which will impact on some services, she said: “I am not convinced this is the right way to go. It raises more questions than answers in my opinion.”Officers had argued that continuing with the previously-approved phased increases would be “counter-productive” in terms of encouraging usage and generating income.They also stressed that the proposed .% increase would generate an additional £, against the £, under the initial pricing policy and steer the authority towards recovering some % of its costs.Councillors heard that while the new pricing policy had been successful in meeting income targets in recent years – with facility usage remaining comparable in   to the two preceding years – the latest review had identied a number of key areas where usage trends caused some concern.The current year’s membership sales have “signicantly reduced” by % with the only area of growth being membership types which restrict users to either ‘wet’ or ‘dry’ services for a reduced rate.Membership is also the only area where actual income is predicted to be less than the previous year – down by £,.From a business perspective, Cllr Colin Pike urged caution on the introduction of any increased charges which, he said, people would notice “instantly”.He commented: “We understand that we have to make money but you don’t do that by putting prices up.”Initiatives such as incentivising existing customers to bring along a friend or relative to an activity, he said, would boost user numbers and increase revenue.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The North-east is one of the areas for which Observatree has a shortage of volunteer surveyors.
