title: ‘Hinch are history makers
story: BALLYNAHINCH created more history on Saturday by finishing top of the Ulster Intermediate League and gaining promotion to the Premier League for the first time.An Alex Millar double and an Andrew McIlwaine goal proved enough to ensure lsquoHinch all three points, guaranteeing them a top spot finish with two games remaining.As you would expect from a top of the table clash, both teams were up for the fight and rightly so, with the league title up for grabs.Without a doubt, the two best teams in the league were going at it head-to-head and it wasnrsquot long for inidual battles to start taking shape.Ballynahinch broke the deadlock through Millar after great link-up play with forward partner Jason Campbell.Ballymena deservedly responded with a swt counterattack goal to level the score.The game was end-to-end with both teams looking to go in front, but cometh the hour cometh the man and big game player McIlwaine scored a belter of a goal after Matthew Martinrsquos through ball found him in in space.Ballynahinch pushed for a third goal, but couldnrsquot get break the stern Ballymena stern defence with the score remaining at -. The second half continued to be a feisty affair and a great spectacle for the neutral spectator.With the lowered sun in Ballynahinchrsquos eyes, Ballymena did the smart thing and constantly took the high router, creating numerous scoring opportunities for Ballymena.Unfortunately, for lsquoHinch, their lead didnrsquot last too long as Ballymena bounced back with another great counter-attacking goal to make it -.It was end-to-end stuff, like the first half, the best of the chances falling to Millar, McIlwaine and Campbell only to be denied by the hard-working Ballymena defence and lsquokeeper.Cards were shown to both sides with William Edgar, Andrew Mulholland and Tim Crean doing time on the sideline.Ballymena had decent short corner chances, but were closed down well by Ashley Brown, Rea Coffey and of course Aaron Donnell.lsquoHinch had a few shorts of their own, but couldnrsquot convert. With  minutes remaining on the clock, Ballynahinch patiently played the ball around the back, waiting for an opening.Ashley Brownrsquos pass then found the lurking Stuart Hunter in space. Hunter was able to pick out roaming right back Leslie Harrison, who pulled a perfect pass back into Millar and he made no mistake in finding the net.Ballynahinch could easily have sat back and closed up shop, but they pinned Ballymena into their own half with a series of concerted attacks.Congratulations to everyone involved with the Ballynahinch menrsquos team, especially the supporters who never miss a game.The celebrations were short-lived as Ballynahinch have a huge game this weekend when they face Portrush in Coleraine in the Irish Hockey Challenge semi-final at pm.Ballynahinch: Aaron Donnell, Rea Coffey, Andrew Mulholland , Ashley Brown, Leslie Harrison, Matthew Martin, Stuart Hunter, William Edgar,Tim Crean, Jason Campbell, Alex Millar, Andrew McIlwaine, Luke Curry, Micheal Carney, Josh Higginson, Steven Crean.Joint men of the match: Alex Millar and Rea Coffey.Ballynahinch Ballymena ULSTER INTER LEAGUE.prettyPhoto

title: £2m tidal turbine providing energy spins in to action
story: A poundm tidal turbine currently in Strangford Lough could provide electricity for between - homes, it has been revealed.The Scottish firm behind the innovative Subhub has said that energy produced from the fast-flowing lough could cost as low as p per kWH for local industrial load customers.However, the Subhub is not connected to the local electricity grid and is being tested for its environmental impact and maintenance needs.The distinctive yellow Subhub mdash which is roughly the size of of a bus mdash has been in Castleward Bay for the last six weeks.Easily seen from Portaferry, it was towed from Belfast Harbour and fixed into position within  hours on January .Jeremy Smith, managing director of QED Naval, said that Strangford Lough was chosen over the Orkneys for the Subhubrsquos final commissioning before being made available for the global market.Mr Smith explained: ldquoThe Subhub is a foundation structure for tidal turbines and provides a means of transporting and fixing tidal turbines to the sea bed.ldquoWe want to prove the environmental credentials of Subhub after developing it since .ldquoWe selected Strangford Lough as the commissioning site specically as it had the iants of conditions that Orkney hadnrsquot. The Orkneys was problematic as itrsquos a long way away. It would also have costed a lot of money to tow up into position but also the conditions up there were not what was needed.ldquoOur Strangford site has fast-flowing water, a pure rock sea bed and is a stonersquos throw from the shoreline. Itrsquos very accessible and also happens to be a beautul part of the world.Mr Smith said that the Subhub would be in the lough for the next three months at least as it was being assessed.ldquoWe are working with Cuan Marine Services who provides us with daily reports really to see what the environmental impact is for marine mammals.He said that QED Naval had developed Subhub which was less expensive to make, to move into position and to decommission, than other tidal wave s.He believes that some industrial load customers could avail from its electricity.ldquoIndustrial load customers could be paying between -p per kWH now, added Mr Smith.ldquoIf we could work with local industrial customers to get power purchase agreements, there is potential for us to cut their fuel bills for heating water to less p per kWh.QED Naval has worked in collaboration with the Centre for Advanced Sustainability at Queenrsquos University on the project.The Subhub spent last year being equipped at Cimpina Engineering in Belfast before being moved to Strangford Lough.This is the second tidal power development in Strangford Lough.The worldrsquos first commercial-scale tidal turbine was commissioned on the lough in July, .The .MW SeaGen project developed by Marine Current Turbines comprised two KW turbines and represented a poundm investment. It has since been decommissioned..prettyPhoto

title: Clonduff are All Ireland champions
story: IT WAS a pillar-to-post victory for Clonduff as they grabbed their first AIB All-Ireland Intermediate Club Camogie title at Croke Park on Sunday, but they were pushed all the way by a youthful Gailltiacuter side.Victorious skipper Paula Gribben was the driving force for the Down side with an all-action display, but had more than ample support from the Carr sisters, Sara-Louise and Fionnuala, who scored four points between them on the th anniversary of their father Ross securing his second All-Ireland Senior football title with Down.The big news before throw-in was that dual All-Ireland winner with Waterford, three-time Soaring Star and seven-time All-Ireland Poc Fada champion Trish Jackman, who is a lecturer in the University of Lincoln, was making her first start since Gailltiacuterrsquos All-Ireland semi-final loss to Eglish two years ago.Jackman was sited at full-forward, but could only look on as Clonduff flew out of the traps and twice built up a five-point advantage.That included the first five scores of the game, Gribben converting three frees and a , and Sara-Louise Carr firing over a brilliant point.Annie Fitzgerald would play a key role in dragging Gailltiacuter back into proceedings, getting her sidersquos opening score from play and converting a free immediately after being fouled.Sara-Louise Carr stretched Clonduffrsquos advantage once more with a neat point and that score was quickly followed by a monstrous one from the middle of the field by Fionnuala to make it -.But Gailltiacuter were settling into the game and getting a realwhen running at the heart of the Clonduff defence, with Fitzgerald in particular a constant thorn, while Aacuteine Lyng and Emma Roche began to exert a greater influence in deeper positions to provide more of a  for the pacy attackers.They struck the last three points of the half via the sticks of Clodagh Carroll and Fitzgerald and a free to trail - to - at the interval.They might have gone in ahead though, as Fitzgerald was put through by Jackman in injury time, only for Clare Gilligan to first make a brilliant hook and then foul the marauding centre forward. Lyng took the resultant penalty, but it was saved by a combination of Karen Haughey and then Sara-Louise Carr in the last action of the half.The second period followed a similar trend as Clonduff dominated the third quarter, Sara-Louise Carr banging over her third point and Gribben, who was picking up so much ball around the middle third, putting four between them once more from a placed ball.Gailltiacuter took over from then on, but will rue near-misses with shots for goal from Jackman, Carroll and Fitzgerald.The latter reduced the margin to the minimum with three scores, the third from play in the th minute after wonderful work by Kate Lynch, but crucially Gribben responded with a fantastic conversion of a free outside the  after a heavy challenge on Megan OrsquoReilly.Lyng made it a one-point game once more from a free, but Clonduff defended resolutely to hold out.Clonduff: K Haughey, N OrsquoHagan, J Boden, S Murphy, C McGilligan, E Rafferty, F Carr , B Fitzpatrick, C Cowan, C Fitzpatrick, SL Carr , P Gribben , O Gribben, K McGilligan. Subs: M OrsquoReilly for Rafferty, R Mulholland for C Fitzpatrick.Gailltir: C Jackman, E Mahony, M Heffernan, C Dunne, L Sheridan, E Roche, H Flynn, S Fitzgerald, A Lyng , C Carroll , Annie Fitzgerald , K Lynch, A Corcoran, T Jackman, E Walsh. Subs: C OrsquoSulivan for Walsh, Aoe Fitzgerald for Corcoran, Corcoran for Carroll.Clonduff -Gailltiacuter -ALL-IRELAND CLUB FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Down High out of luck in decider
story: DOWN High were desperately out of luck at Royal School, Dungannon, on Saturday morning when they lost out in the Danske Bank Medallion Bowl finalDown High started the stronger of the two sides and within  minutes had a successful Joseph Dooley penalty under their belts.This came after Omagh strayed offside, attempting to contain sustained Down High pressure. However, as the first half progressed the balance of play swung in favour of the Tyrone team who managed a two unconverted tries before the interval.Both of these tries came from consistent pressure in the close quarters from the powerful Omagh pack. Omagh went into half-time with a - lead.Down were first to score in the second half when Dooley added another penalty to his tally, bringing the margin down to four points.However, again, momentum turned and off the back of well executed blindside attack, Omagh extended their lead to - with a converted try.To their credit, the young Down High squad didnrsquot in any sense give up. With  minutes left in the tie and after some superb continuity work by the Down pack, David Corrie supplied Rory Wilson with a perfectly directed pass that saw the winger e over in the corner for five points.With  minutes left on the clock, Down hunted the converted try that would give them the victory, but despite plenty of play deep in Omagh territory and a number of promising attacks, they were unable to deliver the critical blow required before the referee sounded the full time whistle to this tight encounter.Other results: U-A lost - to RS Dungannon, U-B defeated Wellington -, U- defeated RS Dungannon - and Omagh Academy -.Down High Omagh Academy DANSKE BANK MEDALLION BOWL.prettyPhoto

title: Ear%2C nose and throat to make way for new cataract surgery
story: PLANS for a specialist regional centre of excellence for cataract surgery at the Downe Hospital have come at a price.Health chiefs have confirmed this week that ear, nose and throat day surgery sessions currently provided in Downpatrick are relocating to Lisburnrsquos Lagan Valley Hospital to make way for the new cataract service which could be operational in the near future.While the South Eastern Trust has confirmed that ENT day surgery service is moving to Lisburn, the organisation is insisting there are no plans to reduce the number of ear, nose and throat clinics delivered at the Downe, with the current number set to increase.Last year, the Department of Health revealed that the Downpatrick hospital would be at the forefront of a new model of care with the Downe set to provide a new consultant-led, prototype cataract service for patients from across a wide area.The new service is designed to signicantly reduce surgery waiting lists, with the elective care centre providing routine day surgery procedures at an enhanced outpatient department at the Downe.The centre will be evaluated on performance, quality, service user and staff experience, productivity and overall value for money.While delighted with this, former South Down MP Margaret Ritchie is concerned that ENT day surgery is moving to Lisburnrsquos Lagan Valley and is arguing there is a need for the retention of this specialist service locally.ldquoThis particular service is well received and utilised in the Downe, said Miss Ritchie.As part of the regionalisation of clinics and services, the Downpatrick hospital will soon provide a regional opthalmology service which involves cataract surgery and is very welcome.ldquoAs part of this regionalisation of services, it is important that those services such as ENT surgical clinics, which have been in existence for some time, continue to remain in the hospital. In fact, the South Eastern Trust has been concentrating for some time on trying to find suitable day surgical services which could be delivered in Downpatrick.Miss Ritchie said it appears ldquovery short sighted to relocate services from the Downe to other hospitals, suggesting the bedding down of eye surgery will result in the increased requirement for theatre access for ENT and other services.She added: ldquoAs the Downe has high level computerised technology theatres, it is important that full use is made of them to ensure continued local accessibility to day surgery services at the point of delivery.ldquoI have already written to the Trust urging that ENT surgical clinics are retained in the Downe Hospital.Also this week, Miss Ritchie has issued a fresh call for a permanent MRI scanner to be installed in Downpatrick.She said that for a number of years the local community has been involved in trying to secure a permanent scanner which health chiefs agree is a necessity.She added: ldquoI understand that the permanent facility is subject to a business case which needs a Minister in place to approve. Whilst the devolved institutions remain in cold storage, the approval of such a facility will probably take some time.ldquoIn the meantime, a mobile scanner has been located at the Downe for a limited period to deal with a current overburdened service at the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald. I hope this unit can remain in place until the business case for the permanent scanner has been approved.A South Eastern Trust spokeswoman has confirmed that there are no plans to reduce the number of ENT sessions delivered at the Downpatrick hospital.She added: ldquoThe Trust is planning to increase ENT clinics at the Downe and to relocate an ENT day surgery session from Downpatrick to the Lagan Valley Hospital to facilitate the cataract elective care centre prototype work..prettyPhoto

title: Food firm to create 125 jobs with £17m investment
story: DOWNPATRICK is in line for a major jobs boost.Finnebrogue Artisan has this week unveiled plans to create  new jobs as part of a poundm investment in an ultra-modern nitrite-free bacon facility.The news comes just weeks after the firm unveiled details of a poundm investment in a new vegan and vegetarian factory to support  jobs.Already one of the districtrsquos leading employers and widely regarded as one of Northern Irelandrsquos most innovative food producers, Finnebrogue Artisanrsquos latest investment is being supported by Invest NI.The new manufacturing facility is for the production of the companyrsquos nitrite-free bacon, hailed by many experts as a breakthrough in the food processing sector when it was unveiled to wide acclaim in January last year.The Naked Bacon range is now widely available in leading supermarkets across the UK, with Invest NI offering the Downpatrick company over pound.m of support towards the capital investment in the new nitrate-free bacon facility.The  new posts are expected to be created by , supporting  posts already in place at the ultra-modern plant outside Downpatrick.Finnebrogue chairman Denis Lynn says it has been known for decades that nitrites used in curing meat can cause cancer.ldquoThatrsquos why, despite being the UKrsquos leading top tier sausage maker, we refused to make a single rasher of bacon until we could figure out a way to make it better and safer, he continued.ldquoWe always set out to make food the best it can be, without being bound by the way it has always been done. And so, after much research, we discovered a process that uses fruit and spice extracts to flavour the pork, keep it pink and retain shelf le.Mr Lynn added: ldquoWe are using this technology in our Naked Bacon and wersquove had a great response from both retailers and consumers.Invest NIrsquos executive director of business and sector development, Brian Dolaghan, said Northern Irelandrsquos reputation as a region that produced ldquoinnovative, quality food had been enhanced by the innovation and development of nitrite-free bacon by Finnebrogue.ldquoThe product has been welcomed by top food scientists as a signicant advancement in food safety and has already found a market among health conscious consumers, he continued.ldquoAgri-food is one of our priority sectors and it is great to see the new facility operational and producing this cutting-edge product. Our support is ensuring Finnebrogue is able to capitalise on its innovation and realise growth.Mr Dolaghan added: ldquoThe local economy will also benefit from this fantastic food innovation as the  new jobs will deliver over poundm to the economy each year in salaries.The Downpatrick firm also produces and sells The Good Little Company range of healthy sausages and recently opened a vegetarian factory producing innovative, meat-free meal options.Finnebrogue Artisan is regarded as one of the fastest growing food manufacturers in the UK with its turnover increasing from poundm to over poundm per year over the past ten years.The company says that following Invest NIrsquos support, it anticipates that sales of Naked Bacon will add poundm to its turnover by .Invest NI has offered Finnebrogue Artisan an employment grant of pound, and a capital grant of pound, to boost its latest investment programme..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C February 27%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash The Department of the Environmentrsquos Roads Division warned yesterday that staff cutbacks could substantially delay two new major schemes in Downpatrick.Divisional Roads boss Mr J D Kirk admitted that several proposed schemes will be hit, including a car park in the Irish Street Market Street area of Downpatrick and a realignment programme for Saul Street and Scotch Street.Mr Kirk claims that he does not have a large enough supervisory staff to carry out work which has been programmed.Mr Kirk stressed that the cutbacks could not have come at a worse time when the Roads Service is under heavy pressure to complete schemes and also to start several others which are in the pipeline.He explained that the long-awaited new pound, car park for Downpatrick now seemed certain to run into further dficulties and that the realignment programme will suffer from the staff shortages.Downpatrick councillors have hit out at the threat of further delays to local schemes. Cllr George Flinn was particularly outraged. ldquoI am amazed to hear of this and deplore any delays in schemes that should have been completed a long time ago., he said.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Ballynahinch Chamber of Commerce are to continue their efforts to have the townrsquos police station opened full time.The Chamberrsquos executive committee, who met recently, discussed an acknowledgment from RUC headquarters, saying they would look at the possibility. The committee agreed to pursue the matter.At the same meeting members expressed pleasure at the announcement that the Department of the Environment intend spending pound, on improved lighting in the town, but they showed deep concern over the Department of Educationrsquos decision not to provide a swimming pool for the town.Already local schools are up in arms about the decision, as the pool would have provided swimming facilities for over , pupils. However, the Chamber intend to follow it up and are to invite representatives of the ious schools to meet them in April to discuss the situation.DRUMAGHLIS mdash The future of Drumaghlis Primary School is causing problems for the South Eastern Education and Library Board. The Department of Education havenrsquot yet disclosed their intentions, in spite of having been told of strong feeling that it should not be closed.Mrs Ethel Smyth, a member of the maintained schools committee, was irritated by the lack of information from the Department.She said the school had  pupils and assumed maintained status in January of last year. In June members of the committee requested financial help from the Department to modernise the toilets abed were concerned to receive a letter asking their views on the schoolrsquos future.Mrs Smyth said that parents of children attending the school were totally opposed to its closure in view of the long distances by the pupils would have to travel to other schools.KILLYLEAGH mdash An emergency meeting of Killyleagh Young Farmersrsquo Club was held in the townrsquos Masonic hall this week.Twenty-six people were present, including a representative from YFC headquarters. The meeting was chaired by Mr Denis McAuley, from Downpatrick YFC. A y and informative discussion took place during which many helpful points were raised regarding the future of the club.The election of the senior officials and office bearers was completed and all posts were filled. Finally, after the interest shown in the club at the emergency meeting, members stressed that the look forward to a very successful year.STRANGFORD mdash The Department of Environment has proposed that crossing fares for the Strangford ferry should be increased.Ards Borough councillors were told this week that the Downpatrick DoE office, which administers the ferry, has recommended that fees should be increased in line with the rising costs of operating the service.If a new increase is implemented, it will mean that a passenger will pay p to use the ferry between Strangford and Portaferry instead of the present rate of p. The new cost for a motorcycle will be p instead of p car fares will go up to p from p vehicles up to two tons will pay pound mdash an increase of p and vehicles up to five tons will pay pound instead of pound..A letter to the council said that the Department believed that it was better to introduce ldquomodest annual increases rather than larger ones every few years. Councillors decided to consider the matter fully and to write to the Department expressing their views.NEWCASTLE mdash Mr Dermot Patrick Herlighy , of Clontarf, Dublin, died suddenly at Royal County Down Golf Club on Saturday morning from a coronary attack.The deceased was a member of the Irish international golfing party who were practising on the course at the weekend.BALLYGOWAN mdash Residents in Ballygowan have called for the removal of a water booster generator near the town which has created a traffic hazard for more than a year.The problem relates to huge booster which was erected on a bend on the Carrickmannon Road to increase pressure in the water supply for parts of the area.Local councillor Jim McBriar says he wants the generator removed before it causes a serious accident.ldquoThis booster may be serving a need until a proper replacement is provided, but local people want it removed because it is hazardous, he said.A spokesman for the Water Service said they had very little power in the situation. ldquoWe asked the Northern Ireland Electricity Service some time ago to provide a temporary booster until the water situation was sorted out, he said.ldquoHowever, it has been there for more than  months now and it should it up to them to remove it.Initially, the generator was only meant to operate temporarily, but now local people fear that it may stay there indefinitely.KILLINCHY mdash Mr Tom Pendry, the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State in the Northern Ireland Office with responsibility for Agriculture, visited Cuan Sea Fisheries Ltd, near Killinchy, on Saturday.Dr Jasper Parsons, general manager of Cuan Sea Fisheries, met Mr Pendry, and led him on a conducted tour of the oyster farm.Cuan Sea Fisheries, which employs a staff of eight, was established six years ago on the shores of Strangford Lough. Pacic oysters, imported as seed from hatcheries in England, are reared in the lough on trays and in nets.Interest in oyster farming grew in Northern Ireland in  after successful experimental work by the Department of Agriculturersquos Fisheries Division which showed that the Pacic oyster could thrive in Strangford Lough.CARRYDUFF mdash Plans are being drawn up for a new pedestrian crossing scheme in Carryduff.Residents in the area have been pressing for a controlled crossing system with traffic lights for some time and at last it looks s through work is in the pipeline.Members of Castlereagh Borough Council heard that there are plans for crossings on the Ballynahinch Road, Church Street and the Hillsborough Road.BALLYKINLAR mdash Downpatrick firemen answered a call to a gorse fire at Ballykinlar Camp on Saturday. Approximately six acres of gorse had been extinguished on arrival.CASTLEWELLAN mdash The game fishing season begins shortly, but anglers wishing to use Castlewellan Lake will have to wait another month.Although the Department of Agriculture have  game and mixed fisheries to offer anglers, , including Castlewellan, will not open until April  to facilitate spring stocking.Already an experiment to test ious methods of stocking is being conducted in Castlewellan Lake. This involves the tagging of a large number of fish.SPA mdash A capacity audience filled Ballynahinch High Schoolrsquos assembly hall to see Spa Young Farmersrsquo Clubrsquos presentation of George Shielsrsquo evergreen comedy play, The New Gossoon.The cast did the author and themselves proud with their presentation. So well received was the play that inquiries are already being made with regard to taking it on a short local tour. The play was produced by Mr Cecil Orr, the club president..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C March 6%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Work is to begin in two monthsrsquo time on three factories at the Flying Horse estate on the outskirts of Downpatrick ndash and they are expected to be ready for tenancy at the end of the year.The factories are being provided by LEDU and are timed to coincide with a massive LEDU drive in Downpatrick aimed at finding new businesses and enterprises in the locality. There will be two small  sq metre factories and a larger  sq metre factory, capable of producing at least  new jobs.News of the development was announced this week by LEDU manager Ton Short, who said that tender documents were already being drawn up.Mr Short promised thatthese factories can be filled, his organisation will push for more as soon as possible.ldquoWe are trying to generate interest in the Down area for this type of venture because although we believe there is potential in the Downpatrick area, enquiries from there have always been poor, he said.ldquoWe will of course accept any suitable tenant from outside the area, but we are hoping to see the establishment of locally-based concerns by local people.Down Council chairman Eddie McGrady described his reaction to the news as one of satisfaction and said it was the culmination of a concerted effort to have smaller units available for occupation in Downpatrick.EDENDARRIFF mdash A dairy firmrsquos plans to build a store at Edendarrf, outside Ballynahinch, have been knocked on the lead by local planners.The firm, which supplies dairy foodstuffs all over Northern Ireland, could pack up and move to Portadown, taking with it eight jobs which are currently available to local men.Express DairyLtd are currently operating on a temporary basis in a yard at the rear of the Travellersrsquo Friend, but their plans for a cold store, canopy, toilet and plant room have been turned down.The planners say the commercial development proposed would be out of place in the rural scene andit was allowed it would be a precedent for further commercial development on similar lines in the open country.Local councillor Patrick Forde does not agree with the plannersrsquo reasoning. He told a meeting of Down councillors this week that the development would take place in an existing yard behind a high wall.ldquoIf this is turned down the firm will be going to Portadown and the jobs will be lost, he said.Drumaness councillor Jim Magee pointed out that there was already commercial development in the area.NEWCASTLE mdash The press officer for the local branch of the Approved Driving Instructors Association has supported moves to introduce compulsory wearing of seat belts to the province.Mr Sean Boden, from Newcastle, has supported the moves following a referendum of all local branches of the Association and an official statement on the subject has been issued.It states: ldquoThe Approved Driving Instructors Association of Northern Ireland wishes it to be known that its membership strongly advocate the wearing of seat belts by drivers and front seat passengers.ldquoWith only minor reservations regarding the categories under consideration for exemption, this Association is in favour of seat belt legislation.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh, Shrigley and District Town Committee held two meetings last month and on both occasions ious problems affecting the area were discussed.At the first meeting the new chairman, Mr W Maguire, received unanimous support for a vote of thanks to two outgoing officers, Col Rowan-Hamilton and Mr M Porter, who had both served for seven years.It was stated that street lighting in Irish Street was almost non-existent and members said the street constituted a serious hazard, particularly to old people.Concern was also expressed about the dangerous state of the footpaths between Killyleagh and Shrigley and at Cuan Beach. It was also noted that a telephone box at the Toye had vanished after being damaged in an accident.PORTAFERRY mdash Moves by the Department of the Environment to increase fares for the Strangford Ferry now seem certain to come against a wall of fierce protest.Battle lines are already being drawn by ious local bodies who are angry at the DoE Road Servicersquos recent proposals to put up the ferry fares in a bid to combat rising costs of operating the service.Both Ards Borough Council and Down Council have been informed of the proposals and have hit out at the Road Servicersquos intentions.The announcement has also met a stormy reaction from the Portaferry and District Development Association.The Assocation has adamantly recommended that the proposals should be rejected and has called for an emergency meeting with all interested parties in St Columbarsquos High School later this week.A spokesman for the Association stressed that local people on both sides of the lough have been enraged by the proposals and that there is a possibility that support may be called upon from South Down MP Enoch Powell, North Down MP Jim Kilfedder and Lord Dunleath, the Ballywalter peer.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Ballynahinch piper Ian Jess added another trophy to his ever increasing collection when he pipped current All-Ireland champion Tom Anderson, from Dublin, in a play-off for the solo championship at Dungannon on Saturday.Ian, the current Ulster senior solo champion, finished level with his All-Ireland champion counterpart, but took the title on the play-off march, strathspey and reel programme.And Ian wasnrsquot the only Ballynahinch piper to triumph at the competition. Four other young pipers finished in the prize list, with one, Paul Herron, winning outright in his section.Richard Parkes, from Field Marshal Montgomery, the Carryduff-based band, was third in the strathspey and reel section. A newcomer to the ranks, he also won the open jig competition.COMBER mdash Comber Town Committee has decided to draw up a petition in a bid to pressurise the GPO to improve postal facilities in the town.The committee is calling on the support of all local people and arrangements are being made for members to be stationed around the town with petition forms on a publicised day in the near future.The controversy began when the old sub-office closed down and a new one opened in Bridge Street. The new post office shared by a fancy goods and confectionary shop and many people in Comber feel that the town is large enough to have a proper office.People have complained that they have trouble getting into the post office, especially on busy days when the front area is blocked by customers buying goods at the confectionary store.KILLINCHY mdash The Bishop Hall was filled to capacity on Friday when Killinchy Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church held a social evening.The highlight of the evening was Killinchy Drama Grouprsquos comedy, lsquoStymiedrsquo. The Drama Group is only in its second year and it to their credit that the acting was of such a high standard. The cast was Richard Stewart, Alberta McKeown, Angela Kenmore, Brian Price, Ernest Kenmore, Sylvia Cassidy and Margaret Gibson.CROSSGAR mdash The prize for the best puppy at the recent Ulster Cocker Club show in Belfast was awarded to Miss Madam, owned by Mrs A Spratt, of Church Road, Crossgar.RACING mdash The Ulster Harp National run at Downpatrick last Wednesday was won by an outsider, Miss Leap. The National was the highlight of the well-attended meeting and it gave trainer Sye Kirk and rider Tommy Finn their biggest success to date..prettyPhoto

title: Gates swing open at new play parks
story: TWO childrenrsquos play parks were opened in Saintfield and Killyleagh last week.They are part of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Be Active campaign which was launched last year.The parks were part funded by the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership, which is supported by the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand the EU, with Newry, Mourne and Down Council contributing towardS the investment.Lislane play park in Saintfield was officially opened by council chairman Mark Murnin with support from pupils of Academy Primary School and St Maryrsquos Primary School in the town, who were involved in the consultation process.The children were delighted to try out the new equipment that ranges from zip lines to a rota-web climber and a hot shot target wall.The second play park to be opened was at the Bridge Centre in Killyleagh where Cllr Murnin was joined by children from Killyleagh Integrated Primary School and St Maryrsquos Primary School.The pupils enjoyed playing on the Rock lsquonrsquo Bowl, Double Zig-Zag Twister, and the Playtronic Daisy Chain Reactions game. They also enjoyed signing their names using the free standing lsquoSign Your Namersquo play .  Cllr Murnin said: ldquoI am delighted to officially open both play parks. These facilities will no doubt be incredibly beneficial to the members of the community, giving children a safe place to play. It also highlights the councilrsquos commitment in delivering on its play strategy and we will continue to improve play facilities throughout the district.ldquoThe play parks are fantastic assets to both Saintfield and Killyleagh and are already being well used by the children. It is great to see their communities working together.He added: ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down District strongly believe in the importance of play in a childrsquos physical and social development, and it is an integral part of growing up, we hope everyone enjoys using these facilities.The development of the play facilities will see children and young people across the district benefit from the latest state of the art equipment.Cllr Roisin Mulgrew, Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership chairperson, said: ldquoThis partnership project between Newry, Mourne and Down District Council, the Rural Development Partnership and our local rural communities is delivering real impact on the ground, producing state of the art play parks in many areas.lsquoOur children and young people are the ultimate winners who will benefit from these fantastic facilities.Jerome Burns, DAERA representative, added: ldquoThe Department is delighted to be a partner in this project which has produced such a signicant impact across the district.ldquoCouncil funding matched with EU funding through the Rural Development Fund has maximised the overall impact.ldquoThe positive benefits of play for children is matched by the positive impacts on the whole community including improved access to facilities, health and well-being and community cohesion..prettyPhoto

title: June’s horse assisted work recognised
story: A COMBER womanrsquos belief in the power of horses to help people connect better with others has led to her being nominated for a major national award.June Burgess has been shortlisted for a prestigious  Soldiering On award.Junersquos horse-assisted workshops help veteran and existing members of the Armed Forces suffering with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder.The former international three-day event rider hosts a range of workshops at her Horses for People stables on the Killinchy Road.The  year-old will find out at a gala dinner in London on April  whether she has won the Animal Partnership award.June says she has had such a great experience already from just being an award finalist that winning would be icing on the cake.ldquoI had no idea I had been nominated but itrsquos a real honour, she said. ldquoI really didnrsquot expect anything more so it was a total surprise when I made the final as I attended a reception in the House of Lords which was very exciting.ldquoTherersquos been such a big thing made about being a finalist that it really doesnrsquot matter whether I win or not.The Soldering On Awards aim to honour all of the armed services community or those who work to support the community.June has spent a letime devoted to horses, from competing in over  competitions to just riding for the love of it.All but one of her horses are former competitors in the Irish, UK and European circuit.Part of Junersquos reason to develop her horse-assisted workshops was to give them a special role in their retirement.ldquoMy old boys have done their job all their lives so I think they deserve a home for le, she said.ldquoItrsquos nice for them as they enjoy it and itrsquos as close as they get to competitions now. Because they were used to competitions, they love engaging with people and they get to perform for the day as well.The businesswoman owned and developed the Fitzwilliam Hotel in Belfast and was a director of several other successful companies.She began to become more involved in business and leadership coaching after being asked to mentor Ulster Rugby in .ldquoFrom being to become involved in coaching, I began to learn about equine therapy about six years ago. Itrsquos now quite mainstream in the US, although it is still very new here, she explained.While some equine-therapy is based on people riding horses, interestingly the courses that June delivers for Armed Services veterans and others does not involve the person even getting on to a horse.ldquoI focus my workshops more on leadership as Irsquom very conscious that Irsquom not a therapist, said June.ldquoHorses are extremely therapeutic animals and after I saw a video called Wild Horse Warriors which shows the amazing effects of horses working with war veterans, I thought that I would love to do that as well as it combines my love of horses and my leadership coaching skills.ldquoThe whole idea of my course is that I donrsquot focus on the post-traumatic stress that veterans may have. I focus on building le-skills and being able to cope with whatever le throws at you.ldquoSo I developed a two-day workshop of exercises where people interact with horses to help them with their communications. Engaging with horses is exactly the same as engaging with people and they will let you knowyoursquove got it right or not.To get more information about Horses for People courses visit www.horsesforpeople..prettyPhoto

title: Lidl secures permission for new Newcastle store
story: SUPERMARKET giant Lidl is on the verge of securing outline planning permission for a major new store in Newcastle.Almost three years after it purchased the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site in the town, planners are recommending that the redevelopment proposal in an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty should proceed.Lidl submitted plans to redevelop the . acre Shanslieve Drive site in January last year, with the ambitious redevelopment including a new pound, base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team.The recommendation to grant outline planning approval for the brownfield site will be tabled at next weekrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee.Lidl Northern Irelandrsquos regional director, Conor Boyle, said the company welcomed the plannersrsquo approval recommendation for its proposed new store.Hs added: ldquoWe have engaged with the local community extensively on this proposal and look forward to the next stages in the planning process.Permission is being sought to bulldoze the existing school to pave the way for the construction of a new food store and dedicated centre for the volunteers who run the mountain rescue team.A new entrance via Bryansford Road is proposed, but there will be no access from Shanslieve Drive. The development proposal includes plans for almost  parking spaces, eight of which are reserved for mountain rescue team members.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal and while planners have received  objections, they have also received five letters in support of the proposal.In papers submitted ahead of next weekrsquos meeting, planners confirm that none of the statutory consultees, including the Department for Infrastructure, Rivers Agency, Environment Agency and the local environmental health department, have lodged any objections to the redevelopment of the former school site.They confirm that roads officials are content that the proposed development will not have any ldquoadverse impact on the existing road infrastructure and is acceptable in terms of road safety.Planners are also insisting that the indicative designs of both the new store and mountain rescue centre would not be inappropriate in this part of the resort.They say it is acknowledged that there are ldquoobvious restrictions for the redevelopment of the existing Lidl store in Railway Street and there are no alternative vacant sites in the town centre which can accommodate the supermarketrsquos needs.ldquoA suitable brownfield site has become available at the edge of the town centre which could accommodate the proposal and has met the requirements of strategic planning policy, say planners.They also confirmed that a study of the impact of the new store on existing retailers shows the proposed investment will not have any ldquosignicant or unacceptable impact on Newcastle town centre.Environmental health officials say they have no objection in principle to the investment, provided conditions are attached restricting hours of business and deliveries, with planners concluding that the overall impact of the proposal, which is close to a number of homes, is not considered to be ldquosignicantly detrimental to warrant a refusal of the application.Lidl has confirmed it plans to develop a new , square metre supermarket, explaining it opted to redevelop the former primary school site as there are limited opportunities to redevelop the storersquos current base at Railway Street in the resort.Lidl says it has been looking for alternative premises in Newcastle town centre for over a decade without success and that while properties have become available, none were suitable because they were too small.It says the current sales area at its Railway Street base is is too small for the store to carry a full range of goods, pointing to narrow aisles with limited circulation space. The company says the car park is too small and fails to meet its requirements, with the general customer experience falling short of a modern food store.Planners say that having assessed the ious planning policies and having regard to all representations made, all consultees engaged and all other material considerations, it is found that the proposal is acceptable in planning terms and approval is recommended..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle’s pop up beach back on agenda of council
story: A DECISION to reject a proposal for a pop-up beach in Newcastle has been overturned.Last month, a Newry, Mourne and Down Council Committee recommended not to proceed with the articial beach mdash similar to those in Paris and other parts of Europe ndash at the townrsquos promenade.However, the decision was overturned at Monday nightrsquos meeting of the full council when it was agreed to seek funding for the pop-up beach and develop a business case which could pave the way for its introduction.But not all councillors agreed, with Sinn Fein members rejecting it. They said there were health and safety concerns associated with the beach. They expressed support for transporting sand by road from Ballykinlar to Newcastle promenade and implementing an enhanced beach management plan.The radical suggestion to bring a touch of French summer flair to Newcastle was initially discussed last September when it was agreed to further explore the idea, with the initial focus on the cost of developing such a facility.The idea was suggested because of the lack of sand on Newcastle beach.Pop up beaches along the banks of the Seine and other cities and towns across Europe are hugely popular and some local politicians believe they can be a success in Newcastle.Council officials have confirmed that while Newcastle promenade is not suitable for pop-up beaches, two areas adjacent to the Downs Road car park would be suitable and that the cost over a nine-week period would be pound,.At last monthrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee, politicians rejected the pop-up proposal and agreed to seek a meeting with the Environment Agency to discuss securing a marine licence to transport sand from Ballykinlar to Newcastle.It was also suggested that groins would be placed along sections of beach to protect the sand and a programme of better beach management introduced. On Monday night, this recommendation was overturned by  votes to .Mournes SDLP councillor Laura Devlin, who initially proposed to explore the merits of a pop-up beach, said the local authority ldquoneeds to think outside the box to create an articial beach or ldquosimply accept that Newcastle will never have a sandy beach.She continued: ldquoIf improving the natural beach was an option I would obviously proceed in that direction. However, it is not workable.ldquoI have been advised in no uncertain terms by a iety of coastal erosion experts that importing sand to Newcastle or removing stones from the beach simply wonrsquot work due to the movement of sediment and that permission to do this work would be denied by central government.ldquoAs a councillor for Newcastle, I want to improve our tourism product and the pop-up beach proposal is simply my suggestion to try and do something dferent. I also recognise that an articial beach would have to be properly managed and maintained.Cllr Devlin added: ldquoA pop-up beach could not just be created at the start of the summer and left. It would have to be adequately cleaned and looked after. As a mother, I would not want my child playing in dirty sand so the management and cleanliness of the pop up beach is essential.ldquoThis suggestion wonrsquot be without itrsquos issues, but surely as a council it is our job to try and make improvements and better our area where possible, expressing disappointment Sinn Fein opposed her proposal.Sinn Feinrsquos Willie Clarke argued that there was no appetite for a pop-up beach and that the suggestion to move sand from Ballykinlar to Newcastle was to replace the hundreds of tonnes which drt away on a seasonal basis.He continued: ldquoHow are you going to manage a pop-up beach that will be filled with stagnant sand  There is the potential for both dogs and young infants to foul the sand and other health and safety issues which need to be addressed.ldquoWill the sand be cleaned every day  What measures will be taken to prevent sand from blowing up Main Street  Local people and traders want to see a sandy beach, not a pop-up beach. I believe it is a no brainer that we try to secure Environment Agency agreement to place sand on the beach.Cllr Clarke said part of the pleasure of going to the beach was being able to go into the water and suggested that a pop-up beach could not provide such an experience.He added: ldquoWe need to look at anti-social behaviour issues associated with pop-up beaches which could contain broken glass. I wonder who is going to look after them given the dficulty I have in getting someone to clean the beach ldquoWe need to invest resources to ensure the proper management of the beach and encourage people to go to parts of it where there is sand.Cllr Andy McMurray described pursuing the idea as ldquofolly given the current problems in keeping the promenade tidy..prettyPhoto

title: Penalties settle derby cup tie
story: BALLYNAHINCH Olympic set up a Clarence Cup quarter-final clash away to Comber Rec, but they had to do it the hard way at Kilmore Road on Saturday.The biting cold wind and rain turned this derby clash into a lottery which went to a penalty shoot-out that ended in total controversy.Olympic held a slight advantage at - on penalties when Kilmore goalkeeper Darren Ross threw his side a leline after he brilliantly saved Niall Murrayrsquos spot kick.This was no more than Kilmore deserved, but their players and supporters quickly became incandescent with rage when the referee insisted that Ross had moved off his line and ordered the spot kick to be taken again.Murray made no mistake at the second attempt and blasted Olympic into the last eight as Kilmore were left to rue what might have been.Olympic played with the swirling, gusting wind in their backs in the first half, but Matty Hardy and Jack Larkin at the heart of the Kilmore defence looked calm and composed.Olympic were struggling to get the ball down in the middle of the park and play their normal passing game as Kilmorersquos Michael Monan and Anton McGrattanrsquos forced Stevie and Ryan Noade into hurried passes.However, with  minutes gone Murray used the wind to his advantage.Olympic were awarded a free kick just inside the Kilmore half and out on the line beside their own dugout. Murray launched the ball high into orbit and wasnrsquot the least bit surprised when the wind took over and helped it on its way to the top right hand corner of the net with Ross clutching at thin air.Six minutes later at the other end Anton McGrattan struck yet another free kick from just outside the box past Ryan Walsh to bring the sides level.Olympic continued to see more of the ball, but Jones, when he did receive the ball out wide, was let down on a few occasions by a lack of support in the box and some wasteful finishing from Shane Murray.Kilmore were far from out of it and the bustling Joe McKinney was proving a handful and he almost gave the visitors a nd minute lead when he shot wide after a sizzling breakaway run from Anton McGrattan.Murray missed another good chance for Olympic after Jones carved out another opening before Kilmore seized the lead.Callum Dougan foraged deep and played a delightful through ball into the path of McKinney, who had beaten the offside trap. McKinney wasnrsquot for hanging around and after shrugging off Stevie McGoran, herounded lsquokeeper Walsh to make it -.The unrelenting wind and rain greeted both sets of players back for the second half and it was Kilmore who went on the offensive with Ryan Slavin being denied by Walsh.Two minutes later Kilmore shot themselves in the foot when Murray floated a free kick into the box and Jason Noade had all the time in the world to head the ball past Ross.Things became hot and heavy for a while with the tackles flying in, but clear cut chances at either end were hard to come by.Kilmore were now asking most of the questions, but a resolute Olympic rearguard refused to budge and Walsh had relatively little to do, apart from the odd shot from distance.Extra-time produced little of note, but Kilmore could have wrapped things up in the second period when McKinney crossed for Pete Casey, but, for once, he sliced his effort into no manrsquos land.Jones, Jason and Stevie Noadersquos first three penalties were perfect for Olympic, but they were matched by McGivern, McKinney and Larkin for Kilmore.Adam McLean nudged Olympic - ahead before Anton McGrattan fired his effort wide, advantage Olympic.Murrayrsquos first attempt was saved by Ross, but the referee made him retake the penalty as he insisted Ross had moved forward off his line. Murray was not about to look a gt horse in the mouth and drilled his second attempt to the net, much to the despair of a mightily aggrieved Kilmore side.Ballynahinch Olympic: Ryan Walsh, Dalton Tate, Aaron McClean, Jason Noade, Ryan Noade, Stevie McGoran, Stevie Noade, Ryan Molloy, Shane Murray, Niall Murray. Subs: Darren Lyons, Simon Marmion, Adam McLean.Kilmore Rec: Darren Ross, Eoin McGrattan, Larry McGonagle, Matty Hardy, Jack Larkin, Michael Monan, Anton McGrattan, Ryan Slavin, James McGivern, Callum Dougan, Joe McKinney. Subs: Peter Casey, Matthew Stewart, Mark McMahon.Ballynahinch Olympic Kilmore Rec CLARENCE CUP TH ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Planners give go ahead to Downpatrick hotel plans
story: DOWNPATRICK is in line for a major new -bedroom hotel.Planners will next week recommend that the eagerly-anticipated development on the site of the former Abbey Lodge Hotel on the Belfast Road should proceed.The new three storey hotel mdash being developed by Inch Abbey Holdings Ltd ndash features a range of leisure facilities including a swimming pool and health spa.The recommendation to approve the major new investment, which will create a number of full and part-time jobs, will be tabled at a meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee next Wednesday.In addition to the swimming pool and health spa, the new hotel will also offer bar, restaurant and conference facilities, asuite, changing rooms, treatment rooms, fitness suite and a gymnasium.Nine years ago, a property developer came close to investing in a new -bedroom hotel on the same site. While planning permission was secured, the proposal fell through due to the adverse economic circumstances at the town.The site was subsequently sold several years ago to a local businessman who is behind the new proposal to redevelop site which has been approved by a range of statutory agencies.Itrsquos understood access to the proposed new hotel will be via Inch Abbey Road, with parking located to the side and rear of the new , square metre building. There will also be a dedicated parking area for coaches.Original plans for the new hotel described finishing the exterior of the building in stone slate, with the accommodation centred around a landscaped courtyard. The proposed hotel development also includes plans to upgrade the Inch Abbey Road junction with the Belfast Road.News that the exciting new proposal is set to be given the green light next week comes after recent confirmation that planning permission is being sought to provide  new hotel rooms in Downpatrick town centre.The Downpatrick Property Trust is aiming to convert a number of existing flats at the junction of Market Street and Irish Street to provide what is being described as ldquooverflow hotel bedroom accommodation for nearby Denvirrsquos Coaching Inn.The proposal is also seeking permission for several hotel serviced apartments and to convert existing ground floor retail accommodation in Irish Street to a wheelchair accessible bedroom with an en-suite shower and toilet.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has placed tourism at the top of its agenda and is striving to attract more international visitors to stay overnight across the district. It has highlighted the need for additional hotel accommodation across the district.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran hopes the plannersrsquo recommendation for the Belfast Road site will be approved next week, paving the way for what he described as an ldquoexciting new development to help increase visitor number, provide new jobs and boost the local economy.He said the project would create jobs in the construction industry, provide a boost for local buildersrsquo suppliers and act as a catalyst for additional private sector investment.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThere is a need for more bed space in Downpatrick and this new development, which will complement existing provision, is most welcome. The fact that new conference facilities form part of the new hotel proposal is an added boost to the town.ldquoThe new hotel will help the local council with its drive to attract more overnight visitors to the district and I very much look forward to construction work getting underway..prettyPhoto

title: The pride of Portaferry
story: PORTAFERRYrsquoS Ciara Mageean was the toast of Irish athletics in Scotland on Sunday night.The  year-old middle distance runner won bronze in the m race at the European Indoor Championships in Glasgow mdash but it could so easily have been silver.Mageean clocked a time of :. behind runaway winner Laura Muir of Great Britain and was pipped on the line by Polandrsquos Sofia Ennaoui.It is her first indoor medal at European level and goes along a bronze won over the same distance outdoors at the  European Championships.Ciara ran a patient race, taking an outside route during the bunched start, and as hometown hero Muir began to pick up the pace she looked assured of a medal going into the final lap.It looked for a time like it might be silver as she headed Ennaoui coming off the final bend, but she cruelly beaten on the line.She said afterwards: ldquoPeople talk about dferent things in athletics, but I donrsquot do it for the money, and the amazing times are very few and far in between.For Mageean there was also added justication in her move to Manchester in late  after a below-par run at the World Championships in London.She said she was delighted to win bronze, but admitted that she was slightly annoyed that it was not silver.ldquoI came into these championships to win a medal. But thatrsquos the athlete and competitor in me. If anyone said to me a few months back you can take any medal, Irsquod have said yeah, Irsquoll have that.ldquoBut I knew I was in good shape, knew I was training well, in form, so be able to deliver that out on the track means an awful lot.ldquoI just wanted to walk off the track with my head held high. Irsquove beat myself up before after Irsquove finished, but I go out to enjoy my athletics now as well, she added.Two bronze medals left Ireland nd on the medal table, but Mageean sees great potential in the Irish team and is hopeful for the future with the World Championships and the Tokyo Olympics on the horizon.ldquoFor us to come away with two medals here is fantastic, she said. ldquoIt is such a young team and I am delighted to be able to show the younger athletes that Ireland can be up there and we can be fighting.She added: To be able to come here and show off the form Irsquove been in andwalk away with a medal, you canrsquot be any more happy than that..prettyPhoto

title: outstanding quality at second calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. title: ruas winter fair to become important dairy showcase
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: judges praise fantastic calf fair

If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valTheresa May#s Brexit strategy has been dealt a devastating blow after the House of Commons rejected her EU Withdrawal Agreement by an overwhelming majority for the second time.MPs voted by  to  against the deal, including all  DUP MPs voting against, despite the prime minister’s assurance that new agreements reached with Jean-Claude Juncker in Strasbourg would ensure the UK cannot be trapped in the controversial backstop arrangement indefinitely.Prime Minister Theresa May speaking in the House of Commons, London, after the governments Brexit deal was rejected by  votes to . Photo: House of Commons PA WireAlthough the  margin was reduced from the record -vote defeat of the first “meaningful vote” in January, Mrs May was left far adrt from a majority with just  days to go to the scheduled date of Brexit on March .European Commission president Mr Juncker had already warned thatMPs turned down the package agreed in Strasbourg on Monday, there would be “no third chance” to renegotiate.In line with a promise set out by Mrs May last month, MPs are now due to vote on Wednesday on whether they are willing for the UK to leave the EU without a deal on March .Mrs May announced that she will grant Conservative MPs a free vote on a motion stating that “this House declines to approve leaving the European Union without a Withdrawal Agreement and a framework on the future relationship on March   and notes that leaving without a deal remains the default in UK and EU law unless this House and the EU raty an agreement”.Prime Minister Theresa May speaking during the Brexit debate in the House of Commons, London today, Tuesday March . Photo: UK Parliament Jessica Taylor PA WireIf MPs reject no-deal as most Westminster observers expect, a third vote will follow on Thursday on whether to authorise Mrs May to request an extension of the two-year Article  negotiation process.A Labour Party spokesman said: “Allowing a free vote on no deal shows Theresa May has given up any pretence of leading the country. Once again, she’s putting her party’s interests ahead of the public interest.”Struggling with a croaky voice, Mrs May said that she still believed that leaving with a deal was the best option for Britain and that “the deal we’ve negotiated is the best and indeed the only deal available.”She added: “Let me be clear. Voting against leaving without a deal and for an extension does not solve the problems we face.“The EU will want to know what use we mean to make of such an extension and this House will have to answer that question. Does it wish to revoke Article   Does it want to hold a second referendum  Or does it want to leave with a deal, but not this deal “These are unenviable choices. Thanks to the decision that the House has made this evening, they are choices that must now be faced.”An extension requires the unanimous agreement of all  remaining member states, and Mr Juncker has warned that it cannot stretch beyond May  unless the UK takes part in the European Parliament elections starting on that date.DUP will not back May’s Brexit deal Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Following the vote, a spokesman for European Council president Donald Tusk said: “On the EU side we have done all that is possible to reach an agreement. Given the additional assurances provided by the EU in December, January and yesterday, it is dficult to see what more we can do. If there is a solution to the current impasse it can only be found in London.”The spokesman said that the EU stood by the Withdrawal Agreement reached in November.But he added: “With only  days left to March , today’s vote has signicantly increased the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit. We will continue our no-deal preparations and ensure that we will be readysuch a scenario arises.“Should there be a UK reasoned request for an extension, the EU will consider it and decide by unanimity. The EU will expect a credible justication for a possible extension and its duration. The smooth ing of the EU institutions will need to be ensured.”Cabinet gave its approval to Mrs May’s package at an early-morning meeting in  Downing Street which ended with the PM telling colleagues: “Today is the day. Let’s get this done.”But the momentum moved sharply against the Prime Minister shortly afterwards, as Attorney General Geoffrey Cox released formal legal advice that the changes secured by Mrs May “reduce the risk” that the backstop will be permanent, but do not remove it altogether.The Star Chamber of lawyers convened by the Brexit-backing European Research Group declared that three new documents agreed in Strasbourg failed to deliver the legally-binding changes demanded by the Commons.And the Democratic Unionist Party — which props up Mrs May’s minority administration in the Commons — said its  MPs would vote against the latest deal as “sufficient progress has not been achieved at this time”.With husband Philip watching from the Commons gallery, the Prime Minister warned MPs that “Brexit could be lost”they gave her deal the thumbs-down again.But she met a wall of hostility from her own party as well as the opposition parties, with  Conservative MPs voting against along with  Labour,  SNP,  Liberal Democrats,  DUP, four Plaid Cymru,  Independents and Green Party MP Caroline Lucas.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said that “no signicant changes” had been secured in two months of negotiations and the Government’s strategy was “in tatters”.Brexit figurehead and former foreign secretary Boris Johnson told the Commons that Mrs May and Mr Cox had “sowed an apron of fig leaves that does nothing to conceal the embarrassment and indignity of the UK.”Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told the Commons: “After three months of running down the clock the Prime Minister has, despite very extensive delays, achieved not a single change to the Withdrawal Agreement.“Not one single word has changed. In terms of the substance, literally, nothing has changed.”Charles Walker, vice chairman of the  Committee of backbench Tory MPs, warned that defeat in the second “meaningful vote” on Tuesday evening would lead to a general election.He told BBC Radio ’s World At One: “If it doesn’t go through tonight, as sure as night follows day, there will be a general election within a matter of days or weeks.“It is not sustainable, the current situation in Parliament.”try catch  TrendingStorm Gareth worse than originally thought - N.I. to be pummelled by mph galesNewry murders: Distraught father will lsquosell taxirsquo for chance to say goodbyePolice not seeking anyone  in connection with Newry deathsN.I. child reported missing is found safe and wellN.I. title: chance to join artists to help build penarth winter carnival
story: There will be open workshops hosted in the days running up to the carnival, exploring activity ideas, making costumes, masks and more.The workshops, traditionally known as mas camps, are sponsored by Waterloo Tea Rooms and will be attended by carnival artists from the Butetown Carnival. The artists will be at Penarth Pier Pavilion each afternoon from Wednesday  Feb  to Friday  March  to help build the Penarth Carnival.The drop-in sessions are for adults and families, and youngsters under  are asked to bring an adult.Nikki Fogaty, who helps run the mas camp for Butetown Carnival and will assist with the Penarth Carnival preparations, said: ldquoMas camp is sometimes a bit hectic, but can be great fun. You donrsquot need any experience, just be willing to join in. Come down with an idea for making a costume and find help. Therersquoll be experienced carnival makers here, andyou have got material then bring it, but you can just turn up.Artists from Penarth interested in being involved in the camp and helping with the carnival are invited to a meeting this Saturday  February  in the Beat Centre, West Close, Butetown from pm to pm. They can meet with Butetown artists to plan for the Penarth carnival.On Sunday  February  between pm-pm, interested residents can find out more about the festival at the Penarth Pier Pavilion. Members of the group developing the carnival will be meeting to share plans and welcome new ideas.Carnival organiser Richard Parry is also encouraging Penarth residents to book a day off work to enjoy the carnival on Monday, March .ldquoGive yourself a winter holiday break in your own town, he said Richard. ldquoTherersquos no queuing at airports, traffic jams or packing. Wersquore encouraging as many people in the town as possible to wriggle out of work and make a festival day.The festival will take place across Penarth from March  to March .A new website for the carnival has been launched.
